HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING ON; 
The Big Island

BYLINE:  By MICHELE KAYAL; MICHELE KAYAL is a journalist who lives in Honolulu.

 BODY:
One easy cure for "rock fever" -- the vague claustrophobia that sometimes overwhelms residents of the smaller Hawaiian islands -- is to head for the wide-open spaces of the Big Island, also called Hawaii. Nearly twice the size of the five other major islands combined and one of the most diverse, the Big Island's soaring peaks and bubbling volcano, ancient Hawaiian sites and many resorts offer visitors a compact sampling of the state's best attributes. 
 The Big Island is believed to be the landing place of the very first Hawaiians, and some of their spirit is captured by musicians, like the masters who will lead a ukulele and slack-key guitar program in the upcountry town of Waimea. South of the volcano, considered sacred by many Hawaiians, elders hold front-porch-style chats that offer insights into the culture beyond the hotel luau. 
 The island is also a place of beauty and brawn, with a community of prolific artists thriving deep in the rain forest of Volcano Village, and nearly two centuries of paniolo (cowboy) culture kept alive in rodeos and livestock auctions. The coming weeks offer a rare chance to dip into all of it. 

Events
People in this fertile countryside pride themselves on knowing how to eat, and visitors can join in at the Big Island Festival, (866) 424-3378, www.bigislandfestival.com, Nov. 5 to 9, which this year has lured chefs like Cornelius Gallagher of Oceana in New York and local celebrities like George Mavrothalassitis, known as Chef Mavro, a 2003 James Beard Award winner. Gourmands can get tips from nearly two dozen chefs. A tour of a state-of-the-art aquaculture facility (which produces lobster, clams, oysters and other seafood) just outside the Kona airport ends with a seafood lunch. An "adventure tasting" seminar with Keith Famie, a Food Network personality (and "Survivor II" participant), will challenge festivalgoers to identify exotic foods. Tickets for the more than 80 events, spread among seven resorts on the Kohala Coast (on the Kona side), range from $55 to $150, with multiple-event passes from $140.
A lantern parade through the seaside town of Kailua-Kona on Nov. 7 officially kicks off the Kona Coffee Cultural Festival, Nov. 6 to 16, www.konacoffeefest.com, (808) 326-7820. A coffee-picking contest, a "cupping" workshop -- think wine-tasting for coffee fanatics -- and other events celebrate Kona's 600-plus coffee farms. A $3 festival button, available at events, provides general admission; some events have additional fees and require reservations. 
Anyone who has fallen in love with Hawaii through its music can participate in the Waimea Ukulele and Slack Key Guitar Institute, Nov. 8 to 10, at the Kahilu Theatre, 67-1186 Lindsey Road (behind Parker Ranch Center), Waimea; (808) 885-6868, www.kahilutheatre.org. Masters including Led Kaapana and the father-son team of Dennis and David Kamakahi will lead beginners, experts and nonmusicians in workshops, master classes and kanikapila, or jam sessions. Per-class fees are $40 to $60. The artists will also pluck and chat in conversational forums called "talk story" sessions ($10). A master concert Nov. 7 opens the event, with tickets $25 to $35.
The Hawaiian cultural specialist Kepa Maly will sit under an ohia tree at He Kula Na Mea Hawaii (A School of Things Hawaiian) on the corner of Tiki Lane and Princess Kaiulani Streets in Ocean View, (808) 929-8700, www.hekula.org, on Nov. 8 at 7 p.m. and tell stories of the surrounding Kau district, the southern region where the first Hawaiians are thought to have landed on their journey from Polynesia. The program is free; a fish dinner costs $10. Uncle George Naope, one of Hawaii's best-loved hula masters and musicians, and others will follow on Dec. 6 from 4 to 8 p.m. with songs and tales of Hawaii's past. Admission is $15, with dinner; reservations required.
In the nearby town of Naalehu, paniolos from more than a half-dozen ranches will wrestle cattle and rope steers in the Kau Roping and Riding Association's Big Island Invitational Ranch Rodeo on Nov. 22 at Naalehu Arena on Spur Road, Naalehu; (808) 929-8079. The homegrown rodeo is one of many throughout the year on the Big Island, the seat of Hawaii's ranching industry. Admission: $5 at the gate. Also that day, the public is invited to the livestock auction at Parker Ranch Rodeo Arena, Mamalahoa Highway, Waimea, (808) 885-7311, where ranchers and cowboys will bid on Angus bulls, cows, heifers and horses (free). 
Volcano Village's rain forest nurtures a diverse community of artists, and from Nov. 28 to 30 more than a dozen open their studios to visitors during the Volcano Village Art Studio Tour and Sale, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., free; (808) 967-7247. Free maps, available at Kilauea General Store next to the Aloha gas station, (808) 967-7555, will point visitors to the contemporary blown glass, paintings, pottery, jewelry, fiber art and masks made at eight local studios. 
Thousands come to cheer Boy Scouts, church choirs and farmers in the annual Waimea Christmas Parade on Dec. 6, Mamalahoa Highway, Waimea; (808) 885-3633. Dozens of big rigs, the mainstay of the Big Island economy, are dressed up in lights, and the local electric company wheels out a steam locomotive. The parade ends at Parker Ranch Center, at the town's main intersection, where Santa takes wish lists and photographs. 

Sightseeing
Visitors have a rare opportunity to watch molten rock flow from the earth at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, on Highway 11, 30 miles southwest of Hilo; (808) 985-6000, www.nps.gov/havo. A seven-day pass is $10 per vehicle. Hiking distance to the flow and the quality of what can be seen there vary daily as the lava shifts. Rangers provide information at the visitor center, on Crater Rim Drive less than a quarter mile from the park entrance station, (808) 985-6017, open 7:45 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily. 
The summit of Mauna Kea, the Pacific's tallest peak at 13,796 feet, is home to 12 observatories, and two of the world's most powerful optical telescopes at the Keck Observatory. The visitors' gallery there is open 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. (free). The Visitor Center, at 9,200 feet on the road to the summit, (808) 961-2180, www.ifa.hawaii.edu/info/vis, offers free night stargazing programs. It's open daily 9 a.m. to 10 p.m. Take Highway 200 from Hilo or Waimea; turn uphill at mile marker 28.
Radiant magenta dragonfruit and three-pound mangoes are standard fare at the Hilo Farmers Market, corner of Mamo Street and Kamehameha Avenue, Hilo, (808) 933-1000, www.hilofarmersmarket.com, Wednesday and Saturday 6 a.m. to 4 p.m. There 175 vendors showcase their island flowers and produce. 
The Laupahoehoe Train Museum, 36-2377 Mamalahoa Highway, Laupahoehoe, (808) 962-6300, www.geocities.com/trainmuseum, was created five years ago to entice tourists to a town ravaged by the sugar industry's failure. Videos, photos and displays set up in the former station master's 1928 home tell the story of sugar and plantation life, and the railroad that served them. A 1930 diesel switch engine rolls along 250 feet of track. Open weekdays 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., weekends 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. General admission, $3.

Where to Stay
Carson's Volcano Cottages, 11-3920 Sixth Street, Volcano, (800) 845-5282, fax (808) 967-8094, www.carsonsvolcanocottage.com, just 1.5 miles from the entrance to Volcano National Park, has hot tubs and wood-burning stoves among its 11 units, each whimsically decorated in styles from vintage Hawaiiana to elegant Japanese. Homemade cobblers, breads and coffee cakes are standard breakfast fare. Doubles from $110 to $165. 
The 436-room Royal Kona Resort, 75-5852 Alii Drive, Kailua-Kona, (808) 329-3111, fax (808) 329-9532, www.royalkona.com, on the ocean, offers large rooms with a tropical motif, swimming in a small manmade lagoon. Doubles: $160 to $270. 
Budget: The Kona Tiki Hotel, 75-5968 Alii Drive, Kailua-Kona, (808) 329-1425, fax (808) 327-9402, www.konatiki.com, is so close to the ocean that waves wash into the pool. The cheerful decor and ocean-facing lanais (small verandas) of all 15 rooms make up for their lack of TV, phone and air-conditioning; Continental breakfast included in the double rate, from $61; with kitchenettes, $84.
Attentive touches distinguish the 30 simple, motel-like rooms at the Kamuela Inn, 65-1300 Kawaihae Road, in the inland cattle town of Waimea (also known as Kamuela); (800) 555-8968, fax (808) 885-8857, www.kamuelainn.com. They include country quilts, Asian accents or back lanais. Doubles from $59; phones only in the higher-priced rooms. 
Luxury: The Mauna Lani Bay Hotel and Bungalows, 68-1400 Mauna Lani Drive, Kohala Coast, (800) 367-2323, fax (808) 885-1484, www.maunalani.com, on the Kona side, has 350 rooms in cool off-white with sleek, contemporary furniture. The property is steeped in Hawaiian culture, with ancient fish ponds and a cultural specialist on staff. There is a palm-dotted beach and two 18-hole golf courses, including an oceanfront course. Doubles from $385. 
The Hilton Waikoloa Village, 425 Waikoloa Beach Drive, Waikoloa, (808) 886-1234, fax (808) 886-2900, www.hiltonwaikoloavillage.com, also on the Kohala Coast, is so big that a tram transports guests around the property. There are canal boats, a dolphin pool and an artificial lagoon with a waterfall; golfers have two 18-hole courses. The 1,240 rooms spread among three towers have lanais, room for lounging, and decor in beige and neutrals with rattan touches. Doubles from $199. 

Where to Eat
Cafe Pesto, Suite 101, Kawaihae Center, Kawaihae, (808) 882-1071, bends its Italian fare to fit the islands, serving Pacific seafood risotto and hand-tossed pizzas topped traditionally or with local favorites like kalua pig or chili-grilled shrimp in a casual atmosphere. Lunch, dinner daily. Dinner for two $70, with wine. 
At Thai Thai Restaurant, just down from the Volcano General Store in Volcano, (808) 967-7969, the green papaya salad is salty, sweet and hot all at the same time; the curries are rich and satisfying. Statues and photos from Thailand decorate the laid-back 12-table dining space. Ordering dishes "Thai hot" is only for the brave. Dinner, served nightly, runs $45 for two, with beer. 
The Lava Rock Cafe, behind the Kilauea General Store next to the Aloha gas station in Volcano, (808) 967-8526, serves burgers and steaks plus local favorites like breaded chicken katsu, saimin noodle soup and chili-rice bowl. Open Tuesday to Saturday for all meals; breakfast and lunch only on Sunday and Monday. Dinner for two with wine made in Volcano, $35.
One of the few places to find local color in a tourist town is the Ocean View Inn, 75-5683 Alii Drive in Kailua-Kona, (808) 329-9998, with coffeehouse staples like meatloaf, chicken a la king and pork cutlet with gravy in a no-nonsense atmosphere. Dessert? Jell-O, of course. Dinner for two with beer or wine, $35.
Everything at Merriman's, in Opelo Plaza on Mamalahoa Highway in Waimea, (808) 885-6822, from spinach salad with beef jerky standing in for bacon to the wok-seared snapper with wasabi cream sauce, features the freshest local ingredients paired in exciting ways. Dinner nightly, lunch weekdays. Dinner for two with wine, $125.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
In Mount Kisco, a Store Rises From the Ashes

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO 

 BODY:
DESTROYED in a fire three years ago, the Elephant's Trunk, a family-owned clothing and costume store here since the early 1970's, reopened last week in a new brick building on Main Street. It becomes a co-anchor with the national retailer Borders Books and Music in a redeveloping section of this northern Westchester village, a retail and commercial hub about 35 miles north of Manhattan.
 The return of Elephant's Trunk, which sold jeans and hippie-styled clothing when it first opened 32 years ago and these days offers mother-of-the-bride ensembles to many of those same customers, attests to the success of the village's expansion and revitalization efforts. 
 The downtown area had struggled in the slow economy of the early 1990's, and then at the end of the decade was stricken by a flood related to the tropical storm Floyd and, less that a year later, the fire at the Elephant's Trunk.
As part of the recovery effort, the village installed storm drains and contained a creek in a former swamp area between Main Street and South Moger Avenue. It has also planted grass and built parking lots and walkways in the now parklike setting that connects its two main retail streets. 
With several hundred stores, Mount Kisco has mom-and-pop retailers, some of them dating back several generations, as well as larger chain stores like Banana Republic, Victoria's Secret, the Gap and Starbucks. Nancy Hack, the president of Mount Kisco's Chamber of Commerce and president of Hack Insurance Agency, a family business dating back to 1918, described Mount Kisco as "a smaller version of White Plains with a hometown feeling."
Referring to the explosive retail and residential growth now taking place in White Plains, which is about 18 miles south of Mount Kisco, Ms. Hack said, "We're growing here too, but on a smaller scale and in keeping with the suburban community that we are." She said Mount Kisco's retail and commercial sectors mainly serve residents in northern Westchester and lower Putnam County. In White Plains, meanwhile, several large shopping centers and a new $350 million retail-entertainment-residential complex draw from a broad area encompassing New Rochelle to the south and Fairfield County to the north and east. 
Covering 3.1 miles, Mount Kisco has a population of 10,000 residents, and twice that number on workdays. The village's three largest employers are Northern Westchester Hospital Center, Mount Kisco Medical Group and the Visiting Nurse Association of Hudson Valley. In all, the village has 775,091 square feet of commercial office space and a 5 percent office vacancy rate, according to Phyllis Tunnell, a commercial real estate broker with T Square Properties, which has offices here and in White Plains.
Ms. Tunnell observed that a few law firms and financial firms had opened satellite offices in Mount Kisco rather than in White Plains. The growth of Mount Kisco's commercial and retail sectors is reflected in the Chamber of Commerce's growing membership, which recently reached 150, Ms. Hack said. 
THE owners of Elephant's Trunk, the brothers Rafael and Robert Brache, who grew up in Mount Kisco and started the business when they were 21 and 19 respectively, said they decided to rebuild the new three-story store at the same site as the original wood-frame building because of Main Street's rebirth.
"We were lonely here for many years, but that's not the case anymore," Rafael Brache said, explaining that restaurants, boutiques and other smaller retailers have opened new stores or expanded existing ones along Main Street and that Borders Books had brought more foot traffic to the area. The first of a number of chains to move to Mount Kisco, Borders arrived in the mid-1990's, followed by the Gap and others.
South Moger Avenue, which runs parallel to Main Street and is home to just a handful of smaller concerns, has attracted more of the chains, including the Gap, Baby Gap, Chico's and Starbucks. In addition, a new retail area of about half a dozen stores was built just behind South Moger when the village renovated the area between the two streets. At the same time, some stores that were accessible only to the street created second entrances from the parking area. 
At the new Elephant's Trunk on Main Street, the brothers have discontinued their costume rental business, instead creating space for two more retailers. They recently leased storefronts to Dorothy Stein of Eastchester, a lingerie concern, and Chiara Scura, a shoe store in Chappaqua. It is the first expansion for each retailer.
The Brache brothers purchased the original building, an empty site that had at various times been an antique store, hotel and bar, in the early 1970's for $100,000 and had just paid off their mortgage when the building was struck by the fire, which apparently started in an electrical box and was ruled accidental. The new $1 million building has 9,000 square feet of space, the same as the old building.
To maximize the space available, the owners obtained village approval to rebuild on the original store's footprint, even though current zoning requires more setback space from the street and sidewalk. The owners also created a third floor where only a loft had existed before.
To relieve some of the pressure on parking in the village, the owners chipped 50 feet off a granite outcropping in the rear of their property, creating 16 spaces for cars where there had previously been eight. Part of the parking lot will be covered in a porous mixture of grass and concrete to minimize the amount of runoff to the main roadway and storm drains.
DANIEL MONTROY, the architect for the project, said the owners chose weathered brick for the exterior instead of replicating the 1920's wood frame structure, because they wanted the new store to blend in with Village Hall across the street and to create a more substantial appearance on that section of the busy street.
The interior of the new Elephant's Trunk is designed to suggest that of a European opera house, with arched windows, 10-foot ceilings, elaborate chandeliers and a soaring staircase, said Mr. Montroy, a partner in Montroy Andersen Design Group in Manhattan.
Mayor Patricia M. Reilly, a fifth-generation resident of Mount Kisco, noted that the smaller retailers and the larger chains provide a healthy mix today for the village. "You can go to any Banana Republic in any place in the U.S. and find the same items for sale," she said. "With the smaller stores mixed in, you have a counterbalance."
On South Moger Avenue, Jeffrey and Edward Smilkstein, twin brothers who own Smilkstein's Shoes, agreed that the arrival of chain retailers had helped to inject new energy into the retail area. Members of the Smilkstein family have been retailers here since 1910, but in the 1980's the family sold off other property, including a department store. All that remains of the family business is the children's shoe store.
As the mayor said, "When the chains came in, some of us who were born here worried that the village would never be the same." Her mother, she recalled, shopped in the now-defunct Abel's Department Store, where the sales clerks knew not only their customers' first names, but also the sizes of everyone in the family.
"Yes, the village has changed," said the mayor, a retired health services coordinator for the Bedford Central School District, "and Mount Kisco may not be the same as it was when I was growing up here. But the changes are for the good, because we've been able to balance the old in a way that hasn't sacrificed the small-town qualities that drew us here to begin with."

A picture caption in some regional editions last Sunday with an article about downtown Mount Kisco, N.Y., misidentified one of two men shown in front of a new store, Elephant's Trunk. The man at the right was Daniel Montroy, the architect, not Rafael Brache, an owner.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/East Midtown; 
New Hotel Seeks Executives on Extended Stays

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
DESPITE the decline in occupancy and steep falloff in nightly room rates over the past three years, this is a good time to open a new hotel in New York, said Mary Lou Pollack, general manager of the Alex on 45th Street just east of Third Avenue. Her hotel is expected to open within a few weeks when the last fixtures are installed and city approvals are obtained.
 "Things may look bad compared to the big party in 2000," when the occupancy rate citywide approached 84 percent, "but occupancy in this neighborhood has reached into the 80's," she said. "That is not bad. Fall is a strong time in New York, and room rates in the premium sector are up 12 to 13 percent over last year." 
 Across the city, the numbers have just begun to move upward from a decline that began in early 2001 and was greatly aggravated by the attack of Sept. 11. But industry executives and consultants say the market for hotel properties is coming back to life after having been frozen in place for several years. Capital is available to finance hotel deals, and buildings are once again changing hands. 
In fact, it was announced last week that Marriott would open the first new hotel in Harlem since the 1950's, as part of a mixed-use development at 125th Street and Park Avenue. 
Hotel investors are seeking to position themselves to take advantage in an anticipated economic recovery and increase in travel said Arthur Adler, managing director for the Americas of Jones Lang LaSalle Hotels, a division of the brokerage and services company.
"It has been a tough couple of years, but now owners are looking at their properties and deciding whether to sell now or wait," he said. There is expected to be no shortage of eager buyers.
"There are barriers to entry in New York, just are there are in other major cities," Mr. Adler said. "When the economic tide turns, they stand to benefit."
"There is a tremendous amount of capital interested in investing in lodging right now," said Mark Gordon, a managing director of the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, an investment banker specializing in real estate. He said that investors were seeking to put money into hotel deals and lenders seemed to have funds available as well. 
"It is a great time to refinance hotels," he said. "Rates are at a 40-year low and lots of lenders are interested in doing refinancing. Sonnenblick-Goldman has done $2 billion in hotel refinancing in the last two years and has another $500 million in deals pending."
On the equity side, he said, foreign companies in particular are looking to buy or build hotels, primarily in New York to establish a presence in this country. "Look at the Mandarin in Columbus Circle" at the Time Warner Center, he said. "That is going to be their headquarters in this country, and you have to pay a premium to do that." 
Some people think the operating side of the business has started to bounce up from the bottom. The revenue per available room, a key economic indicator for the industry, increased one-tenth of a percentage point in New York in June compared with the corresponding month in 2002, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. That may not seem like much, but it was the first time this year that the financial performance exceeded the year-earlier month.
It was driven by an increase in occupancy of 5.8 percentage points, to 82.6 percent; hotel operators are wary about trying to raise rates until it is clear that the occupancy gains can be sustained. Although the movement was in the upward direction, there is a long way to go. According to PricewaterhouseCoopers, revenue per available room fell from a high of $189 in 2000 to $140 in 2002 and continued to decline this year until the reversal in June, when it rose to $142.61.
Anecdotal evidence may precede the statistics. "I tried to find a room last weekend for a business associate, and it was hard to do," said Izak Senbahar, one of the developers of the 33-story Alex. "Hotels in the city are starting to fill up."
He said there has been an increase in business activity on Third Avenue, where many of the existing buildings have been refurbished. The Alex, he said, has been designed for corporate executives visiting those businesses, with 73 of the hotel's 203 guest rooms equipped with full kitchens for people planning to stay for more than a few days. Room rates range from $375 to $1,500 a night, although discounts are available for longer stays.
"Our target is business people planning to stay for a few weeks or a few months," Mr. Senbahar said.
TO accommodate those guests, each of the rooms is equipped with desks with telephone and Internet connections. And the hotel has printers and fax machines on wheeled carts that can be quickly moved into rooms. The idea, Ms. Pollock said, is to have the machines available without making the rooms look like office cubicles.
For those who do not want to cook for themselves, the hotel will include a restaurant created by Marcus Samuelsson, the executive chef at Aquavit. The restaurant, Riingo, whose name is derived from the Japanese word for apple, will have its own entrance on 45th Street, but will also provide 24-hour room service to the hotel.
Even though the hotel business seems to be recovering, the strong market for permanent residential space is leading to some conversions from hotel use. One example is the Delmonico Hotel, on Park Avenue and 59th Street, which is being converted into condominiums. "A hotel today cannot compete with residential at a prime location like Park and 59th," Mr. Gordon said.
Other hotels that are expected to become residences are the Empire, Middletown and Windsor, industry professionals say. The Courtyard hotel, on Third Avenue between 52nd and 53rd Streets, currently in bankruptcy proceedings, is also expected to be converted into long-term residences.
Butsome properties changing hands are expected to stay as hotels, often after extensive renovation. The 722-room Metropolitan Hotel on 51st Street and Lexington Avenue was sold in July by Loews Hotel to a group including Goldman Sachs's Whitehall fund. It is expected to undergo a $22 million refurbishment, including the addition of 10 guest rooms, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers.
The 180-room Doral Park Avenue at 38th Street was also sold this year and will be managed by the Kimpton Hotel and Restaurant Group, that company's first property in New York. It is expected to have a $19 million renovation, which will include a major restaurant and the addition of 17 guest rooms.
Another hotel that has been the subject of speculation is the Roosevelt on Madison Avenue between 45th and 46th Streets, which has more than 1,000 rooms. Many industry analysts expect that the building, which occupies a full block just north of Grand Central Terminal, will be converted to an office building. 
"That is a great office building site," said Mr. Adler. "It is just south of the new Bear Stearns headquarters, and it is a big hotel with small rooms."
Also on the block are the last two of the group of four boutique hotels developed by Bernard Goldberg and currently owned by Credit Suisse First Boston. The Roger Williams and the Franklin have been sold, and the Mansfield and Shoreham remain available.
Developing a new hotel during a downturn had its advantages, Ms. Pollack said. "We caught the labor market at the low end this summer," she said. "People are happy to come to work in a new project. That condition did not exist in 2000."
If the upturn in occupancy continues, hotel operators will rely less on heavily discounted Internet sales to fill rooms, improving their revenues, said Sean Hennessey, director of the New York area hospitality practice for PricewaterhouseCoopers. 
But, he said, labor, insurance and property taxes are going up as well, squeezing profitability. "It's an improvement, but not a case for joy," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the 33-story Alex Hotel, which is expected to open within a few weeks at 205 East 45th Street, 73 of the 203 guest rooms are to be equipped with full kitchens. The project is intended to capitalize on an increase in business activity on Third Avenue. (Photo by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Nongambling Attractions For Atlantic City Project

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY 

 BODY:
MENTION the name of this city and two words pop to mind: casino and boardwalk. 
 That sums up the essential experience of visiting Atlantic City, conceded Dennis C. Gomes, president for resort operations for the Aztar Corporation, which owns the Tropicana Casino and Resort in Atlantic City and an establishment with the same name in Las Vegas. "You come, you gamble, maybe you walk along the ocean a little bit, and that's pretty much it for many people," he said. 
 In Las Vegas, by contrast, the city is nearly as famous for its lavish shows and enticing shopping as for its casinos -- and nongambling properties generate substantial profits, Mr. Gomes added. 
In 2002, according to gambling control authorities in Nevada and New Jersey, the 43 casinos in the Las Vegas "Strip" generated $4.6 billion in gambling receipts, but Atlantic City generated almost as much, $4.3 billion, with only 12 casinos.
On the other hand, the 43 properties on the Las Vegas Strip also generate about $4.4 billion in nongambling revenue, including lodging, from their 40 million annual visitors, Mr. Gomes said. This compares with $300 million from 32 million visitors a year for Atlantic City's 12 properties, he said.
"Imagine the market potential for Atlantic City if we could up the ante and provide a more well rounded gaming and nongaming experience to visitors," said Mr. Gomes, who held various executive positions in casino hotels in both Atlantic City and Las Vegas before becoming the head of Aztar's resort operations.
Now, his company is making a big play to do that very thing, with a $245 million expansion project at the Tropicana here that possesses what Mr. Gomes calls "Las Vegas meets Atlantic City" qualities. The project includes a new 28-story tower across Pacific Avenue from the Tropicana. This building has 505 new hotel rooms on 18 floors, bringing the resort's total to 2,126 rooms, making it the largest hotel in New Jersey. Other features include 45,000 square feet of meeting rooms, executive boardrooms and four convention and hospitality suites on the top floor that are to feature floor-to-ceiling windows. The building's other 10 floors are taken by a parking garage.
But the ground-breaking aspect, Mr. Gomes said, will be the Quarter, a separate building with three floors and 200,000 square feet of nongambling space.
Designed to suggest the look of old Havana, the new buildings are going up on a former parking lot across from the Tropicana's three towers along the ocean boardwalk. The Quarter is to be connected with the existing towers by a wide bridge over Pacific Avenue that will house some of 40 new shops that are to be added. The new tower, which has a Spanish-style dome and cupola, has already been topped out. The Quarter is not expected to open until April 2004.
Earlier this year, the Tropicana's 220-yard oceanside facade was renovated to extend the Spanish architectural elements, bright stained glass and teal and terra cotta colors that will distinguish the Quarter over to the Boardwalk. The Marketplace at the Boardwalk, on the lower floors of the Tropicana, also opened earlier this year, with 12 dining, nightclub, retail and live entertainment spots. 
The Quarter at the Tropicana will house a mix of national and regional retailers, live music venues and a number of well-known bars and restaurants from New York, Philadelphia and Las Vegas.
The list of tenants so far includes retailers like Brooks Brothers, Chico's, Mondi, Swarovski, the Spy Store and Zephyr Gallery. The restaurants will be Carmine's, based in New York; Cuba Libre, based in Philadelphia; and Red Square, based in Las Vegas; plus chains found in other parts of the country like Murray Bros. Caddyshack, the Palm, P. F. Chang's China Bistro and Ri Ra Irish Pub. The Sound of Philadelphia will feature a nightclub, as will Cuba Libre.
There will also be live entertainment at the Ri Ra pub, and a Planet Rose karaoke club will be another tenant at the Quarter. An expanded version of Tropicana's Comedy Stop Cafe and Cabaret and the new Tango's Casino Lounge will be housed there as well. In addition, there will be strolling entertainers in the Quarter's courtyards and open spaces. An Imax theater will also be part of the mix.
Earlier this year, the ultramodern Borgata casino opened in Atlantic City -- the first new casino in 13 years -- with 2,010 hotel rooms, a swanky retail mall with 10 boutique shops, six new restaurants, a nightclub and a luxurious spa. The dramatic design of the Borgata, which is located away from the Boardwalk in the Renaissance Point area, is generally agreed to have been a factor in drawing a healthy business to its casino.
Mr. Gomes, who is the president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, which lobbies with legislators on behalf of all the Atlantic City casinos, said Aztar had begun planning the Quarter four years ago, well before the Borgata came on the scene. "It's not about competition," he said. "It's about economic potential."
Aztar projects that the economic impact of the Quarter will be substantial for the city and state: 600 construction jobs and 2,000 new permanent jobs paying $35 million in annual wages; more than $26 million annually in state and local taxes; $15 million in state casino taxes; $9 million in Atlantic City taxes; and $2 million in annual Casino Reinvestment Development Authority and parking fees to be paid by Aztar.
MR. GOMES also maintains that his company is taking a very different approach in its selection of tenants than the Borgata took. The Borgata aims to "create" their own chefs and nightclubs, whereas, Mr. Gomes said, "we have opted to secure well-known brand names to increase traffic and attract more diverse audiences to Atlantic City."
Mr. Gomes, who insists that the expanded Tropicana will be a standout among Jersey casinos, is himself unusual among Atlantic City's casino operators. He began his career in law enforcement in Las Vegas 35 years ago. Mr. Gomes said the book and film "Casino" are based on an investigation he led for the Nevada Gaming Control Board's Audit and Special Investigations Department.
After that, he became chief of New Jersey's Gaming Enforcement Special Investigations Bureau and contributed to the development of the state's casino control regulations as the industry began to develop 25 years ago in Atlantic City. Mr. Gomes was in charge of the first investigation of a New Jersey casino operator.
"I've never gambled," he said with a chuckle. "My mother still thinks this is a nice business. I've got her convinced this is no different than any other form of entertainment."
Mr. Gomes said he remembers Atlantic City in its early days, when it was a major tourist attraction in the Northeast, and later, after it became "decrepit." 
"I believe that we are now in the beginning stages of bringing Atlantic City back to what it used to be -- the ancient glories," he said.
The Tropicana, among the first casinos built in Atlantic City, opened its North Tower in 1981, expanded with 500 additional hotel rooms in its South Tower in 1988 and another 500 hotel rooms over a parking garage and transportation center in the West Tower in 1996. In 1996, the Tropicana also expanded its theater to seat more than2,000. It also opened the first comedy club in Atlantic City 20 years ago.
The Tropicana is responsible for some gambling innovations, too, Mr. Gomes pointed out. In 1997, it opened the Change Your Life video poker room, where for the first time a slot player could win noncash jackpots like a new house, car or college tuition. Two years ago, it pioneered with exercise slot machines, for those who like to work out as they gamble.

HEADLINE: It's a Girl! (Will the Economy Su ffer?) 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
LOOKING for a distraction, the two economists sauntered out of their offices at the University of California at Berkeley last spring and met near the water cooler. 
 The economists, Gordon B. Dahl and Enrico Moretti, are both experts in a rarefied part of the field known as econometrics. On this day, however, their conversation quickly drifted to a wide-ranging discussion of the reasons for the persistent wage gap between men and women. 
 Could the problem stretch far beyond the workplace, they wondered, and all the way back to childhood and the ways that parents treat boys and girls? Was it possible that even in the United States, even in 2003, parents favor boys in a way that has lifelong implications?
One way to look for such a preference, they realized, would be to see whether parents of girls divorced more often than parents of boys, as has long been the case in male-centric societies like China. So the two economists scurried back to their respective offices and, over the next three days, did what economists do: plugged reams of data into a computer and ran regressions, statistical speak for the search for patterns. 
"We thought, 'There is no way we are going to find something systematic,"' Mr. Moretti said. "The results were shocking."
In every decade since the 1940's, couples with girls indeed divorced more often than those with boys, United States Census Bureau data showed. The effect was not huge -- just a few percentage points -- but it was unmistakable. It happened in every region of the country. It happened among whites more than blacks and among people with only high school diplomas more than those with college degrees.
Over the last 60 years, parents with an only child that was a girl were 6 percent more likely to split up than parents of a single boy. The gap rose to 8 percent for parents of two girls versus those of two boys, 10 percent for families with three children of the same sex and 13 percent for four. Every year, more than 10,000 American divorces appear to stem partly from the number of girls in the family.
Whatever the cause, and there are some prime suspects, the effects are as obvious as they are pernicious. Children from divorced families are twice as likely as other children to drop out of high school, become parents while teenagers or be jobless as young adults, earlier studies show. The new research makes clear that girls are bearing more than their share of these costs.
"I'd rather boys and girls have the same crack at success in life," said Mr. Dahl, an assistant professor at the University of Rochester.
THE study fits in with a fast-growing interest among economists in how families operate, research that is moving beyond the ways that women's family roles affect their finances to include fathers and children as well.
"This is part of well-known economic imperialism," said Shelly Lundberg, a professor of economics at the University of Washington at Seattle, referring to her field's penchant for sticking its nose into just about every human endeavor. "How families operate and how husbands and wives make decisions has important economic implications."
Taken together, this research strongly suggests that the age-old favoring of boys is not confined to the past or to developing countries like China and India. It is subtle and less widespread than it once was in the United States, but it still gives boys an important leg up. 
Parents, and especially fathers, appear to invest more in their families when they include a boy. They put more money into their homes, spending an additional $600 a year on housing, according to a study of families with an only child by Ms. Lundberg and her colleague Elaina Rose, an associate professor of economics.
In addition, fathers increase their workweeks by more than two hours, and their earnings, after the birth of a first, male child. When the first child is a girl, workweeks increase by less than an hour.
The effects go beyond mere dollars and cents. Among unmarried couples, fathers read to baby girls and put them to bed as often as they do for boys. But the fathers feed the boys, change their diapers and play with them more often than they do with baby girls, concluded Ms. Lundberg, Ms. Rose and Sara McLanahan, director of the Center for Research on Child Well-Being at Princeton. 
And among unmarried women who had ultrasound scans, those carrying boys were slightly more likely to marry the father than those with girls, a study of California records from the early 90's by Mr. Dahl and Mr. Moretti showed.
By itself, of course, the higher divorce rate among parents of girls does not prove that society prefers baby boys. Mothers might tolerate a difficult marriage if they have sons, thinking that the presence of a father is crucial to the boys. 
Or mothers and fathers might both have a slight preference for children of their own sex. Some fathers might spend more time with their family when it includes boys, strengthening the marriage. Other fathers, knowing they are likely to lose a custody battle, might avoid a divorce when it would cost them time with their sons.
But a wide array of findings from family research suggests that these factors alone do not explain the gap. 
"The weight of the evidence suggests that parents have a preference for boys," said Mr. Moretti, an assistant professor at the University of California at Los Angeles who, like Mr. Dahl, had been on sabbatical at Berkeley. "The differences are not huge, but they are not trivial."
Researchers also found a Henry VIII-like eagerness for a male heir in many parents. Over the last six decades, 33.7 percent of families whose first four children were girls had a fifth child, while only 31.5 percent of those who start with four boys kept going.
The preference for boys could matter a lot more in the future. Technology already permits parents to choose a baby's sex, and as the cost of the procedure falls, it could create a divisive social issue. 
For about $3,000 on top of the usual fee for in vitro fertilization or artificial insemination, the Genetics & IVF Institute in Fairfax, Va., will sort sperm by weight, separating the X chromosomes, which produce girls, from the smaller Y's.When its customers are indeed able to become pregnant, the institute claims a 75 percent success rate for parents who request boys and 90 percent success for those who want girls. Another method boasts a success rate closer to 95 percent for each sex, but it is more controversial because doctors check for gender after in vitro fertilization and discard the embryos of the unwanted sex.
"There is reliable technology for gender selection," said Dr. Norbert Gleicher, chairman of the Centers for Human Reproduction, which has clinics in Chicago and New York. Whether it becomes more popular "will depend to a large degree on the political climate."
President Bush has appointed a committee, led by Dr. Leon R. Kass, to advise him on biotechnology and issues related to the beginning of human life. In an preliminary report it released on Oct. 16, the committee questioned the wisdom of sex selection. 
THE research by Mr. Dahl and Mr. Moretti, which was first reported in the online magazine Slate by Steven E. Landsburg, another economist at Rochester, seems to offer a new reason to be squeamish about the process. 
If parents, as a group, showed no preference for one gender over another, the new technology would be able to do little more than reallocate boys and girls in society. But if parents favor one sex, then acquire new degrees of control, the delicate balance between boys and girls could easily be upset, researchers say. 
Consider what would happen if many parents with two girls opted for sex selection when having a third child, while those with two boys were more likely to leave the gender of their third child to nature. Over decades, the population would slowly become more male.
"This presents enormous ethical and social problems," Mr. Moretti said.
Nobody seems to believe that the United States will end up like China or India, where the combination of ultrasound scans and abortion has created a vast gap between the number of boys and girls being born. The good news for society, researchers say, appears to be that the preference for boys is waning somewhat in the United States.
In the 1940's, for example, couples with an only child who was a girl were 8 percent more likely to get a divorce than those with a lone boy. In 2000, the gap was just 5 percent.
"Gender is just not what it used to be," said S. Philip Morgan, chairman of the sociology department at Duke University and a fertility expert. Girls now play high school sports about as often as boys, for example, and they enroll in college more often. 
In fact, Mr. Morgan, who wrote about the divorce gap in the late 1980's, said he could no longer notice it among the group he studied. But because Mr. Dahl and Mr. Moretti used a larger sample, the Census, he said he did not doubt their findings. The two economists are now presenting the paper at seminars across the country and plan to submit it to a journal next month. 
As clear as its results seem to be, Mr. Dahl emphasized that they were not necessarily an indictment of all, or even most, parents' attitudes toward girls: "Remember, the numbers aren't huge. So it doesn't mean this affects the whole population. It might just be a small fraction."
Obviously, that fraction would not include Mr. Dahl, who is the father of three girls. 
"I could not imagine it any other way," he said of his family.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
A Tight Job Market Dampens Ivy League Hopes

BYLINE:  By AMY WU

 BODY:
LIKE many other Ivy League students, Rachael M. Roewe had lofty dreams when she entered the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania four years ago. She would study econom ics, then embark on a career analyzing emerging markets. 
 But the closest she has come to Wall Street since she graduated last May with a bachelor's degree is the MeKong Vietnamese Restaurant and Bar in Greenwich Village, where she works as a waitress on weekday nights and as a bartender on weekends. Last month, she spent her days as a freelance makeup artist at the cosmetics counters of Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue. 
 "I'm just doing this for fun," and to help pay the expenses of living in Manhattan, said Ms. Roewe, 22, who grew up in Burlington, Iowa. She said she had sent out countless resumes and job applications and had even interviewed at a few investment banks, but that she had been told she was either underqualified or overqualified for the few jobs available. 
"I went to a really good school and I did all the right things, so what else can you do?" said Ms. Roewe, who says she was the only person in her high school class to attend an Ivy League college. She said she graduated from Wharton with a 3.1 grade-point average. "You realize that just because you went to the best undergraduate business school doesn't guarantee that you will have a job," she said. 
Almost half a year after finishing their studies, many graduates of Ivy League and other elite colleges have come to that same realization and, like Ms. Roewe, many are settling for jobs that have little to do with their career goals. Some are riding out the tight job market in graduate school.
In a survey last winter of 162 colleges, the National Association of Colleges and Employers found that, on average, 51.6 percent of students who finished school last year had a job at graduation, compared with a 62.6 percent rate for graduates the previous year. Most students who had not found a full-time job were willing to pursue other alternatives, with part-time work, unpaid internships and volunteer work the most common options cited. 
The job outlook is likely to remain difficult for the next batch of college graduates, from elite universities or otherwise, but there is a glimmer of hope: some colleges are reporting an increase in on-campus recruiting so far this fall.
The economy is also showing signs of improving, although the nation's overall unemployment rate is 6.1 percent, up from 4.1 percent three years ago. Since February 2001, some 2.84 million jobs have been lost, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And during August, 1.9 million Americans had been looking for work for 27 weeks or more.
ALTHOUGH few Ivy League universities have released employment numbers for the class of 2003, data from the previous two years confirm the continuing challenge in finding jobs. At the Harvard Business School, 87.6 percent of students accepted job offers at graduation in 2000; that number fell to 77.6 percent in 2003, according to David Lampe, a spokesman.
Peggy L. Curchack, an associate director of career services at the University of Pennsylvania, said that the job scene this year was "the most difficult market that I've had students try to enter." 
But Ms. Curchack, who has worked at the school's career services department since 1982, said that some investment banks that did not recruit last year had come back for this fall's recruiting, which began last month and continues through November. "What we're beginning to see is a little bit of an increase, and it's looking a little less dismal than we feared," she said. 
Columbia University has had a 10 percent increase in on-campus recruiting this fall, according to Laura Hoffman, director of employer and alumni relations at the university's career center. 
"We're not back anywhere near 2000 levels," she said. But, she added, "I'm cautiously optimistic that things are improving." 
Bain & Company, the management consulting firm, which recruits heavily at Ivy League universities, plans to increase the number of people it recruits on college campuses by 30 percent this year, said Mark E. Jones, director of the company's office in Dallas. 
"We're definitely more optimistic than six to nine months ago," he said. 
In the boom years of the late 1990's, Ivy League students were often courted by corporate recruiters long before graduation. Some students, particularly those in high-demand fields like technology and finance, were flooded with lucrative job offers. Some received perks like club memberships. Although fewer such offers are being made, most Ivy League colleges say their students are still better off than others. 
"Companies are still very interested in students of this kind of caliber," said Philip Jones, the career services director and an assistant dean for undergraduates at Yale. "It's not to sound blase about it because things could be better, and it certainly has been a challenge compared to a few years ago."
Steve Pollock, the president of WetFeet Inc., a company in San Francisco that offers recruiting services, said major companies are more likely to continue recruiting at elite universities because of the high caliber of job candidates and the businesses' long history at the schools. "The companies usually have a core set of schools they focus on, and many are top-ranked academically," he said. 
Many universities have extensive and loyal alumni networks, and they have been bolstering their career services departments by adding staff members and holding workshops. Some want students to come in for career counseling as early as their freshman year.
Last year, Brown University began turning to parents and professors for job leads. It even approached potential employers at professional conferences on campus. "We're being much more proactive to establish relationships; we use every opportunity to reach out as much as possible," said Kimberly G. DelGizzo, Brown's director of career services. 
Still, many recent Ivy League graduates remain in a holding pattern. Ms. Roewe said that her Wharton roommate, who also graduated last spring, had a $7-an-hour internship at Universal Studios, and that another former classmate was working at a Gap store.
Margie Tsaousis, 22, who received a political science degree from Vassar College last spring, worked as an unpaid intern at City Hall in San Francisco before being hired as a legal assistant in that city. She is paid $10 an hour and receives no benefits.
As graduates look for high-paying jobs, many may be wondering if the high price of their education was worth it. Ms. Roewe noted that it cost her parents around $100,000 in tuition alone to send her to Wharton for four years. Last week, the College Board reported that it now costs an average of $26,854 a year to attend a four-year private school, including tuition, fees, room and board, up 5.7 percent from last year.
Carlos Sanchez, 22, of Los Angeles said he thought that the bachelor's degree in economics he received from Princeton in May would land him a six-figure job at an investment bank. The reality check came when he met with a recruiter at a temporary agency. 
"She asked, 'What is your ideal job?' and I said, 'I'd like to get $100,000 a year.' She said: 'What, are you crazy? It's more like $30,000, and you're going to have to settle with that,"' said Mr. Sanchez, who has moved back in with his parents in Rowland Heights, Calif..
Most recently, after a six-month search, he received an offer to be a manager at an industrial supplies company in Los Angeles. He said he would most likely accept the position, though he was still hoping for a job at an investment bank.
"I'll probably stay at the job and play it by ear," he said.
SOME graduates blame themselves for their predicaments. Sunny Cheung, 22, who graduated this year from the University of California at Berkeley with a degree in computer science, said: "When I got into Berkeley, people told me you'd get a good job for sure, so I didn't think about jobs until my third year in school. By then I started to worry because I had no internship experience."
Mr. Cheung said that by the time he graduated, he had applied to about 50 companies but was only offered four interviews. He said he took the first offer he received: a $7-an-hour internship at an Internet company in San Francisco, with no benefits apart from the free snacks. He said the Berkeley name is somewhat of an added burden.
"My parents were happy about me finally finding a job, but they think the wage is too low." he said. "They weren't happy about a Berkeley grad getting such a low wage."
Ms. Roewe, meanwhile, says she is hopeful about eventually finding a job on Wall Street. 
"Our generation thinks that you shouldn't have to do things like wait tables," she said. "My dad worked on a farm and worked an egg-processing job while he was in college, so he tells me I don't want to hear about waitressing. I feel like it isn't the worst thing I could do. Maybe I'd even learn something about hard work."

HEADLINE: Conde Nast Redesigns Its Future 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CARR

 BODY:
THE lights of Midtown Manhattan still twinkle in the early-morning darkness as a man walks toward 4 Times Square, a huge office tower. He is short and moves with a shuffle, a gait that suggests he may be a bit old for punching a clock at 5 a.m. With his khakis, loafers and a green sweatshirt that seems too big on him, he could be one of the kitchen staff showing up to prep food at the vaunted Conde Nast cafeteria, four floors up. 
 But look closer at the sweatshirt and the outline of the New Yorker logo emerges. Peer closer at the man and S.I. Newhouse Jr. is revealed, one of the world's richest men and the owner, along with the rest of his family, of a far-flung and immensely profitable media empire. 
 As chairman of Conde Nast Publications, he presides over magazines like Vogue, Vanity Fair and, yes, The New Yorker -- shiny totems built to assemble wealthy readers and the advertisers who covet them. 
During the day that follows, he might consult his brother, Donald, about acquisitions, have lunch with one of his prized editors and examine printing bills. 
At 75, Mr. Newhouse, known to all as "Si," is a Medici of a glossy fief who finds no detail too small to merit his attention. He and Donald Newhouse, 74, oversee Advance Publications, a family-owned business built on the triad of magazines, newspapers and cable that has $4.2 billion in revenue and more than 22,000 employees. Si Newhouse is this parent company's chairman and Donald its president. 
The company was founded by S.I. Newhouse Sr., but it became a truly diversified enterprise under the sons, with Si running the magazines and Donald in charge of the newspapers. For years, the two brothers ran the business the way their father did, working off the back of the envelope and managing by the seat of their pants.
That approach is changing rapidly. For all the palace intrigue over who will succeed Si Newhouse, the revolution that many thought would occur in the next generation has already taken place -- and has created a markedly different company. 
In the past, Conde Nast's ability to increase revenue was matched only by its ability to spend wildly on content. Little more than a decade ago, the magazine company managed to lose $20 million in a year, but this year it will make more than $120 million, according to industry executives familiar with the numbers. 
American business history is rife with examples of visionary builders who successfully managed to pass on both their legacy and assets to the next generation. But by the third generation, most of it having known only wealth, the dispersal of power often leads to infighting and a sell-off. From the Chandlers of Los Angeles to the Cowles of Minneapolis, many of the biggest owners in media have eventually succumbed. 
THE Newhouses now spend every day making sure that the same thing does not happen to the company their father built out of a single dilapidated newspaper. Si Newhouse is trying to ensure that his values are carried into the future by the people he has chosen as his heirs apparent. 
The only problem with the succession plan, company executives say, is that there probably won't be a succession anytime soon; Mr. Newhouse is hardly frail. Having modernized the business and rendered it more manageable for the next generation, he still expects to be leading the organization for many years. That, inevitably, has caused discomfort, even in the most well behaved of family enterprises.
The family operators of the next generation not only have apprenticed but also have had significant roles. Officially, Steven Newhouse, 46, the son of Donald, heads the Internet operations of both the magazines and the newspapers, retains the title of editor in chief of The Jersey Journal and oversees the Golf Digest division. But as a practical matter, people at the company say, he is deeply involved in every significant initiative at Conde Nast. (Steven Newhouse declined to be interviewed for this article, as did Si and Donald.) 
Working from London, Jonathan Newhouse, 51, the younger cousin of Donald and Si, has taken the brands of Conde Nast and helped build an international division that has half the revenue of its counterpart in the United States. The British version of Glamour magazine in particular has achieved startling success, quickly becoming Britain's leading women's magazine. Both younger Newhouses defer to Si, but executives at the company say that each is ready to run Conde Nast. How those roles will be brokered is up to a very secretive family. 
"There is no need to grandstand," a company executive said. "Everyone knows who has the power." 
Led by a man of few and sometimes mumbled words, the magazine company is not big on rhetoric. Conde Nast and its parent company are highly compartmentalized, and normally loquacious media executives get a serious case of lockjaw when the subject of the family business comes up. That remains true even though the company has a very good story to tell. 
Through shrewd if expensive acquisitions and very well-timed sales, the Newhouses have managed to position their family company for the long haul in an era of behemoths. The profits from cable and the newspapers have been used to build Advance into the second-largest magazine company in the country. 
Historically, the Newhouse newspapers were unambitious but high-earning, and the magazine division was the opposite -- prestigious but with very low returns. Now the newspapers, like The Star-Ledger of Newark and The Times-Picayune of New Orleans, are winning Pulitzers. The New Yorker, a longtime problem child that had lost a total of $200 million since 1985, is finally making money. 
The Newhouses have never been big on synergy -- their various divisions have been uncooperative by design -- but the company reached a size and complexity in which the cost and revenue benefits of acting in concert could no longer be ignored. The severe advertising recession of the past two years has pushed Conde Nast, a paragon of profligacy known for its conga line of idling Town Cars surrounding the building, into focusing on costs. 
As recently as 10 years ago, editors and publishers at Conde Nast had no budgets. Now they find themselves in quarterly budget meetings where they are asked again and again to account for their decisions. The building still has editorial divas with million-dollar contracts swanning about, but on the business side it is no longer enough to pile up ad pages regardless of the price they fetched. 
Si Newhouse once famously compared Conde Nast to MGM in the 1930's, when various stars were kept under contract and allowed to pursue their art. 
James Truman, editorial director of Conde Nast, said: "We are still very much like a movie studio. Except that it's now a modern movie company. It is run like a business."
IN the past, Conde Nast's magazine sales representatives talked trash about corporate siblings in order to land a sale. Now they are part of an integrated corporate media sales effort -- engineered by Steven T. Florio, the president and chief executive of Conde Nast-- that accounts for much of the company's revenue. 
Although the company says it does not negotiate rates, advertisers say it does precisely that with its large corporate package deals. Many of those contracts result in huge special sections that have grown to the point where they threaten to overwhelm the magazines they inhabit and the consumers who try to read them.
Conde Nast charges consumers very little for lavishly produced magazines like Allure;subscribers pay around $1 an issue. In doing so, the company forgoes significant circulation revenue in favor of building an audience for advertisers. 
After generating profit margins of 2 percent or worse in the mid-90's, Conde Nast has now crept into the low teens, according to senior executives. That is still below the industry average, but with revenue of about $1.2 billion, it means that the company is producing at least $120 million a year in earnings. 
The decision, in 1998, to sell Random House to Bertelsmann -- for $1 billion, according to a senior executive at the company -- helped fuel a buying spree. In the last four years, Advance has spent more than $1.1 billion on acquisitions. It bought Fairchild Publications from Disney for $650 million in 1999, and later added Golf Digest from The New York Times Company at a cost of $435 million. Last year, the company bought Modern Bride magazine from Primedia for $52 million, consolidating its position in a niche where it already owned Bride's magazine. 
With the addition of the new divisions, the need for a shared back office for things like human resources, computer systems and purchasing became manifest. So the company not only brought in Michael Wolf, a media consultant from McKinsey & Company, in 2001, but actually put his recommendations into effect. 
In addition, the cowboy culture on the sales side of the organization has been replaced by a much more buttoned-down professionalism. Ron Galotti, a legendary publisher who returned to Conde Nast after the failure of Talk magazine, soon found himself out of a job, in part because his combative style of selling no longer fit with a company that had changed significantly in the years he was gone. 
After a long drought in new titles, the company introduced Lucky, a shopping magazine for women, in 2000. It is connecting with both readers and advertisers and is headed into the black after just three years, according to company executives. And Teen Vogue, a younger, more accessible version of Vogue that began publishing this year, has also elbowed out a place in a very crowded teenage market. Over all, advertising pages are up 7.5 percent at Conde Nast this year.
Fairchild Publications, the division of Advance that produces trade publications like Women's Wear Daily and consumer magazines like W, has established a lower-cost model of publishing under Mary Berner, its president and chief executive. Details, an upmarket men's magazine which floundered under Conde Nast's cost structure, is now flourishing at Fairchild. 
The upshot is that magazine publishing, long considered an expensive hobby at the company, is helping the bottom line.
"We are now making a contribution to the parent company, one that is becoming more and more meaningful," said Charles H. Townsend, chief operating officer of the Advance Magazine Group, the operating company for all the magazine divisions. "We have adopted a certain amount of discipline and have had some success. The risk is that we step over the line and curtail creativity."
There is also the risk that the job goes unfinished. Alexander Liberman, the legendary creative muse of Conde Nast, once suggested that waste was an intrinsic part of the creative process, and some of that ethos remains embedded in the culture. Conde Nast headquarters is still a rarefied environment driven by the fashion of the moment, the kind of place where a poor choice of shoes can turn an elevator ride into an exercise in social Darwinism. Even with an increased emphasis on the bottom line, the publishing company is not going to turn into Wal-Mart anytime soon.
"There is a culture of entitlement here like few businesses I have ever seen," one senior executive at Conde Nast said. "We have made strides, but there is much still to be done."
THE work on both the revenue and the cost side is exactly the kind of thing that companies do to clean themselves up when they are about to be sold or go public. Neither outcome is a possibility with the Newhouses. By remaining private, the company has been able to invest for the long haul and not worry about quarterly performance. 
With Time Warner preoccupied with repairing the damage done by the AOL merger, Advance, which seemed somewhat imperiled five years ago precisely because it was private, can now compete with virtually anyone in the industry. 
The Fairchild acquisition allowed Advance to step up its dominance in fashion magazines. And by acquiring Golf Digest, the company gained more male readers while adding a new population of the wealthy demographic that is its core expertise. 
The company has the money -- and the inclination -- for further shopping. Conde Nast executives said Si Newhouse sent back the sale proposal for New York magazine, which recently came on the market, without looking at it, in part because he believes that the likely price will not be supported by the performance of the magazine. But the appetite for growth remains.
The possibilities are many but not easy to predict. As Primedia sells off more assets, Conde Nast could acquire its car magazines as a way to diversify its advertising base. Or American Express could decide that its lucrative publishing partnership with Time Inc. would be a better fit with Conde Nast. Or perhaps Hachette Filipacchi Media will let go of some of its American holdings, which include fashion titles and male-oriented magazines like Car and Driver.
It all depends on willing sellers, but the Newhouses move swiftly, sometimes with little regard for price, when they are in the mood to buy.
"If Si and Donald want something, there are not a lot of people to run it by," said one executive at the company. "They can do a deal over dinner if they wish."
EVEN as the third generation becomes ever more ready to take control, Mr. Newhouse squeezes the wheel all the tighter. His management is old school to a fault, although it has been upgraded technologically. His legendary "yellow rain," a hail of notes and questions scrawled on yellow notepad paper, has been digitized as e-mail messages.
"The day that Si figured out how to use e-mail was a bad day for all of us here," one senior executive said.
Mr. Florio has managed to remain chief executive of Conde Nast in part because he and Richard Beckman, chief marketing officer, have put together huge corporate deals that have fueled much of the growth. But part of Mr. Florio's durability comes from his willingness to execute Mr. Newhouse's whims, which can change by the hour, and his ability to motivate and soothe people who might otherwise become worn out by Mr. Newhouse's rougher edges. Mr. Florio is the public face of the company, and he is everything Mr. Newhouse is not: jovial, talkative and prone to bragging.
Mr. Newhouse remains a micromanager who is just as interested in the number of regional ad pages a competitor ran or a layout deep in one of the magazines as he is in major acquisitions, according to several company officials. He is not big on communication, but his opinions are known, they say.
"Si has a real eye for the weakness of something," Mr. Truman, the editorial director, said. "He won't say much, but just by standing there and going from one foot to the other while he looks as something, you know it needs work. His gift is knowing what makes people want to read magazines."
He also has an eye for talent. When he made the decision to replace Grace Mirabella with Anna Wintour at Vogue, his choice was ridiculed in every corner. Under Ms. Wintour, Vogue continues to be one of the most dominant magazines in publishing.
"He has always been incredibly supportive at the personal and professional level," Ms. Wintour said. "Being at Vogue without Si is unthinkable. He is a very important source of advice for me."
If history is any indication, he will be available for quite some time. Mr. Newhouse's father died in 1979 at the age of 83, and he worked nearly every day of his life. People who know the family say that the subject of succession is a nonissue, in part because Si and Donald are in excellent health and in part because it is just not seemly. The Newhouses have never engaged in the kind of public bickering that often tears apart families and their businesses, these people say.
"They have managed to steer clear of the internal fighting that splits up other family businesses," said Roger L. Martin, the dean of the Rotman School of Management at the University of Toronto and a former adviser to privately owned companies. "Donald and Si each have coherent defined roles, they clearly enjoy what they are doing and are using the fact that they are private to accomplish a great deal."
Mr. Newhouse and his brother have managed to set the table for those who will come behind them in much the same way their father did before them. The last part will be the hard part: getting out of the way.
