HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE; 
After the 90's Boom, a Bounty of Blame

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN; William J. Holstein is editor in chief of Chief Executive magazine.

 BODY:
AN intellectual battle is shaping up over what message the Democratic Party should carry into the presidential election. One camp argues that the Democrats should strike a pragmatic pose, cutting deals with Republicans to attack problems like the lack of health insurance for millions of Americans. The other contends that Democrats need to remain true to their populist roots and not make compromises.
 Joseph E. Stiglitz, winner of the 2001 Nobel in economic science, has staked out the second position. His new book, "The Roaring Nineties: A New History of the World's Most Prosperous Decade" (W.W. Norton, $25.95), is a stinging rebuke of the Clinton administration's search for a middle ground. 
 Mr. Stiglitz certainly had a ringside view of what happened during the 1990's. He was a member and then chairman of President Bill Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers from 1993 to 1997 and chief economist of the World Bank from 1997 to 2000. His previous book, "Globalization and Its Discontents," was an attack on the International Monetary Fund for the way it forced countries in economic disarray to cut spending.
The new book is a roundhouse assault on Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, as well as chief executives and corporations, Wall Street, the pharmaceutical industry and just about everyone who helped shape the boom of the 1990's or profited from it. 
Mr. Stiglitz says he left his job as a Princeton professor and came to Washington because he supported President-elect Clinton's more populist inclinations. But President Clinton sought to portray himself as a "New Democrat" who wasn't a tax-and-spender. When the Republicans took control of Congress in the 1994 election, Mr. Clinton moved even further to the center.
Although he never criticizes Mr. Clinton personally, Mr. Stiglitz says the administration as a whole sold out to deregulation, globalization, flawed accounting systems and other forces. That benefited a handful of special interests in the short run, he writes, but it also created worse imbalances between rich and poor. 
Of course, Mr. Stiglitz also criticizes what he calls the "Bush II" presidency. But he argues that the roots of today's economic malaise lie in the Clinton years.
"Americans should face up to the fact that in the very boom were planted some of the seeds of destruction, seeds which would not yield their noxious fruit for several years," he argues.
"What happened in the Roaring Nineties," Mr. Stiglitz writes, "was that a set of longstanding checks and balances -- a balance between Wall Street, Main Street (or High Street, as it is called in the United Kingdom), and labor; between Old Industry and New Technology, government and the market -- was upset, in some essential ways, by the new ascendancy of Finance."
By "Finance," Mr. Stiglitz includes Mr. Greenspan, who, he says, did little to defuse the stock market bubble despite acknowledging that "irrational exuberance" was at work. 
But most of Mr. Stiglitz's sting is reserved for Mr. Rubin, who was at Goldman Sachs before taking over the Treasury and then going to Citigroup. It may have escaped much attention, but there was a bitter fight at the heart of Mr. Clinton's economic decision-making apparatus. Mr. Stiglitz blames Mr. Rubin for pushing the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act, for blocking more spending on social priorities and for letting the I.M.F. impose draconian solutions on debtor nations. "Treasury's views did not coincide with those of Clinton," Mr. Stiglitz writes. "Treasury had its own perspectives, its own ideology, its own agenda, and it was largely, though not completely, able to follow that agenda internationally through its domination of the I.M.F."
MR. STIGLITZ plays upon the old saying that what's good for General Motors is good for America. "The new mantra was what is good for Goldman Sachs, or Wall Street, is good for America and the world," he writes.
A sweeping critique, indeed. The author, though trained in the "dismal science" as an economist, displays nothing short of moral outrage. What, then, would he have us do? His core issue is that the nation needs to strike a better balance between markets and government. 
"The battle of ideas between those who advocate a minimalist role for the state," he writes, "and those who believe that there is a greater need for government if we are to achieve the kind of society we would like is being fought in country after country, in the developing world no less than in the developed, on both sides of the Atlantic and the Pacific."
Mr. Stiglitz argues that market forces have gone too far and that it's time for "a new democratic idealism." He expresses hope that the next cycle in American opinion and politics will emphasize equality, not greed. "Democratic idealism holds that there are legitimate areas for government activity -- from education to the promotion of technology, to social protection for the aged and the disadvantaged," he says.
Even if the author is correct about what went wrong in the 90's, will Americans buy it? Will they sacrifice economic gains at home to bring about "global social justice," as he advocates?
It may be fine to argue that the balance between the market and government has gone askew and needs to be recalibrated, but Mr. Stiglitz seems to become carried away with his passion, and overtly hostile to American business. ("Hidden theft had evidently been part of capitalism for a long time," he writes.)
Not all chief executives, of course, have been involved in financial sleight of hand. To build a more balanced economic future, any government must have at least civil relations with the people who decide whether to invest in research, build factories and hire people.
Agree with him or not, this is a powerful book written by apowerful intellect. And as they try to reclaim the White House, the Democrats will have to decide whether to heed Mr. Stiglitz's call.

HEADLINE: ART; 
Redrawn by Rembrandt

BYLINE:  By DEBORAH WEISGALL; Deborah Weisgall writes about the arts from Boston.

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
"REMBRANDT'S JOURNEY," a subtle exhibition examining the artist as storyteller at the Museum of Fine Arts here through Jan. 18, includes only one image not by Rembrandt. It is an etching by Hercules Segers, a Dutch painter and printmaker who died around 1638, when Rembrandt was 32. Segers made this print, "Tobias and the Angel," sometime in the 1620's. About 30 years later, Rembrandt altered the copper plate to tell a different story, "The Flight Into Egypt." 
 Segers was the most innovative and expressive printmaker of his time. He printed on colored paper and with different colored inks, he printed on cloth, he added color to prints after they had been struck. A pupil of Rembrandt wrote that Segers "printed painting." His works are extremely rare, and most of his surviving images, almost all of them landscapes, are unique variants rather than editions of prints. 
 But Segers could not support himself with his art. The story goes that he was so depressed by his lack of artistic success that he turned to drink and died from a drunken fall before he was 50.
After his death, however, his reputation flourished. Rembrandt was fascinated by Segers and owned eight of his paintings; he must have acquired this plate, too. Segers's etching is a meticulously rendered landscape printed with green ink, a view over hills and forest to a meandering river with a town along its banks. Two tall figures cross the foreground: Tobias, exhausted, drags a big dead fish, while the angel Raphael regards him with tender sympathy.
This story, one of the books of the Apocrypha, concerns the righteous man Tobit, who was blinded by bird droppings. Tobit, wishing to die, sends his son Tobias to collect a debt. Tobias travels with a young man who suggests that Tobias catch a fish in the Tigris River. The fish cures Tobit's blindness, Tobias gets the money and finds a wife and his kind friend reveals himself to be Raphael.
Rembrandt set this story in several prints and drawings, all of them interiors, scenes of family life. He reworked Segers's landscape into an outdoor subject. At first glance, it seems to have nothing to do with the original, but, looking more closely, it's evident that Rembrandt changed the plate with great economy.
He turned Tobias and the angel into tree trunks and branches and disguised Raphael's wings as foliage; on the far right you can still find feathers. With strong, spare strokes, he drew the small group -- Joseph, with Mary and the baby on the donkey -- against the dark copse. He laid washes of shadowy tone over Segers's precise and intricate terrain, but he kept the lizard near the bottom and the tiny shepherd standing on the left. In Segers's etching, solace radiates from the angel. In Rembrandt's version, the forest embraces the family, as if the leaves that were once wings have retained divine power. They shield the family from sight, abetting their escape.
Why did Rembrandt do this? Clifford S. Ackley, the curator of the exhibition, pointed out that Segers's etching is a free variation on a painting by Adam Elsheimer, a German painter who died in 1610, from whose work Rembrandt also took ideas (including a nocturnal painting of the "Flight"). Segers and Rembrandt would have known Elsheimer's paintings from prints, made by yet another artist. "This is a long conversation over time," Mr. Ackley said. "And it is a collaboration between one artist who was living and one who was dead."

GRAPHIC: Photos: At far right, Hercules Segers's etching "Tobias and the Angel" from the 1620's, and above, what Rembrandt turned it into about 30 years later: "The Flight Into Egypt." (Photographs courtesy Museum of Fine Arts, Boston)

HEADLINE: High Anxiety 

BYLINE:  By KATE STONE LOMBARDI and MERRI ROSENBERG

 BODY:
IT'S the high season for one of the toughest games in town: the college admissions process.
 The pressure is mounting. Guidance counselors, parents and students alike are reaching for the toughest headache remedies. One-upsmanship and backbiting have been observed among particularly competitive parents. Some friendships are fraying, both parent friendships and student ones, by many accounts. And those who have "graduated" from the process tell stories of how awful it was to feel suddenly that every move of senior year relates to the question of what college or university decal will go on the back of the family car. 
 The topic is never far away. As Abigail Dalton, a senior at Ardsley High School, said: "A day has not yet gone by since the first day of school when I have not been asked where I'm applying early. Everybody wants to know their competition." 
 The pressure is, of course, not limited to Westchester and it is by no means universal. In many families, the decision is clear and the path to freshman year is smooth. Yet in a county where high-stakes public and private schools and high-achieving families are common, the agita level is high as early-decision deadlines approach around early November. Also, if the pressure seems higher this year in an already high-pressure game, that may be because it actually is. There are more seniors than there once were because of the baby boomlet. Those seniors fill out more applications, and more are applying early decision, because early applicants tend to have a better chance of getting the school of their choice. The college admissions game is tough and getting tougher. Will it be the Ivies? A state school? A safety school? And when will it be over? When?
 For Marleen Kassel Kerson, an Ardsley parent whose daughter graduated from Washington University in St. Louis last spring and whose son is a freshman at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, senior year was a difficult experience.
 "It was a year-and-a-half-long phenomenon," she said. "People staked out the Ivies, and the other kids slink away, and parents do, too. The kids who are headed for the Ivies take three to five A.P. classes a year, and are in honors courses. When kids aren't applying to the Ivies, then their parents walk to the back of the barbecue."
 Pure demographics is one cause of increased college competition. In 1990, there were about 2.6 million students nationally who graduated from high school; by 2009, demographers predict there will be 3.2 million, according to the National Center for Education Statistics. (Here in Westchester, about 10,000 high school seniors are seeking admission for the class of 2008, according to the Westchester Putnam College Conference Committee, an organization of local guidance counselors that runs the various countywide college fairs.)
 In 1998, there were 50,000 early applications; in 2002, there were 70,000 applications for a slot during the fall go-round, according to the College Board. Colleges are able to be more selective. At Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, for example, during the last five years there has been a 35 percent increase in applications, and now the college accepts 40 percent of applicants, rather than 50 percent. 
 For parents who may have been accustomed to smoothing their children's way from infancy onward, the reality check can be disturbing. "The colleges are not necessarily impressed by parents' wealth," said Scott Steinberg, a counselor at Briarcliff High School for the last 20 years. "Coming out of Westchester is not necessarily beneficial at the top tier schools. For the Ivy League schools, there are so many applicants from Westchester, they're just knocking each other out. 
 "We're a small school, 116 seniors, and we're encouraging all students and parents to keep the process confidential. Overall, these are good kids, who've known each other their whole lives, and good parents. But there's some jealousy, envy and hostility. A lot of friendships are broken over this."
 Parents who have been through the process before are sometimes stunned by just how much things have changed.
 "When my older daughter applied to Penn early, 11 years ago, the dean practically said, 'Go buy the sweatshirt,"' said one Scarsdale mother. "No one would say that now."
 Dr. Ellen Klausner, a psychologist with offices in White Plains and Manhattan, said that college admissions is a continuation of the competitive game that began when parents bragged that their baby was already sleeping through the night, walking at 9 months or toilet trained at a year old. 
 Parents become intensely invested in the college admissions process, she said, because they view it as a reflection of their success as parents. Beyond that, many status-conscious parents often view college as one more statement of prestige, she said. 
 "We live in a very competitive environment and a college is not unlike a Prada or a Mercedes," she said. "You have a label that you can attach to where your child goes. People look for status symbols everywhere."
 Nor are teenagers themselves immune to the game. Lizzy Schulzinger, who graduated several years ago from Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, recalls the spring of her senior year, when college acceptances began to roll in.
 "Once they get into a school, the next morning they have the decal up on their car in the Greeley parking lot, so you know so-and-so got into Harvard," she said. "Someone got the super-size Yale one that takes up half the window. It was disgusting."
 How bad can the competitiveness get? So bad that Penny Oberg, former head of the guidance department at Horace Greeley, felt that she had to share an anecdote about bad behavior in a newsletter sent to students and parents in 2002. Ms. Oberg described a mother whose daughter was accepted to a college, and who then called the admissions department to complain about another student who was wait listed.
 "The parent (who remained anonymous) was angry and claimed that wait listing the other student, who the parent believed was not as qualified, diminished the acceptance," Ms. Oberg wrote. She went on to ask parents to please consider what kind of image such conduct gave their community.
 To be sure, not all communities and not all schools see conduct worthy of reproach. Yonkers, despite its school system's troubled history, has successful students who go to the nation's most prestigious colleges. Administrators there say the atmosphere is different as far as Ivy League status symbols.
 "Our group of top kids is just as obsessed, and focused on their long-range plans, as any others," said Jerilynne Fierstein, director of public relations for the Yonkers public schools and the director of the district's gifted and the arts programs. "Our honors kids do apply, and get into the Harvards, Yales, Stanfords. But I would say it's not so much of an issue for the community."
 In places where the endless discussion of Ivy League applications and SAT scores is common, parents who had been friends may begin to avoid one another in the grocery store. 
 As the post cards arrive inviting students who have scored well on their PSAT's to special information sessions, the information filters through high school hallways, or is left on family answering machines. "You're not going to the Yale session at the school on Tuesday? Oh. Pity, I thought Robert would have been invited."
 Mundane tasks like the college tour are part of the equation. Some families mention heading off for the weekend to Hanover or Cambridge (translation: Dartmouth, Harvard or M.I.T.) as a subtle form of name-dropping. 
 Deborah Kerson, an Ardsley High School graduate of the class of 1999 who graduated in the spring from Washington University, remembered that there was no escaping the social pressures.
"When I applied to Washington University early, nobody had heard of it, " she said. "People were weird, like I was going to this random school. From the high school perspective, there was the idea that if you're not going to a good college, your life is basically over. And I do remember typing kids in my class by the schools they applied to."
 Strong feelings aren't limited to those who seek acceptance at selective colleges. Parents of student athletes check the sports statistics, anxious about competition that may deprive their own child of a sports scholarship to a desired school. Other parents, whose children have talents in music, drama or the arts, are just as concerned about who gets first chair in the orchestra, or the lead in the fall play or who wins the essay contest.
 One Westchester educator, who reacted to the friction by agreeing to speak only on the condition that he not be identified, has a daughter who earned a full academic scholarship to a solid college, partly based on her talents as an athlete. "There was resentment that she got the money, and a few other scholarships available locally that she wasn't given," he said. "There's competition for ever more limited dollars."
 With everyone looking for that special edge, the sense of others' advantages raises the pressure -- for example, if Mom went to Harvard or, even better, if Grandpa gave a building to Yale. 
 "All the issues involved with legacy, athletes and affirmative action just exacerbate all the emotional feelings," said Carol Gill, a private college counselor in Dobbs Ferry. (Of course, even the decision to hire a private counselor like Ms. Gill is something some families can't do or won't do.) Ms. Schulzinger talked about a girl in her high school class who applied as an American Indian.
 "She was like one-twentieth Native American, and her sister even got a Native American scholarship to Columbia," she said. "She told me this herself in physics class." 
 The early decision equation has also changed the mix. Increasingly, for the most high-profile colleges, statistics show that an early application, in the fall, with the student committing to go to the college or university if accepted, gives a student a distinct advantage over a regular application, which is usually sent between Dec. 1 and Feb. 1. As a result, many students feel they have no choice but to apply during the fall early decision window.
 "This increases their opportunity," said Marjorie Jacobs, director of counseling at Scarsdale High School. "Over 50 percent of our class applies early, and has since the 1990's. Now, perhaps 65 to 70 percent of our students are out early and looking early. They understood it's to their advantage."
 EARLY decision is complicated on another front, though. Early decision applicants make an early commitment, and they must take what they are offered in financial aid, rather than waiting until spring and comparing financial aid packages, assuming they are accepted at several schools. Income issues leap to the foreground. 
 "Who's applying early?" said Ms. Jacobs of Scarsdale. "Kids from communities that are knowledgeable, where they're likely to be paying full tuition. That's what's driving the early process." Matt Sergi, a 1999 graduate of Ardsley High School and a 2003 graduate of New York University, found his experience as the child of divorced parents gave him an unusual perspective. 
 "I myself was both privileged and unprivileged," he said. "In high school, I remember people talking about SUNY Binghamton as the school you went to 'if you can get into an Ivy but can't afford it.' There were whispers about one of the few minority students in the class, whispers like 'I wish I were black to get special financial aid.' I also remember how clear the economic strata lines were in high school, how they lined up with the academic strata -- there were the honors kids, the Regents kids and the below-Regents kids. It was such a caste system."
 As if there isn't enough stress between parents and teenagers, the application process brings even more stress into the relationship. It is by no means unusual to hear of children who refuse to discuss the issue with their parents, or parents and children who don't agree on which school or schools are the best. That didn't happen for Mr. Sergi, but in his family there was an extra layer of anguish.
 "There was stress between me and my mom because of finances when I was applying to college, with all the forms to fill out with financial aid requests," he said. "For me, it was so heart-wrenching -- is Mom paying? Is Dad paying? I was terribly uncomfortable. It brought back all the stress of growing up as a child of divorce." 
 As unpleasant as the process has become, say those who have done it, it seems there's no escaping it. Ms. Gill, the college counselor, said she gets most phone calls from parents on Monday, "after the cocktail party or soccer game over the weekend."
 "What happens is that very often parents feed on each other, and I get questions that range from the sublime to the ridiculous about college admissions," she said.
 Teenagers, too, say the topic is ubiquitous, on the soccer field, at Thanksgiving dinner, in school hallways. 
 "That's all anyone asked all the time," said Ms. Schulzinger. "That's who you were -- you were applying to schools. It's almost like you have no other aspect of your personality. Where are you looking? Did you stay over? Did you interview? How did that go? Do you think you'll get in? "
 That discussion often begins with the question, "So what colleges is Caitlin looking at?" 
 Bob Sweeney, a guidance counselor at Mamaroneck High School, said: "It does get loaded. When that question is asked, there's a certain intimidation, so that the parent thinks, "I'm going to tell them the more prestigious schools, so that I look good."' 
 Not surprisingly many families also try to keep their college plans to themselves.
 "Students are reluctant to tell others about where they're applying," said Ms. Jacobs of Scarsdale High School. "I have seen youngsters be concerned about a friend applying to the same school. There are issues of ownership. They're sensitive to their peers, and don't want to offend them. Kids get very conflicted, because they care about each other."
 Students are well aware of the high stakes involved. 
 "Everyone watches out where other people are going," said Sipra Rathi, a senior at Edgemont High School. "With the Ivy League, if more than two students are applying, people get nervous. They think it lowers the chances of getting into places like Harvard, Princeton or Yale. People feel they're competing directly against each other. If you're hanging out with the top of the class, it gets competitive. People kind of try not to ask, which creates some tension, as they're trying to figure out who's going where."
 Linda Pennell, who had two daughters graduate from Horace Greeley, remembers the intrusiveness of neighbors, acquaintances and strangers.
 "People who wouldn't even begin to ask you intimate personal questions have decided that this is fair game," Ms. Pennell said. "It's as if the whole college process is fair game for opening up your lives to public scrutiny, and everyone has an opinion on whether or not you're applying to the right schools."
 Of course, when the acceptances and rejections begin to arrive, all privacy bets are off. News travels fast, "I heard he didn't really have a safety." "Oh, sure she got in -- she's a legacy, you know." 
 A few months later, the teenagers pack for college and the next class begins its autumn ordeal. One who remembers it well is Ms. Schulzinger, who is now on the other side of the process, working as a student interviewer at Kenyon College. 
 "I had a kid recently who was taking five AP's, was head of the student council and he was so stressed out," she said. "You could see it in his face -- 'I'm really smart and I'm not going to get in anywhere.' It's awful. It's like he thought he was going to ruin the rest of his life if he didn't get in. I really wish I could tell them, 'You're going to be O.K., I promise you."'

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
Take Heed! Winter Is Coming, Ready or Not

BYLINE:  By NEIL GENZLINGER

 BODY:
THE leaves are changing color and the ugly sweaters are coming out of storage, which can only mean that it's time for the Jersey Column's annual Guide to Getting Your Home and Yard Ready for Winter. 
 By "annual" we do not mean to imply that we write one of these guides annually; in truth, this will be our first. Yet plunking the word annual in front of something gives it an air of authority (the annual State of the State Address, the annual U.S. News and World Report Randomly Generated Ranking of Colleges and Universities), and since we actually know little about getting homes and yards ready for winter, we need all the authority we can get. 
 It goes without saying that proper preparation for winter is vital, because otherwise hardware stores, nurseries and fertilizer manufacturers would have practically nothing to sell at this time of year, dealing another blow to New Jersey's already shaky economy. Many amazing products are available for the home and yard in the fall, like magic fertilizer that, if applied now, will somehow make your lawn green and weed-free seven months in the future. Customers buying such fertilizer will find the same stores eager to sell them bridges in Brooklyn. 
 Purchase as many of these products as your car will hold, making sure the neighbors are watching when you unload them so they will be impressed with your industriousness. Here are some other winterizing tips:
 The Vegetable Garden: Remove all dead tomato plants from the garden bed. Do not stop to calculate how much you spent buying and fertilizing these plants for the sake of the six or eight tomatoes they produced. Note that there are no dead plants to remove at the spots where you planted cucumbers, broccoli and green peppers, because those things never did actually grow, did they? On a piece of paper write, "Do Not Plant This Stuff Again in 2004." Stick the paper in a Ziploc bag and place it in the garden.
 The Flower Garden: Churn up the soil to the depth of four inches, mixing in humus, tofu and shredded business records as desired. Keep in mind that insects and small wild animals may be hidden in garden debris, like the 10-foot boa constrictor The Trentonian said was found a few days ago off Warren Street. If you find a boa constrictor in your garden, do not try to apprehend it. Instead, slowly walk backward into your home, pick up the phone, call a real estate agent and put your house on the market. Do not mention the boa constrictor in your house-for-sale advertisements.
 The Bird Feeder: Replace the summer seed mixture in your bird feeder with a fall/winter mix, after consulting with your cat as to which birds it would most like to harass. Bird-harassing cats displease the New Jersey Audubon Society, which will give you an impassioned argument as to why cats should be kept indoors 24/7, but feel free to ignore this perfectly sound advice because, hey, they're just birds, right? Explain to your cat, however, that some birds are better left unharassed, like the emu that has popped up in Hamilton of late. Savor the mental image of your cat's reaction were it to bound out to the bird feeder and find a gigantic emu there.
 Shrubs and Trees: With shears and/or a chainsaw, trim all shrubs and trees as necessary. Try not to leave any stumps in the shape of religious figures unless you have adequate parking for pilgrims and curiosity seekers. To find out exactly how much parking you might need, call city hall in Passaic, where a tree stump that may resemble the Virgin Mary has been generating publicity in recent days. As long as you have city hall on the line, also ask about the dos and don'ts of animal sacrifice, another recent news item there. Suggest that someone in city hall consider writing a book titled, "Things They Never Taught Us in Government School."
 Home Maintenance: Inspect the exterior of your home and note any painting, window replacement, reroofing, caulking, etc. that needs doing. Hire someone to do it. To learn how to pay for all this work, call the governor's office and ask for the details of Public Question No. 1 on the Nov. 4 ballot, which claims that it will somehow allow us to buy another $150 million worth of open space without costing us a cent. Suggest to whoever answers the phone that we use this same budgetary voodoo to erase the gazillion-dollar deficit the state now faces. Then go spread your magic fertilizer; it could snow any day now.

HEADLINE: The View's Great, But the Course Is a Real Dump 

BYLINE:  By JOE CONCHA

DATELINE: BAYONNE 

 BODY:
WHEN the city of Bayonne is mentioned, any number of words come to mind. Probably making most people's top 10 would be "pizza," "tanker," and "landfill." Near the bottom of the list would be the word "golf."
 This thought process is understandable considering that Bayonne, situated in Hudson County, is the only one of the state's 21 counties not to be home to a golf course of any kind. The reason the trickle-down effect of Tiger-mania had not hit the state's most densely populated region earlier is because golf -- with its demands for large swaths of land, alluring scenery and a measure of privacy -- is the last sport that could be properly accommodated in such a cramped area. 
 But come 2005, golfers will be teeing off at a gilt-edged Scottish-style links course built atop of one of the few places in Bayonne that is not populated: a former waste disposal site. The project is being headed up by Empire Golf USA, which operates nine courses throughout the country, including three top-ranked courses in New Jersey. 
 The attraction of building a golf course in Bayonne -- a blue-collar port city that at one time was a leading oil refiner and shipping terminus -- is strictly based on its proximity to Manhattan.
 What's more, the novelty of providing Manhattan's power players with a complete golfing experience a John Daly tee shot from the city is spreading. In addition to the Bayonne Golf Club, a course at Port Liberte in Jersey City -- a paradise for those who work primarily in the city's financial district on the banks of the Hudson -- is being designed by Tom Kite, a United States Open champion, and that is also expected to open in 2005.
 In northern Europe, links courses generally sit on seaside soil unsuitable for farming. Bayonne's longtime garbage dump on this active shipping strait actually fits that description. And in keeping with the design of links courses overseas, all 18 holes at the The Bayonne Golf Club will play into the teeth of Upper New York Bay. The par 70, 6,900-yard course will not only include rolling fairways and stiff breezes off the water, but will feature 100-foot dunes, the highest on the East Coast. 
 "The course will be fair, but it will be very challenging," explained Eric Bergstol, president of Empire Golf and designer of the Bayonne Golf Club.
 Mr. Bergstol estimated that the cost to prepare the 126-acre site, truck the dredge material and build the course and clubhouse would come to more than $100 million, making it the most expensive course ever built in the state.
Since the course sits on a former landfill, it will have no trees, making the surrounding scenery -- in this case the Verrazano Bridge and Statue of Liberty -- visible from every hole. Even on cloudy days the Manhattan skyline sits as a backdrop as old barges and huge oil tankers slip in and out of the adjacent peninsula at the old Military Ocean Terminal, also known as Bayonne Harbor. 
 To take advantage of the course's proximity to New York, particularly Wall Street, Empire plans to offer ferry and private yacht service so that its well-heeled members will be able to avoid tunnel traffic or (gasp) the PATH train. After all, the course is only 10 minutes away by water from downtown Manhattan 
 "Any spectacular golf course would be embraced, regardless of geography," said Michael Esposito, a New Jersey Public Golf Organization member -- and a five handicap. "A 10-minute ferry ride is much more convenient than traveling to Long Island or golf courses throughout North Jersey."
 Still, not everyone agrees with the club's primary selling point -- urban convenience. 
 "I don't think the big guns in the finance industry would embrace such a course," said Gil Pagovich, a sports marketing agent in New York. "No one will want to have their golfing guests carrying their clubs on and off a ferry." 
 Cherokee Investment Partners -- a company based in England that specializes in buying landfills in America and Britain and morphing them into profit-turning golf courses -- is financing the endeavor. Like all private golf clubs, Cherokee will be looking for a return on its investment through initiation and membership fees. To join the club, a prospective member will first have to receive an invitation. 
 Don't bother rushing to the mail box. It is not likely that the invitation will be mass mailed and addressed to "occupant," considering the initiation fee has been set at $100,000 for those who join before the club opens, and $250,000 thereafter. 
 Most Bayonne residents -- who were once led to believe this would be a public course -- can now forget about it. According to the mayor, Joseph P. Doria, the original plan called for a public as well as a private course, but the difficulty in gaining environmental approval for both limited the project to one course. A recent Census report indicated that of the city's 61,274 residents, only 245 earn more than $200,000 a year.
 To avoid being totally shut out, Mayor Doria was able to gain a concession from Empire Golf that included 500 rounds of golf a year at half price for Bayonne residents as well as construction of a 2.5-mile walkway along the waterfront.
 "We're opening up an area that was totally industrial in the past that obviously was environmentally challenged," Mr. Doria said. "None of this was available to the people of Bayonne before."
 While $250,000 is an estimable chunk of change, it is not the most expensive initiation fee in New Jersey. 
 Take Donald J. Trump's 520-acre course in Bedminster that is scheduled to open in 2004. The course, to be called the Trump National Golf Club, will feature the usual over-the-top amenities that have become a staple of any property owned by the flamboyant real estate developer. Mr. Trump is including a separate area for equestrian sports and skeet shooting, for example. Consequently, joining the Trump course will cost more than $300,000. 
 Nor are clubs for the wealthy in short supply in New Jersey. The Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield -- which has been host to 15 United States Golf Association championships in its 108-year history -- charges a $50,000 initiation fee, and members are also required to purchase a $10,000 club-issued bond. At Metedeconk National in Jackson, $140,000 is the price of getting past the security gates. And at Hamilton Farm Golf Club in Gladstone, $250,000 is needed to get on to the first tee. 
 "If the economy were to rebound to a major degree, Bayonne would obviously have a much improved chance for the success," said Chuck Stogel, a former president of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association. "But even given that, people and companies -- those who would have easily jumped at buying into a corporate membership package -- are being much more careful with spending, especially discretionary funds."
 To this day, many ridicule the decision by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to build Giants Stadium atop a swamp. The location and smell would keep fans away, critics said. But judging by the combined 40-year waiting list for season tickets to Giants and Jets games, the location appears to be doing fine. 
 Al Czervik -- a real estate developer played by Rodney Dangerfield in the 1980 movie "Caddyshack" -- once declared that "golf courses and cemeteries are the biggest wastes of prime real estate."
 Al may have been on to something.

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT; 
A Scary Crop

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: MEDFORD 

 BODY:
ON an overcast October afternoon, the pickings should have been great as 5-year-old Mary Wilson searched rows of pumpkins set out at Johnson's Corner Farm, long a popular fall stop in this rapidly developing part of Burlington County.
 "Every one seems to have spots, Daddy," Mary told her father, William Wilson. The two fingered through a couple dozen pumpkins before settling on one of medium size with a few scratches. 
 "Guess it's been a bad year," Mr. Wilson said. "The pumpkins look rather sad." 
 Sad, indeed. Though the seemingly endless days of rain last spring and summer have been a bonanza for a colorful coat of foliage this fall, they played havoc with New Jersey's pumpkin crop. That has put a dent in a rural economy that has come to depend on the weekend picker, the hayride enthusiast and the fan of corn mazes to rev up farmstand sales at the end of the season.
 "We're seeing anywhere from 60 to 80 percent loss in the yields," said Michelle Infante-Casella, the pumpkin expert among the Gloucester County agricultural agents. "That means some places lost 100 percent of the crop. There was a lot of fungus out there, and if they didn't treat it with anti-fungal sprays as we warned, they could have lost everything."
 The main culprit has been the weather. In May, the prime month for planting pumpkin seedlings, it rained 26 days. The rain was double the normal amount in June, and rain fell on 14 days each in July and August, when the plants do most of their flowering. Even though the rain has subsided a bit this fall, the ground soil is so wet that each time it does rain, puddles form, drenching the grown pumpkins.
 "Pumpkins, cucumbers, cantaloupes, watermelons, all sorts of vine plants are susceptible to disease when there is too much water," said Ray Samulis, the county agriculture agent for the Rutgers Cooperative Extension in Burlington County. "The problems start early and continue right on."
 Mr. Samulis said that in May many seedlings died, drowned in those constant rains. Farmers replanted later, but most of those plants did not survive either. Many were afflicted with mildew - either powdery mildew, a white-colored disease on the top of the leaves, or downy mildew, a brown one on the underside. 
 Enter, next, the lazy, shybees, Ms. Infante-Casella said.
 "Bees like to pollinate when there is sun and clear weather," she said. "Cloudy conditions will impede a honey bee from working. They just don't do anything then. And if a flower, in this case a pumpkin flower, doesn't get pollinated, there isn't any fruit."
 To top it off, many pumpkins that did make it through all this contracted a fungus on the outside from being drenched in puddles. Their stems softened and fell off and their shells became fleshy and weak.
"Strangely enough, that wouldn't have been so bad if we grew a lot of pumpkins here for food," Mr. Samulis said. "But it's mostly what the farmers call Face Pumpkins, the kind people buy for show for Halloween." The meat in many of the weaker pumpkins would still be fine, he said, but no one wants to buy a pumpkin for a jack-o'-lantern that doesn't have a strong stem and a clear complexion.
 Harvey Ort, the fourth-generation owner of Ort Farms in Long Valley, near Chester, said he lost about 50 percent of his pumpkin crop but saved enough to sell at his farmstand and to give to people who take his hayrides this fall.
 "It was just too wet," Mr. Ort said. "You can't just wash off a fungus and sell the pumpkin. Leave any fruit in your house in something too moist for a few days and you'll see. It's horrible."
 Ms. Infante-Casella said that many retailers, especially in South Jersey, ended up buying pumpkins from Pennsylvania. It's not that it rained much less there, but the farming process is different, primarily among the Amish who make up much of the farming community in Lancaster County.
 "We tend to specialize in either animal or crop farming in New Jersey, and there they do both dairy and vegetable farming," she said. "They also do more natural farming. They leave a cover crop of straw or living mulch on the soil, which keeps it dryer. They use cow manure, which makes a nice soil environment. Plus the soil out there is really fertile and is a little hillier, so the water drains better and doesn't sit in irrigation ditches."
 Nevertheless, determined pumpkin pickers can take heart. In a sort of Darwinian process, the New Jersey pumpkins that did survive seem more colorful and heartier, Mr. Samulis said. Counting the pumpkins imported from nearby states, there should be quite enough to go around. He also said that corn crops look good now, so Indian corn decorations should be good, and corn mazes should also be in fine shape, unless they were damaged by recent winds of near-hurricane strength.
 Mr. Ort of Ort Farms suggests that those taking home a pumpkin wash it in a solution of 2 percent Clorox to water, to make sure that any fungus is wiped away. He is selling his pumpkins at 49 cents a pound - the going rate around the state and the same as he did last year.
 "Oh, I just gave up the wholesale pumpkins, that other 50 percent," he said. "It will be a little colder winter for us, a little less money coming in, but we intend to have a fun Halloween with hayrides and all anyway."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Harvey Ort, owner of Ort Farms in Long Valley, holds a lucky survivor of this year's pumpkin crop. Many others drowned on the vine or developed fungus. "It was just too wet," Mr. Ort said. (Photographs by Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

PERSON: Robert Strauss

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Brash Managers Need to Have Brash Pitchers

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
EVER since most of America discovered Josh Beckett -- that is to say, when Sammy Sosa bristled during the National League Championship Series -- almost every mention of Beckett has included the adjective "brash."
 Brashness often pays off in sports. And it paid off gloriously last night as Beckett pitched a superb five-hit shutout and the improbable Florida Marlins beat the Yankees, 2-0, to win the World Series in six games. 
 The visitors then celebrated on the mound in Yankee Stadium, a sight that had not been seen in the postseason for 22 years. The Yankees have not won a World Series in three seasons, but who is counting? 
Two figures dominated the World Series. One was the bongo-banging septuagenarian Jack McKeon -- Zorba the Manager -- who has been known to sit in with the band long after midnight.
It was McKeon who chose Beckett to pitch last night, no doubt blowing cigar smoke in his face and saying something like, "Let's get it over with, kid, so we can party right away."
And when a Champagne-drenched McKeon came out for his interviews, he chortled, but in a nice way: "You believe me now? Anything can happen."
The other dominant figure was Beckett, who lost Game 3 on Tuesday, but who gave up only two runs. He was clearly McKeon's best pitcher as this thrilling autumn evolved.
Last night Beckett, on only three days of rest, outlasted the gallant Andy Pettitte. Throwing fastballs in the high 90's, Beckett struck out nine and ruled the Yankees right to the end.
"This guy is special, I told you that," McKeon crowed, but pleasantly. "He's very tough. I knew he had the confidence to do the job tonight."
There had been a potential for second-guessing McKeon for going with his ace a day early. However, this was a decision of two adult parties. Beckett wanted the ball, and McKeon had no problem handing it to him.
"He's a fun guy to play for, man," Beckett said last night. "He expects a lot out of you. He's a good guy who likes to have fun."
They are an odd couple of age and youth. Beckett, the swaggering righty from Texas, shows little deference to his elders, or his peers, either. He buzzed Sosa in the league series, when the Marlins were down by three games to one, and when Sammy took exception to the heat, Beckett said he thought Sammy was over-reacting.
Then after throwing a two-hitter against the Cubs, and showing them to be vulnerable, Beckett said he fully expected to be pitching relief in Chicago in the seventh game, which indeed he was.
There is a school of thought that says McKeon should have saved Beckett to be fully rested today and played mix-and-match -- as he has often done in the postseason -- last night. But McKeon played down the four-day rest that has been the norm for almost every pitcher in baseball this generation.
"That stuff is in the past, this is the future," McKeon said. "I would not take him out in the ninth after 99 pitches."
Beckett concurred, to a point, saying: "In my case, it was O.K., but through the whole year you can't do it. You get stiff arms in a five-man rotation."
Beckett signed out of high school in Spring, Tex., and made the majors in his second year as a professional. Limited by injury, he has only a 17-17 record in parts of three seasons. Last night he shut down the Yankees in their own park and helped win a World Series at age 23.
Even if the Marlins had lost last night, McKeon was not likely to morph into Grady Little, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, who has become a legendary figure in the Greater New England Pantheon of Gloom and Doom because he stuck with Pedro Martinez, a fragile pitcher known for his full four days of rest and his pitch counts.
Little challenged that accurate profile of Martinez, and will pay the price, perhaps in unemployment, certainly in historical repute.
If it had gone badly last night, McKeon would not have had a problem with hauling the kid off the mound. He was never shy about moving people around when he was a general manager known as Trader Jack.
McKeon was rescued from the dreaded R-word last summer when the Marlins' leadership, under Jeffrey Loria, recognized that McKeon was too young at heart to hang around on his porch. A few months later, the Marlins were in the World Series, and McKeon was on the top step pounding his chest and yelling at umpires, the best possible exercise for elderly managers.
With Donald Rumsfeld having a bad season, McKeon might very well become the nation's No. 1 pinup among senior citizens. People sense his zest for life. He does not come off as some Hefnerian old goat, but rather a man who talks about his wife and grandchildren, attends morning Mass, likes to have a good time -- music, cigars, cocktails, theater, opera and lots of baseball hypotheses in the sultry and smoky night air. 
McKeon has given us a refresher course in loving life and loving his business.
Josh Beckett is a bit of a throwback, too. They both wanted to play ball. Plus, as Zorba might have said, there is no second-guessing a manager who plays the bongos. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Baseball Analysis; 
YANKEES' SILENT SURRENDER

BYLINE:  By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
The familiar figure in a blue blazer and a white turtleneck anxiously waited for an elevator about 45 minutes before the first pitch at Yankee Stadium last night. George Steinbrenner shuffled his feet and discussed a family issue. But it took Steinbrenner only about a minute to sound like the demanding principal owner the Yankees know, expect and fear.
 When Steinbrenner was asked for a prediction for Game 6 of the World Series between the Yankees and the Florida Marlins, he turned toward the questioner, stopped shuffling, stopped using syllables on the other topic and said, "My gut is we better win." 
 We better win. Not we better play well. We better win. Steinbrenner's comments were not surprising. He could have made the same proclamation in January or July and probably did. What made Steinbrenner's mandate compelling is how emphatic he was, and because the Yankees really had to win to keep their season alive.
The Yankees failed to satisfy Steinbrenner's gut or themselves as they lost to the Marlins, 2-0, and watched their season end with three straight losses to a team most figured they would defeat. But the Marlins were more resilient than the fading Yankees, who looked and played like a tattered team, whose hitters were invisible and who have made next season incredibly tense because they have not won a title for three straight seasons.
"I guess it's kind of strange to say, but I still think we got the best team in the league," Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte said. "But we didn't win.Obviously, we're not the best team because we didn't win."
Pettitte pitched seven gutsy innings and allowed one earned run, but he blamed himself for throwing too good a pitch to Luis Castillo that resulted in a run-scoring single in the fifth. He could have also blamed himself for not getting an out at third on a bunt in the sixth, even as catcher Jorge Posada was shouting for Pettitte to throw it there. 
But Pettitte is not the reason the Yankees lost this game and suddenly gave themselves a lot of time to catch a movie or grab dinner tonight. Obviously, the Yankees wanted to be at the Stadium playing a Game 7. Pick a Yankee, any Yankee, who waved a bat against Josh Beckett and flopped. Those lifeless hitters are the reasons the Yankees will spend the winter wondering what went awry and why the batting coach Rick Down could be the first man on the unemployment line.
"I guess I'm still kind of shocked a little bit," Pettitte said. "I didn't expect this to happen. I felt as confident walking out of the bullpen that we would win as I ever have."
Steinbrenner was pensive as he waited for the game that would determine whether his $180 million Yankees would play for a title tonight. When someone mentioned to Steinbrenner that he must have felt confident with Pettitte going because he had already saved the Yankees three times this postseason, Steinbrenner was prescient as he sought admittance to the Josh Beckett Fan Club.
"What about the other guy?" Steinbrenner said. "He's a good pitcher. We've got to hit."
Even Steinbrenner knew it. Steinbrenner continued ranting to a friend: "We can't swing at the first pitch against this guy. First pitch, all the time. We've got to be patient."
Guess what? Beckett said he actually felt the Yankees were more patient against him last night than they were in Game 3, but he adjusted by mixing in more off-speed pitches and making several hitters look befuddled. Derek Jeter, who had the only three hits off Beckett in his last start, was 0 for 4, stranded three runners and made an error that led to Florida's second run. The player Luis Sojo called "the real Mr. October" played like it was a meaningless month. 
"It never sets in," Jeter said. "You start in the middle of February with one goal, to win a championship. We didn't do it."
The Yankees were 0 for 12 with runners on base last night and hit a brutal .169 with men on base for the series. There were chances for the Yankees sprinkled throughout every game, including having runners in scoring position five times off Beckett, but they never capitalized. If $180 million bought Steinbrenner anything this season, it should have bought him a couple of players who could have slapped two-out hits.
As the Yankees trudged around a quiet clubhouse like zombies, some of them believed they had lost to a team they should have stopped. The Marlins are deserving champions, a loose band of players who followed Manager Jack McKeon to the pinnacle of the sport and had fun every inch of the way. Jeter said the Marlins were "better than us in this series," stopping short of saying Florida was better than the Yankees. Saying that would have been too painful on a painful night.
After winning four titles in five seasons, the Yankees are winless in the last three so it will probably be time to separate the 2004 Yankees from those championship teams. Even though there will be players remaining from those teams, they are not champions anymore. 
"There'll be changes, I'm sure," Pettitte said. "Right now, I'm sick. I'm sick to my stomach right now."

Paul Burnett/The New York Times); The Marlins celebrating their second World Series title as Nick Johnson of the Yankees headed to the off-season. A nimble slide by Alex Gonzalez, right, gave the Marlins the only run they needed in Game 6. (Photographs by Barton Silverman/The New York Times and G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times right )

HEADLINE: A Campaign Without Big Guns 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA FITZGERALD

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
WHEN New Jersey voters talk about the election, more often than not they are referring to Arnold and California -- or perhaps to the passel of Democratic presidential contenders -- but not to Jim and John, the leaders of the state Democrat and Republican parties respectively. 
 Little wonder. The state's top political leaders have not exactly been hitting the campaign trail with splashy events. They have barely been hitting it at all. 
 For the record, Jim is better known as James E. McGreevey, the beleaguered governor of New Jersey, whose poll numbers have been plummeting. Although Mr. McGreevey is not up for re-election until 2005, the voters' measure of his first two years in office are likely to play a role in the November election. 
And John is John O. Bennett, the Republican co-president of the evenly divided Senate and the highest-ranking Republican in the state, has been struggling because of an investigation into his billing practices while a municipal attorney. Although the two party leaders have been working behind the scenes to raise money for the fall races -- Governor McGreevey, in particular, with great success -- neither man has been very visible in a campaign that has all 120 seats in the Legislature up for grabs. 
Since taking office, Governor McGreevey's poll numbers have been in a consistent decline, so much so that the most recent Quinnipiac University survey, made public on Sept. 25, showed that only 35 percent of the respondents approved of the governor's performance, and 52 percent disapproved. 
And Mr. Bennett -- who earlier this year insisted on staying in his race despite pleas from local party officials to consider withdrawing -- finds himself in the fight of his political life. A defeat in his Monmouth County district could mean not only the loss of a Republican seat but even a shift in the balance of power in the Senate.
As a consequence, the baggage of the political leaders is making the outcome of this midterm election difficult to predict. But its importance cannot be underestimated. Not only will the elections on Nov. 4 be about who controls the two legislative branches of state government, but they will also determine who leads the two parties in the near future. That matters because whoever emerges in a leadership position will largely set the agenda and determine who gets to run for governor in 2005.
Yet while the stakes are high, pollsters see just a handful of races -- about 4 or 5 of the 40 districts -- deciding which party will control the Legislature.
For Governor McGreevey, the outcome could be a crucial factor in whether Democrats want him to seek a second term. With voter approval ratings already low, the loss of either the Assembly or the Senate could set off a call for change that would be hard for the Democratic leadership to ignore.
"If Republicans do win both houses, you will likely start hearing Democrats start talking publicly about Doomsday in 2005," said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University.
Carl Golden, a former spokesman for Mr. McGreevey's Republican predecessor, Christie Whitman, was only too happy to concur. "If he loses one house it's bad; if he loses both houses it's a catastrophe," Mr. Golden said. 
Mr. Golden added, "The only conclusion one could draw from that is that it is a repudiation or rebuke of the governor Unfortunately, that's what happens when you're the governor. As the only state official elected statewide, everything sooner or later washes up at the front door of the governor's mansion."
In truth, it would be hard -- if not virtually impossible -- for Democrats to deny the governor the chance to seek re-election, though Republicans are certainly trying, And so they have already started to campaign against Mr. McGreevey, making him the main focus of this election.
They are counting on his low approval with voters, missteps during his first two years in office and his handling of the state budget as a reason for voters to change parties.
In one Republican mailing, the candidates who are actually running were barely mentioned. Instead, the governor was pictured amid newspaper articles about budget cuts, with a caption saying: "Jim McGreevey wants to elect a Democratic Legislature so he can keep raising taxes. Only you can stop him This year send Governor McGreevey as message. Vote Republican."
Republicans have denounced cuts in property tax rebates to homeowners, higher taxes on cigarettes, automobile fees and a lack in increased financing for suburban schools. The governor has also irked constituencies within his own party by first proposing to cut money for artistic and cultural programs, although mosrt of the funds were were ultimately restored. Educators in the state's poorest districts have also decried a lack of financing for their court-ordered programs.
Democrats believe the focus will backfire.
"It won't resonate," said Adam Green, communications director for the state Democratic Party. "Republicans are trying to make this election a referendum on the word 'McGreevey,' but they will not run against Democrats on the actual accomplishment we've had on issues." 
Mr. Green said that candidates who have been going door-to-door "have found no visceral reaction to Governor McGreevey," and he added that when it came to economic issues, "to the extent that people are attributing blame, they are just as willing to blame former Governor Whitman and President Bush."
It boils down to this: Republicans are looking at Mr. McGreevey and thinking they see James J. Florio, the last Democratic governor, who was voted out of office in 1993 after just one term for pushing a $2.8 billion tax increase through the State Legislature more than a decade ago. Before that election was over, Republicans also effectively turned voter angst against Democrats in general, regaining both houses of the state Legislature.
But while voters may not like Governor McGreevey, few political experts see the sentiment against him approaching the level of the anti-Florio years.
McGreevey Still Has Time
"The independents who traditionally decide elections are fairly well read and discerning and can be ticket splitters, but I don't think at this point I see any real anti-McGreevey sentiment that would translate against legislative candidates from his ownparty," said Mark Magyar, president of the Public Policy Center of New Jersey.
Mr. Magyar said that even if Democrats lose one house of the Legislature, Governor McGreevey still has two years -- an eternity in politics -- to bolster his image and make the case for his re-election.
Republicans, on the other hand, have a much harder task at hand. With less money coming in and crucial battles in districts that have historically leaned Democratic, they face a challenge trying to regain both legislative houses.
What makes the task more difficult for Republicans is the perception that the party has been devoid of leadership since the departure of several power brokers -- Governor Whitman; Donald DiFrancesco, the former acting governor and Senate president; former Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and former Representative Bob Franks. The post-election job facing Republicans -- whatever the outcome next month -- will be to shore up a new coalition to run their Senate caucus.
Yet far from helping other Republicans get elected, Mr. Bennett is having enough difficulty getting in a race that to this point is considered too close to call. 
In the spring, Mr. Bennett decided to seek re-election despite newspaper articles that raised questions about his billing practices as a municipal attorney, something that state and federal officials are still looking into. For his part, Mr. Bennett -- who has featured himself in campaign advertisements with an actual bulldog -- said he has unfairly become the target of the governor, who Mr. Bennett said is keeping an "enemies list" of prominent Republicans. 
The Democratic State Committee acknowledged it had hired a political consulting firm to compile information on the state's most prominent Republican leaders, though for "opposition research" and nothing more. 
Still, some of Mr. Bennett's problems have come from within his own party. In March, the Republican chairman of Monmouth County, William Dowd, said that there was a general agreement among local party officials that Mr. Bennett should not seek re-election. In the end, Mr. Bennett chose to stay in the race, easily defeating a primary challenger.
During his victory speech, he said he intended to frame the general election as a referendum on Governor McGreevey, adding that his Democratic challenger, Ellen Karcher, was "going to end up having Jim McGreevey on her arm, but I'm going to have the people of the 12th District on my arm." 
But in his own district, the strategy does not appear to be working. A recent survey conducted by Fairleigh Dickinson University showed Ms. Karcher --the daughter of former Assembly Speaker Alan Karcher --running ahead of Mr. Bennett, 43 percent to 37 percent. This led Bruce Larson, a political science professor at the university, to conclude, "The issue shaping this election so far is not McGreevey, it is voters' perception of Bennett."
Interestingly, Mr. Bennett's race is crucial because only a few legislative districts are considered competitive enough to end up tilting the balance of power in the Legislature, and his is one of them.
In addition to Mr. Bennett's race 12th District, Republicans are working overtime for control of other seats as well. In the Fourth Legislative District, which includes Camden County, state Senator George F. Geist is going up against Fred Madden, a former acting superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, who along with the rest of his ticket has been the beneficiary of about $1.4 million in donations -- making this the state's most expensive contest. 
Republicans also want to hold onto their Senate seat in the 14th Legislative District in Mercer and Middlesex Counties. Although the district is predominantly Democratic, voters have looked favorably on state Senator Peter Inverso in the past, and his current challenger, Anthony Cimino, is not expected to unseat him. 
Democrats, on the other hand, want to hold onto their seats in Bergen County's 38th Legislative District and in the 36th District, which also includes Essex and Passaic Counties. In Bergen County, Assemblywoman Rose Heck, a Republican, is challenging Joseph Coniglio, the Democratic incumbent, in the hope of restoring some Republican rule to the county, which largely favored Democrats in the last election. In the 36th District, the Democrat, Paul Sarlo, is facing John Kelly, who lost in his last bid for the Senate in 2001.
Should Mr. Bennett prevail and his party either remain co-equals in the Senate or gain control outright, there is some possibility that the leadership roles could change. But some observers are wondering if there is any muscle -- or even the desire -- for such change in the party's leadership.
If Mr. Bennett is re-elected and wants to stay on, "it would be hard to deny him," said Steve Salmore, a former Republican consultant and research professor at Farleigh Dickinson University. "I don't see anyone who is going to organize the kind of take over coalition you need to establish take him out."
Perhaps Mr. Bennett is taking out an insurance policy, since he has already told Republicans that should he win, this will be his last term in office.
Once the midterm elections are out of the way and the parties cast their gaze on the governor's race -- considered the brass ring in state electoral politics --one of the most frequently mentioned of the possible Republican candidates is state Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr. To position himself carefully and avoid picking up any unneeded scar tissue, members of the party have been counseling Mr. Kean to seek a committee chairmanship rather than a Senate majority leadership role should Republicans win the Senate. 
Unlike most candidates, Mr. Kean -- the son of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who is still beloved by a wide swath of New Jersey voters -- does not need to improve his name recognition, said , Roger Bodman, a Republican lobbyist and onetime aide to the governor. "With the prominence of his name, he doesn't need to be Senate president," Mr. Bodman said. Instead, he can remain behind the scenes, working with colleagues and hammering out his own agenda. 
Besides, said Mr. Bodman, "you don't get that much out of the leadership role as you might think."
The worst possible scenario for Republicans would be for the party to lose its split control of the Senate, leaving little momentum as it headed into the governor's race. If that were to happen, the pressure would build among Republicans to find a new leader to rally the troops and start building momentum for 2005.
Republicans Face 'Real Trouble'
"This race is a real opportunity for the Republican Party to get back to parity if they can win at least one house," said Mr. Magyar. "If they don't, they're in real trouble."
To that end, Democrats are trying their hardest to persuade voters through costly television advertising to stay with their party. Indeed, as the election in New Jersey enters its final week, fundraising for legislative campaigns has reached record levels. 
"We're girding ourselves for a $2.5 million blitz on network television," said Bill Baroni a Republican who is challenging two Democrats, Gary Guear and Linda Greenstein, in the 14th Legislative District in Mercer County. 
For their part, Republicans insist the Democrats' tactic may backfire with voters because of the negative tone of the ads.
"Watching California commercials and watching New Jersey commercials is like watching the Disney Channel and then switching over to the Sci-Fi Channel," said Dale Florio, the Republican chairman of Somerset County. "The tone and the go-for-the-jugular approach is truly Garden State politics at its worst."
Still, Mr. Florio conceded that there was no real way of knowing whether the ads were catching on simply considered abrasive until Election Day. Historically, legislative races in New Jersey have been driven by local events.
But this year, besides the run-of-the-mill issues that are the mainstay of local campaigns, there are other factors at work. For instance, some districts are relatively new, having been redrawn after the 2000 Census. This is the second election since the districts were reconfigured, and Republicans wonder if some results in the last election were atypical, since voters were also selecting a governor. At the time, Mr. McGreevey was well ahead of his Republican challenger, Bret Schundler, in the polls.
The other factor making the race hard to predict are the various ethics charges that have been swirling. For instance, Assemblyman Michael J. Arnone, a Republican from Red Bank, has been criticized by Democrats who say readers of the state's legislative Web page were led to believe that he graduated from Seton Hall University. And in the 14th Legislative District, District, Assemblyman Gary Guear has been criticized for hiring his wife as consitituent services director, a job that pays $55,000 annually.
What experts cannot predict is how much these issues will affect the way people vote. Most agree that the tight races will largely come down to money and turning out the vote, an area in which Republicans concede that Democrats may have the upper hand.
"The huge factor here is that the Democrats appear to have extraordinary sums of money," said Mr. Florio. 
Reports released recently by the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission show Democrats well ahead of Republicans when it comes to raising money for this race; so far the Democratic State Committee has raised $14.5 million compared with just $3.7 million collected by the Republicans.
Yet for all the expense, the biggest challenge for both parties simply may be getting people to the polls. 
It appears as though the public has answered the New Jersey election this fall with a resounding yawn. These legislative midterm elections, sandwiched between the California recall race and the 1994 presidential election, don't seem to be capturing much attention, as far as pollsters can tell. Consultants predict that this could historically be one of the lowest turnouts in New Jersey history, with well under 30 percent of registered voters going to the polls.
"You know how it is the goal of every candidate to personally call every potential voter?" Mr. Florio said. "Well, this year you can actually do it."

Who Is Running? Go Online
WHAT do you mean there's an election coming?
For those who have been distracted, unaware or otherwise come up short in conversation about the statewide elections on Nov, 4, there is time -- and a way -- to get up to speed.
For the first time, New Jersey voters will be able to go to a Web site -- www.njvoterinfo.org -- which is being run by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University under the banner "Don't Give Them a Seat Until You Know Where They Stand."
When readers go to the site they will find information about the incumbents, their challengers, the districts in which they live, the major issues and recent newspapers articles about the races.
"Unfortunately, New Jerseyans have limited opportunities to get information about this election," said Ingrid Reed, director of the Eagleton Institute's New Jersey project. "Eagleton has created the first and only Web site that gives voters the information they need to make the election relevant and it has the enthusiastic support of the candidates."
Ms. Reed said the site would be updated through Election Day.

HEADLINE: How Much for That Professor? 

BYLINE:  By David L. Kirp; David L. Kirp, professor of public policy at the University of California at Berkeley, is author of "Shakespeare, Einstein and the Bottom Line: The Marketing of Higher Education."

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif. 

 BODY:
It was big news in academe last winter when New York University bested Harvard and lured Niall Ferguson, the most widely discussed and controversial British historian of his generation, away from Oxford. But recruiting superstars was nothing new for the university. Its strategy has been to achieve world-class status by attracting a critical mass of top-flight faculty. An institution that was nearly bankrupt in the mid-1970's has become the success story inhigher education.
 Having mastered this frenzy of renown, New York University now wants to change the rules of the game, turning its prized collection of individual talents into citizens of the academic commonweal. In a widely circulated report, the university's president, John Sexton, has issued a "summons to engagement." It calls for the research faculty to spend more time with students inside and outside class, "engage with colleagues of differing views of expertise" -- even hobnob with alumni and participate in admissions. 
 The university, and academia in general, will be better off if Mr. Sexton can pull off this sea change -- a shift from "me, myself and I" entrepreneurship to participation in a genuine community of scholars. But unless other top-rank schools decide, improbably, to declare a truce in the star wars, his efforts are likely to fail. In higher education as elsewhere, competition, not the congregation, rules.
Stealing luminaries from other universities has long been regarded as a sure-fire way to climb the academic prestige ladder. In recent years, though, such talent searches have become more commonplace and the offers have grown more outsized. No one outside the world of education used to notice these comings and goings, but now the news media have turned professors into luminaries. 
It was big news in the business section of this newspaper when, a few years back, Columbia offered the economist Robert Barro the sun and the moon, and also carte blanche to hire five additional faculty members, in a bid to lure him from Harvard. (Mr. Barro initially accepted the offer, only to change his mind and remain in Cambridge.) Last year, the Cornel West soap opera made front pages around the country. Would the Harvard professor and hip-hop musician, his intellectual prowess challenged and his pride wounded by Harvard's impolitic president, decamp to Princeton? (Yes.)
As mobility in the senior ranks of faculty members has increased, so have the differences in compensation between the most sought-after professors -- those whom Mr. Sexton lauds as his "blue team" -- and the "gray team," everyone else. Trophy professors are wooed with outsized paychecks, splendid housing, travel allowances, well-endowed research centers, brilliant colleagues -- and the promise that they'll rarely encounter an undergraduate.
Other striving universities -- among them Rice, Georgia Tech and George Mason -- have gone on such star treks, though with mixed success. The newest combatant is the University of Southern California. In an explicit bid to become the next New York University, it has created a war chest of $100 million to recruit 100 luminaries in just three years, with a promise of more money and more star hires down the road. Already this attention-grabbing move is heating up the bidding wars.
What's good for a university's reputation, however, isn't necessarily good for its students' education. Since the standing of top-rung professors, their bankable asset, depends on what they write, not how they teach, their main loyalty isn't to their students or their institution. 
While Mr. Sexton says he is determined to turn this trend around at New York University, some recent initiatives there have reinforced this professorial narcissism. Take the university's philosophy department. In 1995, the department didn't even have a Ph.D. program. Just five years later it was rated as the top department in the web-based publication "The Philosophical Gourmet," the philosophers' version of the U.S. News & World Report college ranking and the bible for prospective graduate students.
A bevy of star hires has elevated the department's academic standing, and with it the university's. But the new recruits have only modest teaching responsibilities; especially in big undergraduate courses, the burden of teaching falls on graduate student instructors and adjunct faculty, higher education's replaceable parts. What's more, the newcomers are narrow-gauge specialists whose intellectual insularity -- a disengagement from both the classroom and the common public sphere -- presents a formidable obstacle to the neighborliness that Mr. Sexton now asks of his "blue team."
If all big research universities were to pledge not to use lightened teaching loads as a bargaining chip, a "common enterprise university" might stand a decent chance. But that's not how this blood sport is played. New York University knows this very well. Barely six months after the university stole him from Oxford, Niall Ferguson accepted an offer from Harvard, which for more than a century has made the poaching of star professors an art form.
