HEADLINE: OPPORTUNITIES; 
Finding Shelter From the Storm In Real Estate

BYLINE:  By KAREN ALEXANDER

 BODY:
TWO kinds of people seem to know everybody in town: politicians and real estate agents. Because of the recession, Christina Shea went from one to the other.
 As a city councilwoman and formerly a two-time mayor of Irvine, Calif., Ms. Shea devoted the last decade to her political career, which paid as much as a part-time job but consumed most of her waking hours. But as her savings dwindled, she retired temporarily from politics at the end of 2000 to earn more money. (Last year, she was re-elected as councilwoman.) She started a consulting business in government relations, which faltered badly after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. 
 So she went into real estate. She studied for the realtors' license exam for six weeks through a correspondence course, passed the test and began selling residential and commercial properties for a Century 21 broker in Irvine last fall. 
Ms. Shea is hardly alone in making the switch to the real estate industry. As other sectors of the economy have fizzled, hundreds of thousands of professionals have migrated to the real-estate field, drawn by the flexibility and independence of a career selling properties, and by the relative ease with which a person can enter the business, which happens to be booming.
Membership in the National Association of Realtors, the world's largest trade association, surged almost 18 percent in the last two years, to more than 950,000 agents and brokers (brokers are senior to agents). According to the association's most recent statistics, newcomers accounted for 75 percent of the organization's new members this year. An additional 48,000 members have been in the business less than two years.
Fueled by low interest rates and easy access to credit, the market for homes has been on the upswing since 1996, setting records for single-family-home sales every year, except 2000. Moreover, many investors view real estate as a relatively safe haven for their savings after the stock market bubble burst. By the end of this year, the number of transactions is expected to show another surge, with more than six million new and used homes trading hands.
The realtors association reported that the majority of people who entered the business switched from another line of work. Only 7 percent of realtors surveyed in 2001 said that selling homes had been their first career; 15 percent came from management positions, 14 percent from sales, 7 percent from education, and 6 percent had been homemakers.
The home-inspection business is also a popular second career, said Mallory Anderson, the executive director of the National Association of Home Inspectors, a nonprofit trade group in Minneapolis. "Most of the people coming into this were contractors or carpenters or worked construction," she said. "Their backs are tired and they want to do something else. They want to be their own boss." 
Matthew Cameron, a 35-year-old with a law degree, found his way into real estate after he lost his job as a high-tech consultant and spent a year seeking work. Mr. Cameron, who lives in San Francisco, never imagined himself selling houses, but after looking around, he realized that real estate seemed to be the only Bay Area industry that was doing well after the dot-com collapse that devastated the region's economy.
For all the flexibility and potential profits a career in real estate offers, it does not always translate into quick profits. After a year in the business, Mr. Cameron and Ms. Shea both say that although they enjoy the work, they have found it more difficult than they thought to make money.
Despite the considerable network Ms. Shea has developed in Irvine, she said that it took her a year to hit her stride. To get started, she spent about $3,000 on licensing fees, local and national association dues and signs and supplies. She spends nearly $400 a month on advertising, a sum she would like to increase when she can. 
"It's difficult to retool when you're 50 years old and haveto start thinking of a whole new career," she said.
Because of her city council duties, Ms. Shea works about 20 hours a week on real estate. She has cut back on the number of political events she attends so she can focus on business. "It just doesn't make any money," Ms. Shea said of the reception-and-dinner circuit she left behind. She also keeps up her consulting business and is a notary. 
Unlike Ms. Shea, Mr. Cameron began his real estate career without access to a wide range of acquaintances in the region. In fact, Mr. Cameron, who was laid off from his consulting job with Deloitte & Touche in October of 2001, had just moved to San Francisco to live with his partner. He knew the real estate business would not be easy. "I braced myself," he said, adding, "I've been surprised by how tough it can be."
It took Mr. Cameron nine months to close his first deal. "I was getting extremely worried," he said. "I was starting to get pressure at home. We really needed another income."
Searching for ways to attract customers, Mr. Cameron arranged a home-buying seminar at the campus of the University of California, San Francisco, where his partner is a medical resident. But barely any of the 26 people who attended the presentation could afford to buy a home in the region. "Unless you can get into the mid-$300,000 range, you are extremely limited here," Mr. Cameron said. "A lot of the people that came, unfortunately, couldn't afford to go into that price range."
Although he is working with two clients now, and trying to stay optimistic, there are no guarantees that either client will strike a deal. "The main problem with real estate is, you don't ever know when your next paycheck is coming in," he said. "I have been second-guessing myself, and I still have feelers out there for a more regular job. If a decent, more permanent position came up that would pay me well, I'd consider it."
Real estate experts say that moving out of the field is almost as common as moving into it. "A lot of people enter the business, and a lot of people leave the business," said Kenneth Rosen, the chairman of the Fisher Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the University of California, Berkeley. While it is relatively easy to enter real estate, "it does involve a lot of skill," he said. 
"It is very hard to make money in real estate, even in a good market," Mr. Rosen added. "There's a lot of substance to it, and it's a much more professional activity than one would think."
Like the stock-market bubble, the real estate boom will eventually experience a slowdown, Mr. Rosen said. Although he does not foresee a drastic fall in real estate prices, he predicts that activity will drop as much as 20 percent over the next several years. 
"Interest rates will go up, and lending will be tightened," Mr. Rosen said. And the backlog of people who were waiting to buy houses, he added, "has pretty much been eliminated" in this current boom. Even though first-time home buyers are always entering the market, the frenzied pace of transactions is bound to slow down.
According to the National Association of Realtors, sales of existing homes will decline 7 percent next year, and new-home sales will fall 10.4 percent. If those predictions are realized, 2004 will still be the third best year for home sales on record.
Mr. Cameron said he was learning on the job. For his next presentation at the University of California, San Francisco, which he is planning for early next month, Mr. Cameron said he would aim the publicity more toward the doctors and medical residents who can afford the market. And he recently left a nationally affiliated brokerage to work for a smaller, more locally focused firm, which agreed to let him keep 65 percent of his earnings. At the larger brokerage company, he had to split his commissions 50-50.

HEADLINE: THE NEW GENERATION; 
Class of 2003: What They Wanted, What They Got

BYLINE:  Interviews by Laura Randall.

 BODY:
Chanda J. Davis, 22, Cincinnati
Bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering, Northwestern University. Engineer, package development, the Procter & Gamble Company, Cincinnati.
 THE economy got really bad the year before I graduated, so we all knew what we were going to be faced with. I started the summer before, looking at job postings on my own. By the time I got to school my senior year, I knew the elements of the job I wanted. I wanted to be in a position where I was going to be around people, and it had to be engineering-related. I had already spent four years in college with mechanical engineering and, by God, I was going to use something that I learned. 
 Getting started early was the key. I interviewed with two companies in the fall of my senior year, P. & G. being one of them. I went in for my second interview during Christmas break and was offered a position on the spot. The salary exceeded my expectations, and I think that's from the downturn happening when we were juniors and we had already lowered our expectations. When everybody started getting frantic about jobs, I already had something lined up. I kept it to myself. I wouldn't talk about my position or the offer unless someone asked about it because I knew that lots of folks didn't have jobs. There was a lot of confusion and nervousness in the air.
I feel blessed because I found a job that I actually like, and then you have someone who scored really high on his G.M.A.T.'s and he's driving a paint truck because he doesn't have any work experience. That's a real example.
I wasn't sure about moving to Cincinnati at first. People would ask, "Where do you want to go?" and being a recent grad, you want to go to the places where there's lots of young people, lots of things to do, so you automatically think Chicago or New York. When I got the offer, I had to think about it a bit, because Ohio was not the place I wanted to go. Now I'm opening up to the city.
I started a week after graduation. At the beginning, it was overwhelming. I talked to people here and they said, you're going to be lost for about a year. I started with responsibilities on Day 1. It's a drawn-out process being comfortable with the 40-plus-hour workweek and being comfortable with being an adult. I would come home for the first two weeks and go right to sleep and wonder where my day went.

HEADLINE: THE NEW GENERATION; 
Youthful Attitudes, Sobering Realities

BYLINE:  By JULIE CONNELLY

 BODY:
PATRICK KEYES, a senior partner and director for business development at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, the advertising agency in New York, enjoys acting as a mentor to his young staff members. Mr. Keyes, 40, says it is a powerful substitute when he cannot agree to their demands for raises or bonuses. 
 "After we complete a pitch for new business," he said, "there are always opportunities to tell them what they did right, or explain how they might have done it better." 
 Mr. Keyes's coaching can be quite specific, particularly when young people are too casual in communicating with senior executives. "I had to explain," he said, "that it wasn't the best idea for a junior person to conclude an e-mail to the president of Ogilvy with, 'Thoughts?' " 
In many ways, his comments capture the attitudes of America's newest labor force, 30-something workers -- the so-called Generation X -- and their 20-something counterparts, Generation Y, who are old enough to be starting careers. This group, ages 20 to 34, makes up roughly a third of the working population, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
These younger workers are often viewed as demanding, self-absorbed and presumptuous, but also as ambitious, free-thinking and eager to learn. They form "a dramatically different labor market that is changing not just the way people are hired and fired, but also how they view their jobs, their employers and their careers," said Peter Cappelli, the author of "The New Deal at Work: Managing the Market-Driven Workforce" and a professor of management at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
Because of an unsettled economy and an employment market that has not been kind to these workers, they think there is no reward for loyalty and are reluctant to make long-term commitments. Though they have been called disloyal and unwilling to pay their dues, the reality is that they are adapting to a workplace in which "corporations broke the old arrangement unilaterally," Professor Cappelli said. "They've seen what's gone on with their parents' generation, and a lack of trust in the corporation is a perfectly rational response to that."
This lack of trust is giving rise to another phenomenon, a sense of free agency among young workers who expect to create lifetime careers not with one or two companies, but as independent contractors, selling their services on a project basis to many employers. Each new job is a new negotiation -- for pay, obviously, but also for control of the working environment, balance between work and private life and training for the next job. 
According to Bruce Tulgan, the founder of RainmakerThinking, a consulting firm in New Haven that studies young workers: "Free agency has swept across the entire work force. Skilled workers of all ages are trading stability for mobility."
The strain is most developed in the 30-something workers who have never known a stable workplace and grew up mainly as self-reliant latchkey children. "As a result," Mr. Tulgan, 36, said, "X'ers are used to facing problems on our own and have great confidence in our ability to fend for ourselves." 
That may explain why young workers seem to be self-centered in their approach. "The things they ask us about are benefits, rewards and career opportunities -- the things that impact 'me' -- rather than where are we going to be as a company in 10 to 15 years," said John Lankford, the director for management education and leadership development at Oakwood Healthcare in Dearborn, Mich., who recruits young workers. 
Mr. Tulgan views this as a sophisticated response to a workplace that operates without the myth of job security. In the last two decades, businesses have embraced large layoffs in the name of cost cutting while reducing benefits for those employees who somehow escaped the scythe. "They don't want to be suckers," he said of younger workers. "They look around and say: 'Don't tell me about the long-term. Do you think I'm a fool?' "
The current economy is putting the concept of free agency to the test. Unemployment is higher among younger workers than in the general population. As of September 2003, the national unemployment rate was 6.1 percent, but it was 10.9 percent for those 20 to 24 and 6.3 percent for those 25 to 34, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
Jeff Taylor, the chairman and founder of the Internet bulletin board Monster.com, said that "of the college class of 2003, 93 percent are still looking for full-time employment." Monster.com, which is aimed at workers of all ages, is popular with young people. On Oct. 21, an online poll of 4,570 visitors to the site revealed that when finding a job, 71 percent planned to stay put, 14 percent expected to move on within two months and 14 percent planned to leave within six months.
These numbers, while reflecting the state of the job market, also highlight the mixed message that many young workers send out: though leery of company loyalty, they long for a stable and comfortable work environment. 
Though a better economy might encourage David Wallsh to start looking around, he plans to stay in his current job. At 25, he is a customer- care consultant for LendingTree.com, an Internet lending service in Charlotte, N.C. He was hired in July 2001, and it is his fourth job since he graduated from Muhlenberg College in Allentown, Pa. A psychology major who wanted to go into human resources, Mr. Wallsh received no job offers after he graduated, so he took jobs as a desk clerk in two hotels and then answered phones at a bank's call center. 
He found out about LendingTree at a job fair, and his first position was working the night shift answering e-mail messages from customers. It took him more than six months to be hired permanently, but now he has been promoted and is working days.
At this point, he said: "My seniority is more important than a paycheck. I might want to become a loan officer."
ANOTHER young person who finds herself driven by the economy into doing work she never expected to do is Keeley Canning Luhnow, 28. She graduated from Wake Forest University School of Law in Winston-Salem, N.C. in May 2002, expecting to practice hospitality law. Though her husband had a job in San Diego, she was willing to relocate for an opportunity to join a big law firm. But she received no offers from firms in any of the cities she and her husband were willing to move to, so she accepted a position as an associate in a one-person firm in La Mesa, Calif., specializing in elder law. 
"I wasn't very keen on elder law when I took the job," she said, "but I've grown to like it. My future depends on what happens with the job market, but my employer hopes I'll inherit her practice."
Experts predict that although young workers are glad to have jobs now, they will grow restless once the economy improves. And when employers start vying for these young workers again, experts say, they will have to make an effort to overcome the young people's cynicism and deal with their contradictory behavior. 
"These young people have moved a lot and they come from broken marriages," said Chris Widener, the president of Made for Success, a leadership consulting firm in Issaquah, Wash. "They look for stability, community, security in the workplace, and if they don't get it they'll move on to another employer." 
Regina Richardson, 26, a senior sales manager at the Millennium Hotel in Cincinnati, has been with the company for four years. What keeps her there, she said, is a boss who "pushes me to achieve what is seemingly unattainable, so I can move ahead with my career." Plus, she said: "It's a friendly place. We all know each other's kids' names and dogs' names."
Even so, Ms. Richardson is not sure she will stay with the company for the long haul. She was raised by a single mother, whom she is proud of and who has worked in the registrar's office at Pennsylvania State University for nearly 18 years. "She's very happy where she is," Ms. Richardson said. "But where the older generation considers it stability, I consider it being stuck." 
Christian Reyes, 28, a senior quality assurance engineer at Electronic Arts, an entertainment software developer in Redwood City, Calif., is equally wary. "We all have these hopes that there will be opportunities for us to build loyalty to the job, though we're cynical," he said. Mr. Reyes has had three jobs since graduating from college. Most of his friends, he said, did the dot-com hopscotch, and most have settled for pay cuts and temporary jobs in the aftermath of the Internet bust.
Complicating life for many employers is that with Gen X'ers, everything is apparentlyopen for negotiation. "This is a generation that is used to asserting itself," said Jeff Chambers, the vice president for human resources at SAS, a software company in Cary, N.C. "They know they are mobile; they know they have opportunities." 
Judith Gerberg, the director of Gerberg & Company, a career counseling service in New York, said that many young workers were used to negotiating with their parents "and they bring this behavior into the office."
Mr. Lankford, the health care recruiter, said that young workers often challenged company policies on matters like tuition reimbursement. "Their attitude is, 'Why won't you pay for this?' " he said. "Instead of accepting that these are our policies, they'll say: 'Let's talk about making an exception.' Or, 'Let's change the policies.' " 
Mr. Lankford, 52, said he was inclined to extend himself not only because the health care industry is in a ferocious bidding war for talent but also because "these people think out of the box." 
A frequent point of negotiation is the work-life balance. "No matter how bad the economy gets, these workers won't work in an environment they don't like," said Ann A. Fishman, president of Generational Targeted Marketing, a research company in New Orleans. "They are willing to give up salaries to have quality of life in the workplace."
Young workers are turned off by having to put in "face time." For instance, they think, why can't we tote our laptops to the wireless cafe and log in from there? 
"The old 40-hour workweek just doesn't apply," said Conrad Sam, 29, director for sales and marketing at Smashing Ideas, a Web site developer in Seattle. "The average age here is 27 or 28, and people come in when they want. If there's work to be done, you'll stay and do it. No one I know would ever work for anyone where there's a premium on face time." 
Education and training are other negotiating matters: free agents quickly discover that survival depends on keeping their skills current. "They want to learn constantly because once they stop learning, they stop being viable," said Heather Neely, a consultant at RainmakerThinking. 
Ultimately, many experts think that negotiation as a model is unsustainable because it causes each employee to focus on his or her own needs instead of the task at hand. "But what does work is giving people latitude around their working conditions," said Rebecca Ryan, the founder of Next Generation Consulting, a company in Jackson, Wis., that advises businesses on how to attract young talent.
Managing younger workers can be challenging. Bosses sometimes complain about these employees' short attention spans and habits like talking to friends via cellphone or by instant messaging or downloading music while engaged in job-related tasks. 
"Multitasking is a myth," said Jennifer B. Kahnweiler, the founder of About You, a career counseling company in Dunwoody, Ga. "I watch my daughters talking on the phone while instant-messaging someone else, watching television and reading a book. You can't transfer that to the business environment. It won't work -- you lose something important if you don't pay attention." 
Yet the appeal of young workers springs from many of the traits that drive their bosses crazy, especially their independence and belief that they should be given special projects, rather than dues-paying chores.
"They are willing to take on tasks they have no knowledge about and they fearlessly march ahead," Mr. Keyes said. "I like that."

HEADLINE: A U.S. Rebirth for Mexico's Comic Legend 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
As Mexico's greatest comic actor before his death at 81 a decade ago, Cantinflas was so revered in the Spanish-speaking world that the verb "cantinflear" entered the Spanish language to describe using as many words as possible to say almost nothing of substance.
 Until recently, the impact Cantinflas had in the United States was thought to be limited to his role as Passepartout, Phileas Fogg's devoted valet in the 1956 film "Around the World in 80 Days." Less was known about Cantinflas's long sojourns in the United States, which produced few films but lasting impressions and one unforgettable romantic relationship. 
 As part of a wider rediscovery of the work of Cantinflas (pronounced cahn-TEEN-flas; his real name was Mario Moreno Reyes), a new play has begun to jar memories of the actor. The play, called "Cantinflas!" and written and performed largely by the actor Herbert Siguenza of the Los Angeles-based comedy trio Culture Clash, opens in Los Angeles on Wednesday after playing to good crowds here. 
The production comes amid a broader recognition of his importance to Latino artists in the United States like the Puerto Rican author Victor Hernandez Cruz, who described Cantinflas as "the poet exiled from the dictionary." Although Cantinflas is still seen as somewhat of a negative stereotype by some Mexican intellectuals, he is a symbol of Hispanic creativity in this country, said Ilan Stavans, a professor of Latino studies at Amherst College.
"The process of rehabilitating Cantinflas from someone ghettoized in pop culture into an icon of empowerment is not surprising," said Mr. Stavans, the author of a scholarly essay on the actor, "The Riddle of Cantinflas." "There's something satisfying in delving into the complex character who so easily touched the lives of Mexicans everywhere."
Acted 70 percent in Spanish and 30 percent in English, "Cantinflas!" explores the actor's start as a performer in a tent show in the gritty border city of Ciudad Juarez, then follows his career as he became an icon of Mexican cinema and took the stage name of Cantinflas, a play on words referring to talking big or drinking heavily in a barroom. 
The decision to perform the play mostly in Spanish was Mr. Siguenza's. Mr. Siguenza, a child of Salvadoran immigrants who bears an uncanny stage resemblance to Cantinflas, reproduces passages from the actor's films.
"You can't easily translate Cantinflas into English for the same reason you can't easily do Groucho Marx in Chinese," Mr. Siguenza said in an interview. "It's a challenge to do Cantinflas in the original, but there's no other way."
Audiences at Houston's Alley Theater reacted enthusiastically. Cantinflas lived in the city in the 1970's and 80's.
"Mario came to Houston and liked it here first and foremost because it was my town," said Joyce Jett, a former appliance store manager who shared her life with Cantinflas for more than 20 years. Their relationship ended in a legal battle in 1991 that recognized her as his common-law wife and initially awarded her a divorce settlement of about $26 million; later the two settled out of court for an undisclosed amount.
Cantinflas, who accumulated an estimated $100 million after making 49 films in a 50-year career, met Ms. Jett while shopping for lighting fixtures in Houston for a home he was building in Mexico. His first wife, a Russian-born actress named Valentina, died in 1966.
Ms. Jett, who attended the opening of "Cantinflas!," was so overcome with emotion by the end of the play that she gave Mr. Siguenza a pair of Cantinflas's sunglasses with the name "Cantinflas" etched into them.
"I was skeptical that someone could master the details of Mario's performances so well," she said in an interview. "The play brought back a lot of different emotions." 
Others who knew Cantinflas had similar reactions. Al Zarzana, the former owner of a chain of Spanish-language movie theaters in Texas, said the play made him remember the efforts Cantinflas made to find anonymity away from fans. They rarely worked. "Wherever we went there would be a native Spanish speaker who would recognize Mario and want to talk to him and embrace him," Mr. Zarzana said.
In Houston, the recent interest in Cantinflas was fueled not just by his status as a Latino icon, but also by economics. The bankruptcy filing two years ago of one of the Alley Theater's largest donors, the Enron Corporation, left the theater struggling; for the Alley, where just 3 percent of the subscribers are Latino, "Cantinflas!" was a way to tap into the city's growing Latino population. Latinos account for about a third of metropolitan Houston's population.
With the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, the Alley commissioned Mr. Siguenza to write and star in "Cantinflas!," which had its first run last year in San Francisco. Preliminary figures showed that the Alley was at more than 75 percent capacity for the play. Mostly the audiences appeared to be Latino, with many people at the Alley for the first time, Mr. Siguenza said.
Although "Cantinflas!" will run through Nov. 2 at the Cerritos Center and there is talk of taking the play to New York, Mr. Siguenza said he had no plans to play Cantinflas in Mexico.
Dr. Kerry Bloom, the actor's dentist here, remembered that Cantinflas was more than merely funny. "Mario was a very charming and generous man," he said. "He had that ability to light up everyone in a room, which is one of the attributes that made him great."

HEADLINE: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 19th District, Northeastern Queens; 
Queens Democrat's Fiscal Policy Assailed

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Two years ago, Tony Avella became the first Democrat elected in his northeastern Queens district in a decade. And since then, Mr. Avella has sought to establish himself as a public official in touch with the moderate-to-conservative sensitivities of his district.
 But now his opponent is assailing his record in one of the few New York City races in next week's general election that is seen as competitive. The candidate, Phil Ragusa, an accountant, is a vice chairman of the Queens Republican Party and has a long history of involvement in civic organizations in the district. He has sought to portray the councilman as a fiscally liberal official out of sync in the district. 
 The 19th Council District, in the far reaches of northeastern Queens, stretches along the Long Island Sound from College Point to Little Neck and Douglaston along the Nassau County border. It is a district with a suburban feel, its streets lined with one- and two-family houses.
Specifically, Mr. Ragusa, who is also running on the Conservative Party line, has made the issue of taxes the hallmark of his campaign, saying that his Democratic opponent has been quick to agree to tax increases.
"He has voted for nearly every tax increase that has been put before him," said Mr. Ragusa, 64, over the clamor in his campaign headquarters. "He voted for nearly every tax and every other spending program. He voted to increase the real estate tax, the sales tax and income tax."
But Mr. Avella, 52, is quick to point out that he was one of three council members to vote against the 18.5 percent increase in property taxes passed by the Council and signed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. That vote, he points out, earned him the rebuke of the Council speaker and made him persona non grata in the Bloomberg administration.
And so far as supporting some tax increases, Mr. Avella said, there was little choice.
"I don't think raising taxes is the solution to fiscal problems," Mr. Avella said. "But we asked the state and federal government for assistance with the city's budget problems. And with their response, we really didn't have another choice. We would have had to lay off police officers and to close senior centers. So I didn't see a way out of raising those taxes." Mr. Avella said he was proud that as chairman of the council's Committee on Zoning and Franchises, he has begun the process of closing what he calls loopholes in zoning laws. Too much of this residential swath of Queens, he said, has become overrun by development, with large, multifamily dwellings creeping into areas of single-family homes.
Development has also been an issue, with Mr. Ragusa criticizing Mr. Avella for accepting campaign contributions from developers who, he insists, are adding to the congestion of the district.
"As the chairman of the Committee on Zoning and Franchises, I think it's terrible that he has fund-raisers with that title on the invitations, and that he accepts money from developers," Mr. Ragusa said. "What's he saying to the people of this district?"
Mr. Avella argued that accepting contributions from developers or anyone else did not translate into additional access. "Because someone contributes to me doesn't mean that I will give them any more consideration than anyone else in this district," he said.
He dismisses his Republican opponent as one whose campaign strategy is reliant on attacks.
"I have been working over the last two years on the issues that are of concern to the people of this district, like overdevelopment and improving the schools," Mr. Avella said. "All he does is to go negative on me."
The lines of the 19th District have been redrawn since Mr. Avella's 2001 victory to include more of the eastern Queens neighborhood of Little Neck. That redrawing has enabled the district to maintain its Democratic enrollment at about 50 percent of the electorate (the rest are split evenly between registered Republicans and those who are unaffiliated or enrolled in minor parties).
In addition, Mr. Ragusa has been endorsed by a host of Republican notables, including former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, State Senators Serphin R. Maltese and Frank Padavan and Mr. Avella's predecessor in the council, Mike Abel.
Still, this is a district with an advantage in Democratic registration and an incumbent councilman. And Mr. Avella has a large fund-raising advantage, raising $113,000 and receiving an additional $70,000 in public matching funds. Mr. Ragusa has raised $38,000 and received $82,500 in public matching funds.
Mr. Avella, who has several labor endorsements but said he had not sought any from politicians, discounts any characterization of himself as the front-runner. "I don't take anything for granted," he said.

PERSON: Garrett Hardin 

HEADLINE: Garrett Hardin, 88, Ecologist Who Warned About Excesses 

BYLINE:  By STUART LAVIETES 

 BODY:
Garrett Hardin, an ecologist and author who warned of the dangers of overpopulation and whose concept of the "tragedy of the commons" brought attention to the damage that innocent actions by individuals can inflict on the environment, died at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif., on Sept. 14. He was 88.
 He and his wife, Jane, 81, committed suicide, said their son David. 
 Dr. Hardin, who suffered from a heart disorder, and his wife, who had Lou Gehrig's disease, were members of End-of-Life Choices, formerly known as the Hemlock Society.
An emeritus professor of biology and environmental studies at the University of California at Santa Barbara, Dr. Hardin introduced "the tragedy of the commons" in an essay published in 1968 in Science magazine. Examining the overgrazing of 19th-century community pastures, or commons, the article showed how depletion of a vital resource was brought about by those who continually increased the size of their herds out of self-interest.
Dr. Hardin presented this case as a cautionary tale for a modern society that was abusing the environment. He also argued that human society had an inherently destructive relationship to nature and naturally overexploited common resources.
His commons theory is frequently cited to support the notion of sustainable development, meshing economic growth and environmental protection, and has had an effect on numerous current issues, including the debate over global warming.
Dr. Hardin confounded many of his supporters with many of his prescriptions for solving the problem of overpopulation.
In a 1974 essay in BioScience magazine, "Living on a Lifeboat," he argued against aid to famine victims in Ethiopia, explaining that sending food would only contribute to overpopulation, which he saw as the cause of the country's problems.
Born in Dallas, Garrett James Hardin received a bachelor's degree in zoology from the University of Chicago and a doctorate in microbiology from Stanford. He joined the faculty of the University of California at Santa Barbara in 1946 and retired in 1978.
The author of 27 books and more than 350 articles, he continued writing until recently, receiving the 1997 Panunzio Distinguished Emeriti Award from the University of California for his continued scholarly productivity. 
He is survived by two daughters, Hyla Fetler of Santa Barbara and Sharon Clausen of Laytonville, Calif.; two sons, Peter, of Pine Grove, Calif., and David, of Santa Barbara; four grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren.
Dr. Hardin, who contracted polio as a child and walked with the aid of crutches, saw his harsh message on overpopulation as a form of tough love. "There's nothing more dangerous than a shallow-thinking compassionate person," he said in a 1987 interview with The New York Times. "God, he can cause a lot of trouble."

HEADLINE: Jesse Jackson Jr. Throws His Support to Dean 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. said Monday that he would soon endorse Howard Dean for the Democratic presidential nomination, telling a mostly black audience on the South Side of Chicago that Dr. Dean had "the best chance to be the next president of the United States."
 "I'm not wasting my time with any more non-straight-talking candidates," Mr. Jackson said in introducing Dr. Dean, a former governor of Vermont, to a group of about 150 people at Chicago State University. 
 "I've seen him stand up for health care," he said. "I've seen him stand up for students. I've seen him stand up for ordinary Americans. I'm asking you to stand up for Howard Dean."
The support of Mr. Jackson, the son of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, has been coveted by several presidential contenders in part because he carries some of theimprimatur of his father. He said after Dr. Dean's 45-minute question-and-answer session that he would "make it official in the next 7 to 14 days."
Dr. Dean, who governed a nearly all-white state, has been fighting to show that he can appeal to a wider swath of voters than the highly educated white liberals whom polls show rallying to his side.
Mr. Jackson joins his brother, Jonathan Jackson, a Chicago businessman and civil rights advocate, and Representative Major R. Owens of Brooklyn as better-known black leaders backing Dr. Dean.
Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, another prominent African-American in Congress, escorted Dr. Dean to two black churches in Detroit on Sunday. Two other members of the Congressional Black Caucus, Representative Carolyn Cheeks Kilpatrick of Detroit and Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of Houston, have expressed interest in Dr. Dean, his aides said.
"Congressman Jackson has been one of the major new up-and-coming African-American leaders in this country, and he has been enormously helpful already," Dr. Dean said in an interview on Monday.
As for Mr. Jackson's father, he said, "We've spent a lot of time on the phone with him," adding, "He is probably the pre-eminent spokesman for civil rights and economic justice, so he's enormously important to a candidate like me."
Mr. Jackson, who earlier this month traveled with Dr. Dean from Washington to Charleston, S.C., said he had invited him home to his district, alone among the presidential candidates, because "I believe he is a man with great integrity."
In the rotunda of the Chicago State student union, Dr. Dean altered his standard stump speech to focus more on issues like discrimination in health care, support for historically black colleges, and affirmative action in the medical profession. In response to questions, he said he would seek a federal law allowing felons to vote.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: PENTAGON TRAVELER; 
Wolfowitz, a Planner of War, Sees It Up Close

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
The day had begun violently with a rocket attack on the Rashid Hotel, where he was staying, but Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense, betrayed no sign of frustration or pessimism as his Air Force jet headed back to Washington late Sunday night.
 "We have witnessed or heard about hundreds of individual acts of courage by Iraqis and by Americans and by the other coalition partners who are working together to build a new and free Iraq," Mr. Wolfowitz told reporters invited into the Airstream trailer that served as his office inside the cargo plane. 
 He said he was moved by a town hall meeting in Hilla, near the ruins of ancient Babylon. He complimented "those remarkable women, including very traditional-looking Muslim women, who are nevertheless courageous enough to stand up for women's rights," and he saluted a first generation of advocates for "organizing a center for human rights in a country where human rights have been trampled on for 35 years so brutally." 
Mr. Wolfowitz landed in Washington on Monday, a day when suicide bombings in Baghdad killed about three dozen people and wounded more than 200. The affirmations of progress in the face of the continuing violence seemed to reflect both the Bush administration's determination to maintain a positive outlook on Iraq and his own personal investment in Washington's policy.
What Mr. Wolfowitz saw during his visit to Iraq illustrated the difficulties the administration faces in trying to pacify the country without establishing a new police state, a clash between promoting a nascent democracy and halting the violence. The trip, his second since the end of major combat in Iraq, also offered abundant evidence of how hard it may be to realize the goal of a peaceful, prosperous and democratic Iraq that Mr. Wolfowitz embraces and helped to place at the center of President Bush's foreign policy.
As the Bush administration's most cerebral advocate of unleashing the American military to oust Saddam Hussein, and one who has argued the case long before being appointed deputy defense secretary, Mr. Wolfowitz has a huge personal stake in success.
Certainly, the scene outside his room at the Rashid early Sunday morning was not one Mr. Wolfowitz had hoped to witness in a visit intended to spotlight the achievements of the American occupation of Iraq. 
It was a minute or two past 6 a.m., in the pastel light of a new day. Mr. Wolfowitz was already dressed in khakis and military desert boots, preparing for his first meeting, a 6:30 session with the Corps of Engineers to discuss electrical needs.
Suddenly the early-morning calm was broken by a series of muted thuds in the distance, and then the hotel shook as missiles drilled into the side of the building, one killing an American officer in a room one floor below Mr. Wolfowitz.
As screams for help echoed through hallways filling with smoke, Mr. Wolfowitz, according to his aides, ordered up a casualty count and asked for a security assessment. He spoke with the wounded gathering in the lobby, and inspected the damage. His flight surgeon treated one man whose feet were badly lacerated when he sought to escape over a path of broken glass.
Rejecting suggestions that he cut short his trip, Mr. Wolfowitz spent the rest of the day attending to his scheduled appointments, a walking symbol of the administration's determination to impose a reality in Iraq that violent events like the Sunday morning attack -- and the subsequent bombings on Monday -- have made more difficult to achieve. 
During the next 14 hours, Mr. Wolfowitz met with Muslim clerics, town council members and business leaders. He went out on patrol with members of the First Armored Division and inspected the rocket launcher seized after the attack on his hotel. He visited wounded from the Rashid at an Army combat support hospital.
Mr. Wolfowitz swears that his practical judgment is not clouded by optimism and faith, and each stop on his whirlwind trip was meant as a data point for his argument.
When he was asked whether the administration's plan to restore the Iraqi economy is stuck in first gear, he quoted the Polish commander, Maj. Gen. Andrzej Tyszkiewicz, who was the host at a lunch at the multinational division's headquarters at Hilla. The general said Poland had been free of Communist rule for almost a decade and a half, and still unemployment ran at 18 percent.
Mr. Wolfowitz stopped at a police station in Baghdad to greet Ahmed Ibrahim, a senior deputy minister of the interior, who was shot in the leg for his alliance with the American administration, and is back to work.
Inside the freshly painted police headquarters, Mr. Ibrahim showed Mr. Wolfowitz a newspaper article put out by supporters of a radical Shiite cleric who has discussed plans to set up his own government of Iraq. The article "targets him in an ugly and vicious way, and he said, 'I'm proud of this,' " Mr. Wolfowitz said. "It's just a wonderful spirit."
Security was a constant theme and a constant concern. Mr. Wolfowitz traveled from Baghdad to Hilla to Tikrit to Kirkuk by Black Hawk helicopter, its blades beating out the rapid metronome that sets the tempo for military operations in Iraq today. Gunners had their sights up and in the locked position from takeoff to landing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy defense secretary, walks with troops after Sunday's attack in Baghdad. (Photo by Department of Defense, via Agence France-Presse/Getty Images)(pg. A12)

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA FIRES: BUSINESSES; 
Impact on Economy Could Be Short-Lived

BYLINE:  By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
At the Arrowhead Credit Union in San Bernardino, a handful of employees showed up for work on Monday in T-shirts and jeans. That was all the clothing they had left after losing their homes to California's raging wildfires. 
 "They have the clothes on their back right now," said Larry Sharp, chief executive of the credit union, which has 22 branches including one, in Crestline, that was evacuated and might have burned. "I don't have a clue right now if we have a branch in Crestline," Mr. Sharp said. 
 Still, the credit union was open, offering quick $3,000 loans to members to help them get back on their feet. That could be a symbol of how quickly business and the economy in California might rebound from the state's latest disaster. 
Economists and businesspeople say it is too early to estimate the property damage and economic impact from the wildfires, in part because they continue to burn. The damages will certainly be hundreds of millions of dollars because more than 900 homes have already been destroyed. But the damages could go much higher because thousands more homes are threatened. 
Still, while the fire is causing great personal distress, economists say that the $700 billion Southern California economy should be able to absorb the damage and that, judging from previous wildfires and earthquakes, the overall impact on the economy will be short-lived. 
Stephen Levy, director of the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy, in Palo Alto, said strikes involving grocery workers and Los Angeles transit workers now under way in Southern California were likely to have bigger impacts on the economy than the fires. 
Indeed, after the damage from the fires has been sustained, there can be a lift to the economy as people rebuild their homes and restock them with clothing and furniture. 
"There's kind of a perverse stimulative effect," said Michael Bazdarich, director of the forecasting center at the University of California at Riverside. "As a society, we're worse off because of the fire," Dr. Bazdarich said. But economic statistics look at output, he added, and that "records an uptick" because of rebuilding. 
Even that uptick, he said, may be small, if the number of houses that must be rebuilt stays at about 1,100. There are roughly 70,000 homes being built in Southern California this year, Dr. Bazdarich said. 
One thing that has mitigated the business impact of the fires, so far at least, is that the destruction has been mainly of homes, not businesses. That is because many of the fires are in foothills where there are few businesses. 
The Tamco steel factory in Rancho Cucamonga, east of Los Angeles, is two miles from where one of the largest fires started. But it has operated round the clock with little disruption other than that some employees have had trouble getting to work because of road closings, Jack Stutz, the chief executive, said. 
"It's more a story of personal calamity than it is impacting business," Mr. Stutz said of the fire. 
To be sure, there have been major business disruptions. Hundreds of flights into and out of Southern California have been canceled or delayed because a major air traffic control center near San Diego was evacuated on Sunday as a fire neared. 
"All the airports in Southern California are running at about 50 percent capacity," said Donn Walker, a spokesman here for the Federal Aviation Administration. Mr. Walker said he did not know when the control center would reopen, but that it would take several days after that for air traffic to return to normal. 
Tens of thousands of homes and businesses have lost electric power and utility officials said there was a danger of more widespread failures. 
But some transportation was moving smoothly. The Port of Los Angeles, one of the nation's busiest container ports, said it had not received any reports of interruptions from the trucks and railroads that take goods to and from the docks. "Everything seems to be going through," said Rachel Campbell, a spokeswoman. 
In San Diego County, many businesses were closed on Monday at the request of public officials. Still, it is not clear how many businesses have been damaged by the fire. 
San Diego has one of the nation's largest clusters of biotechnology companies, but those companies are concentrated along the coast in La Jolla, away from the fires, said Joseph Panetta, president of Biocom, a trade group representing the local biotech industry. Some operations may be impeded, however, because employees live throughout the county and may have been affected by the fires, Mr. Panetta said. 
Candysse Miller, executive director of the Insurance Information Network of California, a trade group representing insurers, said it was too early to estimate the payments insurance companies would have to make, but provided some guideposts. A fire in Laguna Beach 10 years ago destroyed 441 buildings, mostly homes, causing $350 million in insured losses, while one in the Malibu area that same year destroyed 323 structures and caused $375 million in insured losses. 
"We look at Laguna and Malibu and say those were catastrophes, they were tragedies," Ms. Miller said. "This is double that." 
The most damaging fire in the state, in the Oakland hills in 1991, destroyed 2,900 homes and caused about $1.7 billion in insured losses, she said. 
The fires come while California is struggling economically to some extent and faces a huge budget deficit. Those factors contributed to the recall this month of Gov. Gray Davis and the election of Arnold Schwarzenegger to replace him. 
The economic impact and the costs of fighting the fire could put further strain on the state budget and on local government budgets, which are also under strain. 
"It depends on whether the federal government steps in and helps us with this burden," said Phil Angelides, the state treasurer. 
The California Department of Finance estimates that it will cost the state $90 million to $100 million to put out the fires, said Anita Gore, a spokeswoman. She said the state expected to be reimbursed by the federal government for half of that. If that happens, she said, the state will not exceed the $70 million the current budget has allocated for emergency fire suppression.

HEADLINE: A Surge in Money Sent Home by Mexicans 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
Nearly one Mexican in five regularly gets money from relatives employed in the United States, making this country the largest repository of such remittances in the world, according to a poll sponsored by the Inter-American Development Bank.
 The pollster, Sergio Bendixen, estimates that the payments helped feed, house and educate at least a quarter of Mexico's 100 million people. 
 The poll was part of a report on Monday by the bank, which said money sent home by Mexican emigrants will soar to $14.5 billion this year, exceeding tourism and direct foreign investment to become this country's second most important source of income. Oil remains No. 1. 
Mr. Bendixen said the poll offered forceful evidence that remittances not only sustained the rural poor but have also become important to urban working-class households.
Roberto Suro, director of the Pew Hispanic Center, estimated that annual remittances to Mexico and Central America could reach $25 billion by the end of the decade, a vast sum made of countless tiny payments by America's lowest-paid workers.
"This is not necessarily something to celebrate," said Don Terry, manager of the Multilateral Investment Fund. "It means that the Mexican economy is not expanding and so people have had to leave."
Indeed, in addition to showing a significant jump in remittances, the report opened a window onto the shifts in illegal immigration to the United States since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.
In the wake of the attacks, the United States almost immediately dispatched more people and machinery to bolster law enforcement operations on its border with Mexico, and it was believed that the heightened security would discourage immigrants from their illegal crossings.
With fewer immigrants heading north, experts on both sides of the border predicted, remittances to Latin America would sharply decline. And the shrinking American economy was expected to force immigrants out of work, leaving them less money to send to relatives back home.
Those forecasts, according to the Inter-American Development Bank and immigration experts, have proved wrong.
Despite the increased risks of crossing the border, United States population estimates show that the northward flow continued to surge, and experts said the immigrant laborers had proved themselves resistant to a stormy economic climate.
Mexican immigration experts, including Rodolfo Garcia Zamora of the Autonomous University of Zacatecas, estimated that some 450,000 Mexicans entered the United States illegally last year. Mr. Suro said other evidence indicated that the American population grew last year by nearly one million people from Latin America. More than half, he estimated, had no legal status.
"For most Mexicans, the increased risks of crossing the border have had no impact on their willingness to migrate," Mr. Suro said. He recalled a focus group interview in which he asked a conference room full of Mexican men and women how many of them were considering migrating to the United States. They all raised their hands, he said.
The $14.5 billion in remittances reported by the bank marked a significant increase over the estimated $9 billion that emigrants reportedly sent home three years ago. The Mexican government estimated that remittances this year would reach $12 billion, but authorities at the bank said they had adjusted their figures to include money that had come into Mexico through informal channels.
Most of the money is spent on food, clothing and housing. But Mr. Suro said a growing portion was invested in small business or helped to pay for high school and college educations. 
Across much of central Mexico, where men and women have migrated to the United States for so many decades that crossing the border has become more a rite of passage than an escape from poverty, remittances exceed state public works budgets and pay to build roads, schools, water systems and baseball stadiums.
In recent years the United States and Mexico carried out reforms aimed at making it easier and more affordable for migrants to transfer money home. Companies like Western Union cut the fees they charged for wire transfers, halving the cost of transferring money, and American banks have begun allowing illegal immigrants to open accounts so relatives at home can withdraw funds from automatic teller machines.
Those changes have begun to ease the negative attitudes that Mexicans have long held toward financial institutions. Some 45 percent of people polled by the bank said they received their remittances from a bank or other credit institution, compared with only 7 percent in Guatemala and 17 percent in Ecuador.
The opening of more formal channels has made it easier to measure the cash flow, Mr. Terry said. And he said at least a part of the significant jump in remittances could be attributed to better accounting.
The figures have been the focus of an emerging debate among Mexican experts. At a conference last weekend in Zacatecas, several charged that the Mexican government had inflated remittance figures to help brighten an otherwise dreary economic report.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
I.R.S. Is Expected to Retain Credits for Fuel Producers
The Internal Revenue Service appears to have signaled that it will not rescind billions of dollars' worth of tax credits for producers of coal-based synthetic fuel, consultants and lawyers say.
 Such an indication, they say, came in aletter the I.R.S. sent a big synthetic fuel producer saying that it plans this month to resume its consideration of new applications to produce the fuel. Producers have relied on the I.R.S. to issue what are known as private letter rulings as quasi-official confirmation that they qualify for credits. Page C3. 

Bechtel, which hired a former commissioner of the I.R.S. to lobby on its behalf, has won support from House Republicans for what could be a generous new tax break. C5.

Procter's Profits and Sales Rise
First-quarter profit at Procter & Gamble increased 20 percent as beauty care acquisitions and a new Prilosec heartburn drug produced the largest increase in sales in eight years. Net income rose to $1.76 billion, or $1.26 a share, from $1.46 billion, or $1.04 a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 13 percent, to $12.2 billion, bolstered three percentage points by a weakening dollar. C3.

The Co-Conspirators of Spam
The problem of spam, or unwanted commercial e-mail, is usually attributed to outlaws and hucksters. But the torrent of spam that is flowing into people's electronic mailboxes comes not only from the sewers but also from the office towers of the biggest and most well-known corporations. A1.

Takeover News Fuels Gain in Stocks
Stocks rose as companies announced takeovers valued at nearly $63 billion. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 25.70 points, to 9,608.16. The Nasdaq composite index added 17.32 points, to 1,882.91, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 2.22 points, to 1,031.13. C9.

Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut senator who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, will introduce a set of proposals today to increase regulatory oversight of mutual funds and reduce conflicts of interest among fund boards. C6.

Ford May Continue Excursion Line
Ford Motor is rethinking its decision to stop making the Excursion, a huge sport utility vehicle that has been a favorite target of criticism among environmentalists. C3.

Commerce Secretary to Warn China
In a speech today, Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans, left, will give China its toughest warning to date that the administration is growing impatient with Beijing's refusal to fully open its markets to American goods and services. The message ratchets up pressure that has been steadily building since September by a parade of top administration visitors. "China is moving far too slowly in its transition to an open, market-based economy," Mr. Evans said, according to an advance copy. C9.

End of Russian 'Hysteria' Called For
Russia lurched toward a political and economic crisis as stocks, bonds and currency plummeted after the weekend arrest of Russia's richest man, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky. President Vladimir V. Putin called for an end to "hysteria and speculations." A3.

The Latest Details on Vegas
A Web site, Vegas.com, is positioning itself as the leading source of reliable, detailed and up-to-date information about Las Vegas. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. C7.

HEADLINE: BANKING GIANT: THE IMPACT; 
Fleet Customers Looking for Easier Transition

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BAYOT 

 BODY:
FleetBoston customers know about acquisitions. The company has bought more than 50 other banks over the last two decades, growing its assets to $196 billion from $39.5 billion in 1993. 
 Consumers' complaints in the wake of some of those acquisitions mirror those that have accompanied other bank mergers, which have proliferated in the last few years. In addition to higher fees, a phenomenon confirmed by the Federal Reserve and others, customers have cited customer service problems, inferior rates and the inconvenience of new account numbers. They also object to receiving sales pitches from the other branches of the acquiring bank. 
 But with Fleet as the bank being acquired this time, customers may be in for an easier transition. Bank of America has one of the better reputations among the larger banks for customer service. As a provider of home mortgages, it ranks as "better than most," said J.D. Power and Associates, and services like Gomez.com have also highly ranked its Web site.
 According to the American Customer Satisfaction Index, which is affiliated with the University of Michigan Business School, consumers' approval of Bank of America has risen steadily each of the last three year, although that level of customer satisfaction is 5 percent below the index's rating of commercial banks overall.
 "I had done business with some of the other big banks, and I was really surprised that Bank of America's customer service seemed to be quite good," said David Karmol of Great Falls, Va., who has a Bank of America credit card and has also refinanced his mortgage with the company. 
 "Not only did they have one of the most competitive deals, they made it really easy to do," said Mr. Karmol, 50, who is vice president for public policy at the American National Standards Institute.
 That would be welcome news for people like Laurie Brunner, an administrative assistant from Somerville, Mass., who became a Fleet customer after it acquired Shawmut National. She says that in the months after that merger Fleet failed repeatedly to update her mailing address, changed her checking account number without telling her, and recorded her ATM card as lost so that it was seized the next time she attempted to use it.
 "It was such a mess," Ms. Brunner, 33, said. "They've swallowed up numerous banks over the last decade, so you'd think they'd have it down to a science."
 She has since switched to a local bank with only eight branches. "I was sick of large banks," she said.
 Bank of America and Fleet are already working to reassure retail customers. They say the combination of the two banks, which have very little geographic overlap, will create what the two companies bill as the nation's most extensive banking network for consumers, with 5,700 branches and 16,500 ATM's.
 "We can make the case that the Fleet Boston customer gets access to unparalleled convenience and a broad overlay of products," said Kenneth D. Lewis, Bank of America's chairman and chief executive. "We're not really worried about attrition."
 Tracey Mills, a spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association, says that consolidation can improve customer service, and encourage other banks to do the same. "Competition really heats up around a merger," she said, particularly competition from community banks. "Community banks can jump on the opportunity to make changes."
 Commerce Bancorp, a regional bank based in Cherry Hill, N.J., has courted customers after other banks' acquisitions, particularly Fleet's. "It's hard to get people to switch banks, but when their bank is sold, that gives them a reason," said Vernon Hill II, Commerce's chairman. "Every one of these major mergers has caused major disruptions to the customers."
 In a Gallup poll sponsored by the American Banker, a trade publication, 54 percent of consumers surveyed in 2001 said that they were displeased with the service they received after their banks merged with other banks.
 The Federal Reserve's most recent annual report on banks' consumer fees suggested at least one reason for this. "As in previous years, many of the fees charged by multistate banks were found to be significantly higher than those charged by single-state banks," the Fed report said.
 Edmund Mierzwinski, consumer program director for the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, said his organization had consistently found the same thing. "Bigger banks charge bigger fees," he said.
 "If you don't have competition and choice, then the powerful companies remaining don't have to do as good a job," he said, predicting that "further consolidation of the banking system is going to result in higher fees, less competition and I think poorer service in the long run."
 Fleet's acquisition of Bank Boston in 1999 was especially plagued with problems and analysts said the bank lost many customers. Jason P. Brinton of Cambridge, Mass., was a customer of Bank Boston for two years before Fleet bought it. After returning from a year of studying abroad, he said he was surprised to find that his terms had worsened: "I had opened an account that did not involve monthly fees, and came back to an account that did." Mr. Brinton, a medical student at Harvard, switched to Wells Fargo. 
 Fritz Elmendorf, a spokesman for the Consumer Bankers Association, said, "Something that may be worth noting is that banks have learned a lot of lessons from mergers, and one of them is not to rush things." 
 "I think both Bank of America and Fleet have been through enough mergers to have learned that particular lesson," he said.
 Christine and David Hogan of Rio Rancho, N.M., were customers of Sunwest in Albuquerque, N.M. , a community bank, but eventually became Bank of America customers in 1998 through a series of acquisitions. "I liked Sunwest," said Ms. Hogan, who is 41 and a manufacturing technician for Intel. "It was more accessible, more friendly."
 She added that Bank of America has mixed up payments they sent to pay off two loans. At one point, it issued their teenage son an ATM card that deducted money from someone else's account.
 Analysts point to Bank of America's buildup in bank branches as a sign of its commitment to serving consumers. It is adding 550 branches nationwide in the next three years and said yesterday that it planned to go ahead with that expansion.
 It is also trying to make the new branches more inviting than traditional banks. Rather than sitting behind desks, employees greet customers at the door or chat with them on the floor. Customers can help themselves to free coffee and read or watch financial news in a seating area. In addition, all of the branches' fixtures can be cleared to make floor space for after-hours homebuyer seminars or financial classes.

HEADLINE: Miami Caught in Free Trade Quandary 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: MIAMI 

 BODY:
This city seems uniquely qualified to be selected as the diplomatic headquarters of the Free Trade Area of the Americas, the long-awaited agreement on lowering tariffs throughout the hemisphere. What other place can boast of superior air connections, physical proximity, cultural and linguistic ties and a history of strong commercial relations with Latin America?
 Unfortunately for Miami, the selection process that was supposed to make it a shoo-in for the headquarters, a prize worth an anticipated $500 million a year in economic activity and an estimated 15,000 jobs for diplomats, trade negotiators, lawyers, bankers and other white-collar professionals, has become fraught with uncertainty. 
 There is, to begin with, the concern that the trade agreement might not even materialize, or be diminished in scope because of quarreling between negotiators from the United States and the hemisphere's second-largest economy, Brazil.
 The two countries are at odds over import tariffs the United States imposes to protect two industries that are important to Florida, citrus and sugar. That puts Miami in the sticky position of competing to become the headquarters of free trade in the Western Hemisphere at the same time that Florida is lobbying to protect tariffs that inhibit free trade. 
 Compounding Miami's anxiety is increased competition with Atlanta, which has started a well-financed and sophisticated campaign to present itself as an alternate gateway to the region. As Eduardo Gamarra, director of the Latin American and Caribbean Center at Florida International University, put it: "We've woken up from the slumber we were in for the last few years to realize our chances of getting this thing are really in jeopardy. Imagine the shock if the best candidate for the secretariat walks away with nothing."
 Few states have their destinies more dependent on the outcome of the trade agreement than Florida, so such sentiment explains the obsession here with scrutinizing efforts to convince 34 nations in the Western Hemisphere that Miami should be chosen as the headquarters of the trading area, which is scheduled to take effect in January 2005. 
 Studies show the headquarters could create substantial economic benefits for Miami and surrounding areas in South Florida, but the state's large citrus and sugar industries are leading efforts to water down the agreement by supporting existing tariffs on imported oranges and sugar from Brazil, the nation that is already Florida's largest international trading partner. 
 Although the tariffs are among the main obstacles to smoother negotiations with Brazil, Florida's agricultural companies appear to be unyielding in their resistance to the agreement. A group of Florida citrus growers even started television ads this month showing Jon Gruden, the head coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers football team, speaking in support of a 28.7 cents-per-gallon tariff on imported orange juice from Brazil.
 "Losing the tariff would devastate Florida's orange juice industry and thousands of family businesses throughout the state," Mr. Gruden says in the ads. "It that happens, we all lose." 
 The state's competing interests have put Gov. Jeb Bush in a difficult situation. Mr. Bush, who speaks Spanish fluently, has repeatedly said that he wants Miami to win the headquarters and is expected to play an active role in building support in Latin America for the bid. But Mr. Bush also supports the citrus industry's policies, and that support does not sit well with Brazil. 
 "I am afraid, Mr. Governor, that you have apparently been seriously misinformed by your staff on this issue," Rubens A. Barbosa, Brazil's ambassador in Washington, wrote in an unusually contentious letter to Mr. Bush in September. In the letter, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, Mr. Barbosa called Florida's tariffs illegal, discriminatory and protectionist. 
 Within this context, it is no surprise that those involved in preparing for next month's trade negotiations in Miami, an event considered by many a trial-run for the city's headquarters bid, are somewhat tense. Security officials are girding for the antiglobalization protests that accompany such events. Other officials are quietly bemoaning the tension between American and Brazilian negotiators since the breakdown of World Trade Organization talks in Cancun, Mexico, last month largely because of different views on agricultural subsidies.
 Brazil's position on these issues appears to have remained unyielding since Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, recently signaled that the United States could pursue a series of free trade agreements that would leave Brazil on the margins of an Americas-wide agreement. Some diplomats and analysts question whether a headquarters would even be necessary if the trade agreement is watered down. 
 "The competition for a headquarters is not even on our radar screen," said Marcos Troyjo, a diplomat on leave from Brazil's foreign affairs ministry and professor of business diplomacy at the University of Sao Paulo. "People in Brazil are a little fed up with the inconsistencies on free trade coming from the United States."
 If such blustery sentiments were not enough, Miami is also grappling with competition from Atlanta, which has a well-organized campaign reminiscent of its effort to get the Olympics in 1996, as well as several cities outside the United States, including Panama City; Puebla, Mexico; and Port-of-Spain, Trinidad. Other cities, including Houston, New Orleans, and Cancun, Mexico, have not yet said they will compete but have signaled they may do so.
 Hence the growing focus on Miami's chief lobbyist for building support for its bid, Jorge Arrizurieta, a former business associate of H. Wayne Huizenga, the founder of Blockbuster, former owner of the Florida Marlins baseball team and Bush administration appointee at the Inter-American Development Bank. Mr. Arrizurieta's lobbying efforts are intensifying ahead of talks scheduled next month in Miami, on Nov. 20 and 21, among trade ministers from every country in the hemisphere except Cuba, which is not participating in the accord. Cities are required to submit their bids for the headquarters before those talks begin.
 Since July, Mr. Arrizurieta, 37, a Florida-born Cuban-American, has traveled to 12 countries in Latin America and the Caribbean. He recently returned from Port-of-Spain with an editorial from that country's leading newspaper bemoaning a recent increase in kidnappings of business executives. "That's not the kind of publicity you want," he said.
 Still, if its seems like Mr. Arrizurieta (pronounced ah-REE-zuh-ree-ay-tah) is maintaining a busy traveling schedule, his counterpart in Atlanta, Jose Ignacio Gonzalez, is just as frenzied. Mr. Gonzalez, a Colombian emigre and president of Hemisphere Inc., a nonprofit group that is lobbying for Atlanta, has already met with heads of state and trade ministers in every country in South America, including relatively small nations like Guyana and Suriname.
 Mr. Gonzalez and Mr. Arrizurieta crossed paths as they met with the president of Uruguay, Jorge Batlle, and other government representatives on the same day in late August in Montevideo, the Uruguayan capital. Though they did not see each other, they heard of each other's movements from the officials they were meeting with, both men said.
 (Mr. Batlle later endorsed Miami's bid, becoming the first government leader in the region to publicly side with any city, even though it is ultimately the Uruguayan trade minister who will put forward his position in a consensus process involving negotiators from throughout the region.)
 Mr. Gonzalez, the Atlanta envoy, has taken a different approach from Mr. Arrizurieta's by declining to discuss the negative attributes of his competitors in favor of promoting Atlanta's advantages. "Initially," he said in an interview, "Atlanta might not seem like the most obvious choice but we bring the most to the table economically, culturally and historically."
 Atlanta, buoyed by support from local and state political leaders, appears to be doing fairly well in increasing visibility for its bid. Earlier this month, for example, ministers from five Andean countries -- Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia, Peru and Venezuela -- met in Atlanta to discuss preparations for next month's talks in Miami. While in Georgia, they dined with former President Jimmy Carter and met with executives from large Atlanta companies.
 In promoting Atlanta, Mr. Gonzalez emphasizes the roster of companies that are based in the city and have extensive operations in Latin America, including Coca-Cola, Delta Airlines, BellSouth and CNN, a unit of Time Warner. He also cites demographic figures showing that Atlanta has the fastest-growing Latino community in the nation in the last two years.
Georgia's overall Latino population grows by about 102 people a day, Mr. Gonzalez said, making Atlanta and the rest of the state a more important player in Latin American affairs. Hearing Atlanta position itself in such a way has irritated many in Miami, including Mr. Arrizurieta.
 "We're the indisputable gateway to the Americas," Mr. Arrizurieta said, adding that he bristled upon seeing that exact phrase, "Gateway to the Americas," as part of an extensive advertising insert purchased by Atlanta recently in the magazine Latin Trade to win support for its bid. "That really got to me," Mr. Arrizurieta said, speaking in clear English occasionally punctuated by expressions in rapid-fire, Cuban-accented Spanish.
 If negotiators find a way to surmount their differences on agricultural tariffs, Miami will have many supporters for its bid, including at least one prominent company based in Atlanta, United Parcel Service, which publicly sided with Miami after investing $30 million to make the city the center of its cargo shipping operations in Latin America. 
 Several diplomats from Latin American countries also quietly acknowledged they would prefer to have the headquarters in a familiar city in the United States, like Miami, if only because it would be easy to get there and because they would be paid in a relatively stable currency, the dollar. Miami's status as an offshore banking location and magnet for real-estate investments for wealthy Latin Americans add to its allure.
 Miami also remains a leading destination for former heads of state in Latin America, such as Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, who moved here this month after resigning as president of Bolivia amid growing protests there over natural gas exporting policies.
 "Everyone knows why it makes sense to choose Miami," Mr. Arrizurieta said. "It's a matter of not letting our strengths get lost in the fog of a complicated and sometimes contentious process."

HEADLINE: Drug Profits and the Free Market 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 William Safire (column, Oct. 27) discusses how to reverse the pressure to import our own medicines, which are sold more cheaply in Canada and overseas. 
Increasing export prices or decreasing supply to these places makes sense. 
 But we should not assume that the cost of research and development is the engine that drives price inflation. Many medications in a given class are duplicates of each other, and millions of dollars of drug research money are spent creating new competing chemicals only slightly different from already effective medicines.
These products become new billion-dollar drugs with the help of lavish advertising campaigns. In fact, direct-to-consumer ads are permitted in only the United States and New Zealand.

MARC SIEGEL, M.D.
New York, Oct. 27, 2003

The writer is a clinical associate professor of medicine, New York University Medical School.
