HEADLINE: Tax Changes May Slow Export Tide From China 

BYLINE:  By CHRIS BUCKLEY 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
China's juggernaut export growth has continued to defy a chorus of complaints from American manufacturers and politicians, but perhaps changes coming in China's tax rules will take a bit of the momentum away.
 The changes, which take effect on Jan. 1, cut the rebates on tax payments that businesses can claim for goods sold abroad and may raise the price of many Chinese-made consumer goods, including clothes, toys and electrical appliances. 
 No one thinks that the cuts will halt China's prodigious trade growth, but many economists foresee a palpable slowing of that growth, especially among low-end manufactured goods. Export businesses in fiercely competitive industries said that the cuts might erase already thin profit margins and imperil smaller manufacturers that are short of cash. 
 This, it seems, is the price China's government is willing to pay to defuse financial and international political strains unleashed by the country's trade boom.
 "The export rebate cuts in effect amount to a revaluation of the yuan," China's currency, said Zhang Shuguang, director of the Unirule Institute, a private economics research center in Beijing. "It will raise the price of exports without a formal revaluation. By how much is a difficult question, but there's sure to be ramifications."
 For Shen Chaohui, a manager of Galanz Electronics in Guangdong province, the potential consequences were clear as soon as he began calling customers in Europe, Latin America and the United States to say the price of the company's microwave ovens may rise by 4 percent.
 "It's going to have a big impact on us," he said in a telephone interview. "The microwave market is extremely price-sensitive, and any rise in our prices is going to be a plus to our foreign competitors, like LG," he added, referring to the South Korean electronics manufacturer.
 The export tax rebate for microwave ovens, Galanz's mainstay, as well as other domestic appliances like irons and air-conditioners, will fall from 17 percent to 13 percent of the declared value of goods from the start of next year.
 "We're asking customers to get ready for the price hike, but about 90 percent of the ones I've contacted so far can't understand it," Mr. Shen said. "I'm worried orders may start going to other manufacturers." He explained that most of Galanz's overseas orders are what is known as O.E.M. -- original equipment manufacturer -- deals involving Galanz filling orders that are sold under another electronics company's brand name.
 Galanz's difficulties may be repeated across several other industries where export rebates have underwritten China's exports in fiercely contested international markets. Rebates for garments and textiles will also fall by four percentage points; and rebates for metals, raw chemicals, plastics, toys, shoes, watches, ceramics, nylon and rubber products, sporting goods, leather shoes, and travel goods and bags will fall by two percentage points. Tax rebates on crude oil and oil products except gasoline were removed altogether.
 In some manufacturing sectors where government wants to encourage exports, like car parts, the level of rebates remains unchanged.
 The cuts seem small, but may make a significant difference in industries where profit margins are also small. "Most of our import partners have very tight profit margins," Mr. Shen said. "But we can't absorb the rise on our own because our gross profit on exports might not be that high."
 Galanz had set itself a target of raising its exports of microwave ovens to the United States to 3 million next year from 2 million this year, Mr. Shen said. But now the company will reduce its growth target by several hundred thousand, he added.
 Economists and businesses are uncertain how much China's trade growth would be clipped by the tax rebate adjustment. Long Guoqiang, who studies trade issues for the government's Research Development Center, calculated that every one percentage point drop in rebates would lead to a proportional drop in trade in the industry affected. His estimate is supported by government estimates cited in the Chinese press and by several other professional economists.
 Part of the drop in rebates could be absorbed by exporters' domestic suppliers, economists and managers said. But in sectors where profits are squeezed by competition and production overcapacity, exporters may have little choice but to pass on the costs to buyers, which may diminish China's competitiveness.
 "Much of China's export sector is huge volume, but low profitability," said Andy Xie, who analyzes China's economy for Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong. "China's exporters don't have much power. They're O.E.M. manufacturers, and they're highly exposed."
 He added that he expected the rebate cuts to have "serious effects" for China's export performance, contributing to a fall in export growth from this year's 30 percent to about 15 percent next year.
 The export rebate program is a victim of China's soaring trade success. In recent years, as China's exports have boomed, the government has found itself short of cash to pay for a growing mountain of rebate claims -- another possible reason for the reduction in rebates. By the end of last year, the government owed $30 billion in unpaid claims, and with exports set to grow by a third this year, the government may owe another $6 billion by the end of this year.
 For many enterprises, the logjam of unpaid claims has become a major headache.
 "In the past few years, unpaid claims have piled up," said Mr. Xuan, a representative from the Guangdong Textile Manufacturers Association, who declined to give his full name. "It's become a real serious pressure on our business."
 Mr. Xuan, however, said he believed that China's textile exports to the United States and other major buyers would not be drastically cut.
 "Even with the rebate cut, China's cheapness is still a strong advantage," he said. "Some smaller businesses may be in difficulty, but China's overall advantage still exists."

HEADLINE: Drug Profits and the Free Market 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The Doughnut's Hole," by William Safire (column, Oct. 27): 
 It is not the free market that causes drug prices to be high in the United States, it is patent protection -- a government-granted monopoly. 
While research and innovation must be financed somehow, there is no evidence that patent monopolies are an efficient mechanism for this purpose. 
Nearly half of all biomedical research is currently financed by the government and the nonprofit sector. My research suggests that it would be far more efficient if the government simply picked up the tab for the rest and stopped trying to enforce patent monopolies.
With all drugs then sold in a free market, there would be enormous gains for everyone, except the pharmaceutical industry.

DEAN BAKER
Co-Director, Center for Economic
and Policy Research
Washington, Oct. 27, 2003

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Declined in September 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
Sales of new homes edged down in September, the Commerce Department reported on Monday, but they nevertheless registered the third-highest level on record.
 A separate report from a trade group showed that sales of previously owned homes again had their best month -- fresh evidence that the housing market continues to help spur economic recovery. 
 The Commerce Department put new-home sales at a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.145 million in September, a 0.2 percent dip from the previous month. Even with that, sales were stronger than the 1.125 million pace that analysts were forecasting. New-home sales posted their best month ever in June, at a pace of 1.2 million units, and their second-best month in August, at an annual pace of 1.147 million.
 In the other report, the National Association of Realtors said that existing-home sales rose 3.6 percent in September, to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 6.69 million units,the third consecutive record month.
 By region, new-home sales in September soared by 26 percent in the Northeast, to an annual pace of 97,000, and in the West they rose 12.4 percent, to a pace of 335,000. But in the Midwest, sales fell 18 percent, to a pace of 209,000, and in the South, they dipped 2.5 percent, to a 504,000-unit pace.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Move Up Amid Acquisitions in Banking and Health

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday as companies announced $62.9 billion worth of takeovers, persuading investors that share prices are inexpensive even after a 29 percent surge in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since mid-March.
 FleetBoston Financial soared after agreeing to be bought by Bank of America, while the health insurers WellPoint Health Networks and Mid Atlantic Medical Services jumped after announcing plans to sell themselves. 
 The acquirers "feel they are buying them at attractive enough prices today that they will still be able to make money longer term," said Martha Pomerantz, who helps oversee $5 billion at Lowry Hill Investment Advisors in Minneapolis. "It is a huge positive." Lowry Hill's clients own shares of Bank of America and UnitedHealth Group, which acquired Mid Atlantic Medical. 
 The S.&P. 500 increased 2.22 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,031.13. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 25.70 points, or 0.3 percent, to 9,608.16. The Nasdaq composite index added 17.32 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,882.91, for its first increase in four days.
 The S.&P. 500 has jumped since this year's low on March 11 amid speculation that cost cuts and an improving economy will accelerate corporate profit growth.
 Two stocks rose for every one that fell yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. About 1.36 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board, 3.2 percent more than the three-month daily average.
 FleetBoston rallied $7.40, to $39.20, for the biggest gain in the S.&P. 500. Bank of America fell $8.29, to $73.57, for the steepest drop. The $43.6 billion purchase would be the largest banking takeover ever.
 Regional bank shares gained on speculation that there will be more acquisitions. The S.&P. 500 Regional Banks Index rose 2.2 percent, led by SunTrust Banks, which advanced $3.72, to $67.22. PNC Financial Services Group, Pennsylvania's biggest bank, climbed $1.96, to $52.75. KeyCorp added 80 cents, to $27.69. Sovereign Bancorp jumped $1.04, to $20.07. Comerica rose $3.25, to $50.17.
 Investment banks and brokerage firms also rose amid optimism that mergers would help lift profit. The S.&P. 500 investment banking and brokerage index climbed 1.3 percent. The Goldman Sachs Group added $2.37, to $88.19, and Morgan Stanley advanced 34 cents, to $51.78. Merrill Lynch gained 67 cents, to $56.15.
 WellPoint rallied $7.16, to $91.09, for the second-biggest increase in the S.&P. 500. The company agreed to sell itself to Anthem for $16.4 billion to create the country's largest health insurer. Anthem fell $6.21, to $71.05.
 Mid Atlantic Medical rose $5.74, to $59.62 after the company agreed to sell itself to the UnitedHealth Group for $2.9 billion. The transaction values Mid Atlantic at $60.97, 13 percent more than Friday's price. UnitedHealth fell $1.85, to $52.40.
 "We used to talk about merger Mondays, back when the market was in its glory days," said Eric Thorne, who helps oversee $1.7 billion at Bryn Mawr Trust Co. "It hasn't happened in a while, but I wouldn't be surprised so see more. They tend to feed on themselves."
 In bond trading, Treasuries fell in New York yesterday on speculation that Federal Reserve policy makers will acknowledge the economy is improving at a meeting today, bringing them closer to raising their benchmark interest rate. 
 Signs that growth may be strengthening, including reports yesterday showing gains in home sales, come as the government needs to sell more debt to finance a record budget deficit. A sale of $26 billion of two-year notes tomorrow may add to the rise in Treasury yields, which move opposite of price.
 By late in the day, the benchmark 10-year note lost 7/32, dropping to a price of 99 29/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, climbed to 4.26 percent from 4.23 percent on Friday.

PERSON: Raffaele De Ritis 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Creating the Spirit of Carnival in a Tent

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
LET there be light. (Raffaele De Ritis is striding through sawdust and shouting "Lights!") Let there be music. (Now he's shouting "Rob," and Rob Slowik is the musical director.) Let there be action. (Not just from 27 performers, but also 4 camels, 6 horses, 8 dogs and one llama.)
 During this rehearsal under the little top of the Big Apple Circus, Mr. De Ritis rules man and beast. A 36-year-old Italian director, he has created circuses, festivals, operas and magic shows in Europe, and was imported to take charge of Big Apple's new production, "Carnevale!" It opens to the public tonight in the clowny blue one-ring tent in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. 
 Not that this is Mr. De Ritis's first one-ring show in Manhattan. In December 2000, the high-end, $10 million Barnum's Kaleidoscape arrived in Bryant Park, right during the traditional holiday run of the spunky, Manhattan-born Big Apple. Working in Sarasota, Fla., Mr. De Ritis had been Kaleidoscape's highly praised creator. 
If Kaleidoscape subsequently folded its tent for good, Big Apple is still going strong -- and now it has Mr. De Ritis. "I'm not gloating," said Paul Binder, founder and artistic director of Big Apple, "because in this business you can never get a big head. It's a humbling trade. We're just proud to be here for our 26th year."
The show -- billed as a celebration of the carnival spirit of Venice, Rio de Janeiro, Trinidad, Cuba, New Orleans and Jamaica -- is, Mr. Binder said, "the most fast-paced and energetic show we've ever done."
Mr. Binder invited Mr. De Ritis in "for his fresh eye, his immersion in the European milieu and for his depth of knowledge about circus," Mr. Binder said.
Mr. De Ritis reveres the very idea of carnival "because, I think, it is my first memory of any performance, even before circus," he recalled. About that first circus: he was age 3 in his hometown, Pescara, in Abruzzi. "My parents never suspected the course they were setting me on," he said. "People don't realize that the first live paid entertainment that most kids will see, anywhere in the world, is a circus." 
If he is an authoritative director, Mr. De Ritis also shows deference to the cast. "Lots of performers know me since I was a kid," he explains. That is because, even at age 10, he would hang out with circus folk whenever one of the many traveling one-ring Italian shows came to town. At age 12 he was doing publicity and ringside work during school holidays for touring circuses; at 17 he began writing for Italian circus magazines, a practice he continues.
By 18 he had become a circus talent scout in France, Austria, Switzerland and Scandinavia. Not long after, he became the unpaid assistant to the director Jerome Savary in Paris at the Theatre National de Chaillot. (Mr. De Ritis made ends meet by doing Italian-circus publicity and helping a crocodile-hypnotist at the Moulin Rouge load up his circus truck.)
In his mid-20's, he started staging European circus festivals ("45 acts thrown together in four days," he remembered). He is a fierce networker, and his resume is a name-dropper's list of circus greats with whom he has studied or collaborated in Italy, Paris, Moscow and Montreal. 
In 1999, Gian Carlo Menotti asked him to create a magic show for the Spoleto Festival in Italy; ditto for Prince Rainier in Monte Carlo. Now he is at the leading edge of a new wave of naturalistic circus directors in France and Italy. 
AFTER "Carnevale!" Mr. De Ritis will rest for a bit at his house in Pescara, "where I have my circus archive," he said in his precise, slightly accented English, one of three languages he ordinarily uses (Italian and French are the others). "I also work in German, Spanish and Russian, not to mention the animal languages," he said, deadpan.
In Pescara, he will tackle two books: an Italian history of magic and entertainment, and a social history of world circus. He is also writing magic and circus specials for Italian television. 
Erudite and often academic in conversation, the aerialist-thin Mr. De Ritis strolls the practice ring with erect carriage and noble bearing, a clear contrast to the pratfally casualness of the cast and crew. 
In fact, his name has descended from noble origins, but the director is hardly to the manner born. "I live from project to project," he said, "and I try not to think about paying the bills. It is, after all, a gift to love what you do."
Unlike many of the performers he is working with, he does not derive from a multigenerational circus family; his father, Domenica, is a government specialist in pension economics. 
Inevitably, any Italian director must refer to Federico Fellini, and Mr. De Ritis does not disappoint, terming him "an inspirational figure." Mr. De Ritis met Mr. Fellini, the director of "La Dolce Vita," the year before his death, over espresso in Rome. " 'You are lucky, I am not,' " Mr. Fellini told him, Mr. De Ritis recalled. " 'You direct circus, I direct movies. In movies, I lie. But in circus, you tell the truth.' " 
In describing his working aesthetic, Mr. De Ritis resorts to quotation. "Picasso said, 'Je ne cherche pas, je trouve' " ("I don't look for things, I find them"). "That seems right. In circus, I don't look for things. They just emerge from under the sawdust."

GRAPHIC: Photo: RAFFAELE DE RITIS (Photo by Carol Halebian for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Willful Ignorance 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
According to The New York Times, President Bush was genuinely surprised to learn from moderate Islamic leaders that they had become deeply distrustful of American intentions. The report on the "perception gap" suggests that the leader of the war on terror has no idea how badly that war -- which must, ultimately, be a war for hearts and minds -- is going.
 Mr. Bush's ignorance may reflect his lack of curiosity: "The best way to get the news," he says, "is from objective sources. And the most objective sources I have are people on my staff." Two words: emperor, clothes. 
 But there's something broader going on: a sort of willful ignorance, supposedly driven by moral concerns but actually reflecting domestic politics. Surely it's important to understand how others see us, but a new, post 9/11 version of political correctness has made it difficult even to discuss their points of view. Any American who tries to go beyond "America good, terrorists evil," who tries to understand -- not condone -- the growing world backlash against the United States, faces furious attacks delivered in a tone of high moral indignation. The attackers claim to be standing up for moral clarity, and some of them may even believe it. But they are really being used in a domestic political struggle.
Last week I found myself caught up in that struggle. I wrote about why Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysia's prime minister -- a clever if loathsome man who adjusts the volume of his anti-Semitism depending on circumstances -- chose to include an anti-Jewish diatribe in his speech to an Islamic conference. Sure enough, I was accused in various places not just of "tolerance for anti-Semitism" (yes, I'm Jewish) but of being in Mr. Mahathir's pay. Smear tactics aside, the thrust of the attacks was that because anti-Semitism is evil, anyone who tries to understand why politicians foment anti-Semitism -- and looks for ways other than military force to combat the disease -- is an apologist for anti-Semitism and is complicit in evil.
Yet that moral punctiliousness is curiously selective. Last year the Bush administration, in return for a military base in Uzbekistan, gave $500 million to a government that, according to the State Department, uses torture "as a routine investigation technique," and whose president has killed opponents with boiling water. The moral clarity police were notably quiet.
Why is aiding a brutal dictator O.K., while trying to understand why others don't trust us -- and doing something to create that trust -- isn't? Why won't the administration mollify Muslims by firing Lt. Gen. William Boykin, whose anti-Islamic remarks have created vast ill will, from his counterterrorism position? Why won't it give moderate Muslims a better argument against the radicals by opposing Ariel Sharon's settlement policy, when a majority of Israelis think that some settlements should be abandoned, and even Israeli military officers have become bitterly critical of Mr. Sharon?
The answer is that in these cases politics takes priority over the war on terror. Moderate Muslims would have more faith in America's good intentions if there were at least the appearance of a distinction between the U.S. and the Sharon government -- but the administration seeks votes from those who think that supporting Israel means supporting whatever Mr. Sharon does. It's sheer folly to keep General Boykin in his present position, but as Howard Fineman writes in a Newsweek Web-exclusive column, the administration doesn't want "to make a martyr of a man who depicts himself as a Christian Soldier, marching off to war."
Muslims are completely wrong to think that the U.S. is engaged in a war against Islam. But that misperception flourishes in part because the domestic political strategy of the Bush administration -- no longer able to claim the Iraq war was a triumph, and with little but red ink to show for its economic plans -- looks more and more like a crusade. "Election Boils Down to a Culture War" was the title of Mr. Fineman's column. But the analysis was all about abortion and euthanasia, and now we hear that opposition to gay marriage will be a major campaign theme. This isn't a culture war -- it's a religious war. 
Which brings me back to my starting point: we'll lose the fight against terror if we don't make an effort to understand how others think. Yet because of a domestic political struggle that seems ever more centered on religion, such attempts at understanding are shouted down.

HEADLINE: Tom Ford and the Showdown at the Gucci Corral 

BYLINE:  By CATHY HORYN

 BODY:
Tom Ford is that rare designer whose collections for Gucci are monitored by both fashion mavens and Wall Street analysts. In just 10 years, he and Gucci's chief executive, Domenico De Sole, turned a moribund label with revenues of $200 million into a $3 billion luxury conglomerate, making investors rich and the tirelessly chic happy.
 But in a drama that has riveted the attention of fashion followers from Madison Avenue to the trading desks of New York and London, Mr. Ford, 42, and Mr. De Sole, 59, now find themselves in a battle with Gucci's biggest shareholder over who should control the company. Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, which owns 68 percent of Gucci and has pledged to buy the rest by next spring, insists on exerting management control. 
 Mr. De Sole and Mr. Ford say that is not acceptable and might force them to leave. It is the main sticking point in their contract-renewal negotiations with P.P.R., which have entered an end game. A resolution is expected within weeks. 
In an interview last week in New York, Mr. De Sole declined to comment on the negotiations, but he indicated that he and Mr. Ford, after all they have done for Gucci, should retain managerial independence from P.P.R., which is based in Paris and controlled by the French tycoon Francois Pinault. Mr. De Sole noted that following the release on Oct. 15 of strong fall sales figures by Gucci and its Yves Saint Laurent subsidiary, Gucci Group's share price had rallied in heavy trading in Europe. More than one million shares were traded daily at the end of that week, about five times the average volume. 
"It's rekindled a lot of interest in investors to come back to the company," Mr. De Sole said. "They made a lot of money with Tom and I. They trust us."
A spokesman for P.P.R., Thomas Kamm, declined to comment on the contract negotiations or on several analyst reports that said Gucci shares are undervalued.
If Mr. De Sole and Mr. Ford decide to leave Gucci when their contracts expire next March and next June -- and there is little chance that one would stay without the other, given their loyalties -- it will send reverberations throughout the fashion industry. Among those likely to be affected are Gucci's struggling subsidiary brands, including Saint Laurent, Alexander McQueen and Stella McCartney.
"It would be a catastrophe," said Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, who during the most recent round of shows in Paris met with both men as well as with Mr. Pinault. Though magazines like Vogue depend on Gucci advertising dollars, the loss of Mr. Ford would also rob editors of the star power they need to whip up reader interest. Michael Roberts, the fashion editor of The New Yorker, said: "He means a huge amount in terms of presenting an image of fashion to the public. You take him out of the equation and you're left with a big hole."
Indeed, the drama at Gucci points up a serious shortcoming in the fashion world: a dearth of creative talent that can excite consumers. In the last three years, houses like Givenchy, Jil Sander and Bill Blass have struggled to find a new identity by replacing designers -- only to discover, after losing money and credibility, thatthe missing factor was a real talent. Calvin Klein is the latest brand to set off down this road, replacing Mr. Klein with a former assistant, whose first collection in September received mixed reviews from retailers.
And executives at stores like Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus worry about who will one day replace older stars like Giorgio Armani, 69, and Oscar de la Renta, 71, who generate significant revenues.
"This goes way beyond Tom Ford," said the chief executive of an American department store. "Believe me, if Tom decides to leave and retire to his ranch, Gucci will go on. Because the brand is much greater than the man. But who's going to replace him?"
Mr. Pinault, a self-made businessman who parlayed a sawmill into a conglomerate, told The Wall Street Journal earlier this year that he would like Mr. De Sole and Mr. Ford to stay, but that Gucci "shouldn't shake in its boots" at the thought of them leaving. At the end of Mr. Ford's Saint Laurent show on Oct. 12, Mr. Pinault, accompanied by Bernadette Chirac, the wife of France's president, made a symbolic gesture of planting two kisses on the designer's cheeks.
Both Mr. Ford and Mr. De Sole let it be known to close associates in the days before the Saint Laurent show that contract talks had hit a rough patch, fueling speculation among journalists and retailers at the spring 2004 collections that a defection by the pair looked more and more possible. Yet on the morning of Oct. 12, when Mr. De Sole was observed having breakfast with Ms. Wintour at the Ritz Hotel, he seemed again hopeful, saying that he had received a late-night phone call from P.P.R. summoning him to a round of discussions that afternoon.
What may further complicate negotiations is Gucci's recent stock gains, and Mr. De Sole's forecast of more robust earnings for the second half of the year. Two years ago, when Mr. Pinault emerged as the white knight in a nasty battle with rival LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton for control of Gucci, he agreed to buy out minority shareholders for $101.50 a share by next April. That guarantee, a put option, was cut to $85.52 earlier this year when the Gucci Group paid its shareholders a $1.58 billion dividend. Thanks to recent gains of Gucci stock, its shares now sell above the put price, meaning investors will not have reason to trade in their shares. If Gucci remains a public company with independent directors, Mr. Ford's and Mr. De Sole's hand would be strengthened.
After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the global luxury industry faced a pernicious downturn. The confluence of a weak economy, a drop in worldwide tourism and fear of SARS effectively spiked the phenomenal profits that luxury brands saw in the 1990's, when free-spending consumers indulged themselves with $600 must-have bags and even pricier clothing. 
While companies like LVMH showed signs of a turnaround earlier this year, Gucci seemed to stall -- in part, Mr. De Sole acknowledged, because of a poorly received fall 2002 Gucci collection and problems related to new brands, including Saint Laurent, one of nine labels the company acquired in 2001.
In its first quarter of 2003, Gucci's net profit plunged 97 percent, followed by a drop of 47 percent for the second quarter that ended July 31. However, Mr. De Sole was able to offer some good news with the bad, reporting that since Aug. 1, retail sales for the Gucci label were up as much as 20 percent and that its Bottega Veneta division had seen a 42 percent increase. The results led Claire Kent, an analyst with Morgan Stanley in London, to issue a report in which she asserted that the $85.52 put option "greatly underestimates Gucci's true value" -- provided, she added, that current management stays in place.
"The intrinsic value of Gucci is difficult to evaluate if the current management leave," the report said.
Andrew Gowen, an analyst at Lehman Brothers in London, also expressed confidence in Mr. De Sole and Mr. Ford. "I would perceive it as a negative if they leave," he said. "They're a good management team. If it's not broken, why try to fix it?"
There is ample personal wealth on both sides of this latest battle for Gucci to suggest that money alone is not a motivation for going to the mattresses. Having spent $3 billion to help thwart a bid from LVMH, Mr. Pinault may feel more than justified in his desire to gain control of Gucci. Mr. De Sole, who had planned to retire last year, has run the company as if it were his own, and would probably like to finish his career on top.
Mr. Ford received more than $6 million in compensation last year, and in May earned nearly $38 million by cashing in stock options. This is in addition to the $144 million he made from options over the past three years. "He's such a well-known figure that he could find the money to start his own venture," said Christian Oddono, director of research at Actinvest, an equity research firm in London. 
Yet this scenario seems unlikely, and Mr. Ford's threat to leave Gucci may be only a way to gain leverage with Mr. Pinault. He has long said that he wants to spend more time within Gucci building a stable of young brands than designing collections. "Tom's game plan has been to move into a different role at Gucci," Ms. Wintour said. "I don't think he's wedded to being the design director. He could bring in someone else to design Gucci or Saint Laurent." So having his own label may not square with his broader ambitions.
Not everyone is convinced that Gucci and Mr. Ford are inseparable. One New York retailing executive, noting that Mr. Ford has presided over Gucci for more than a decade, said a fresh point of view would not be so bad.
And for now, his 90's formula of sex and swank seems a bit out of sync with the more soulful femininity being offered by designers like Miuccia Prada and Marc Jacobs. Though, like everything else in fashion, it is subject to change.
As Mr. Roberts said, "After one season of milkmaids and Daisy Buchanans, you can bet your bottom dollar that sex will be whizzing back. It's very difficult to sell lots of clothes without a sex quotient."

HEADLINE: BANKING GIANTS: THE OVERVIEW; 
BANK OF AMERICA AND FLEETBOSTON AGREE TO MERGER

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
Bank of America and FleetBoston Financial announced yesterday that they would combine to create a consumer banking giant with branches from Maine to California.
 Bank of America, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., but has a strong California franchise, will pay an estimated $48 billion in stock for FleetBoston's robust presence in the Northeast and for access to some of the wealthiest households in the country. Combined, the institution would be the nation's second-largest bank in assets and would control nearly 10 percent of the nation's deposits, the maximum that can be gained by acquisition. All told, it would have 5,700 branches in 29 states. 
 The announcement comes as Bank of America is being investigated for its role in a widening examination of improper trading in mutual fund shares. The bank recently fired several top executives, and one former broker faces criminal charges by the New York attorney general. The head of its asset management business with oversight of mutual funds was left without a job in the new organization. Page C1. 
For FleetBoston, itself the product of dozens of acquisitions, the deal ends an institution with roots in 18th-century New England and removes another corporate titan from Boston. The bank has been described as a takeover candidate since it incurred heavy losses after the merger of Fleet Financial and BankBoston in 1999. For customers of Fleet and its predecessors -- who have already changed hands many times -- the combination is sure to produce some anxiety about changes in fees, accounts and service.
 Bank of America's chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said yesterday that the addition of Fleet would make Bank of America "truly a national bank." 
 Still, the bank's stock fell sharply yesterday, as analysts questioned the cost of the deal.
 The acquisition, announced on the same day as other big deals in health care and tobacco, may suggest that corporations are beginning to take a more offensive posture after a quiet period for mergers amid corporate scandals and economic torpor. Mr. Lewis predicted that his acquisition would put pressure on other banks to combine, and stocks of several banks viewed as takeover candidates rose yesterday.
 The combination, which was reported yesterday in The Boston Globe, will bring together banks that are products of a dizzying list of deals. Each bank struggled to overcome unexpected losses after its last round of mergers -- Bank of America's approximately $60 billion merger with NationsBank in 1998, and Fleet Financial's combination with BankBoston for $16 billion.
 Bank of America, under the leadership of Mr. Lewis, reduced its exposure to corporate lending and shed risky businesses like subprime lending and auto leasing. FleetBoston, under it chief executive, Charles K. Gifford, also shifted its emphasis to consumer banking, reducing its exposure to Latin America and slashing the corporate loans on its books -- but not before suffering heavy losses in both areas.
 The combined institution will retain the Bank of America name and its headquarters in Charlotte, the former home of NationsBank. Mr. Lewis, 56, will be the new chief executive, and Mr. Gifford, 60, will become chairman and remain in Boston.
 Bank of America will control 12 of the 19 seats on the new board. Because the banks do not have much geographic overlap, regulatory and antitrust issues are not expected to pose significant problems.
 Mr. Gifford's tenure at FleetBoston was marred by losses. He became chief executive in 2001, having earlier been chief executive of BankBoston. From the beginning, he battled rumors that he was about to sell FleetBoston, as the promised turnaround was slow to materialize. "It is not our intention to sell the company," he said in an interview in March.
 Yesterday, he said that the lure of Bank of America was too hard to resist, although he admitted to feeling "a lot of emotion" about FleetBoston giving up its independence.
 The generous purchase price swayed his decision, according to people briefed on the negotiations. Under the terms of the deal, each FleetBoston share will be exchanged for 0.55 share of Bank of America. Based on Friday's closing prices, each Fleet share is worth $45 -- 40 percent more than before the deal was announced. That premium is the biggest among the top 20 bank deals of the last decade, according to SNL Financial.
 "We had no need whatsoever" to do a deal, said Eugene M. McQuade, president of FleetBoston, in an interview yesterday. FleetBoston's management would not have sold "unless shareholders had a substantial premium," he said.
 Mr. Lewis and Mr. Gifford first sat down a year and a half ago, according to executives briefed on the negotiations. Their talks about a merger began this spring, these executives said, and accelerated in late summer. Their No.2 executives, Mr. McQuade and James H. Hance Jr. of Bank of America, have summer homes near each other on Cape Cod and helped move discussions along. 
 FleetBoston was approached by other potential partners, Mr. Gifford said yesterday, although he declined to name them. Executives briefed on the conversations, though, said that the group included Citigroup, Wachovia and Bank One. Representatives of the banks declined to comment on their talks with FleetBoston.
 Bank of America already has a dominant position in consumer banking in the United States, and will gain specifically in the credit card and wealth management businesses. It will also gain a slight share in corporate banking. The combined institution will have relationships with 95 percent of the companies in the Fortune 500, up from 92 percent before the merger.
 Though the loss of FleetBoston's headquarters is a blow to Boston, Mr. Gifford said he was pleased that certain businesses -- including wealth management, Latin American lending, small-business lending and leasing -- would continue to be based there. He declined to comment on layoffs resulting from the merger. The banks have not yet identified the number of staff reductions, a FleetBoston spokesman said.
 The bank is projecting $1.1 billion in annual cost savings, or 6 percent of the expenses of the combined banks.
 Some stock analysts worried that the combination meant that Bank of America, an institution once known for its voracious appetite for big deals, was returning to that role. The last big one -- Bank of America and Nationsbank -- proved initially difficult because of unexpected trading losses and heavy write-downs ofcorporate loans.
 "Shareholders are angry, and feel that they have been betrayed," said Nancy Bush, an independent bank analyst based in Annandale, N.J. "There is rightly a lot of skepticism," given the high price, she said.
 For the near term, Mr. Lewis will be prohibited by law from doing another big banking deal. Assuming the merger with FleetBoston is completed, the bank will control 9.8 percent of the nation's deposits. Under United States banking law, banks cannot exceed 10 percent of deposits by acquisition, although they can gain share by attracting new customers.
One adviser to banks who insisted on anonymity said that the deal reflected Mr. Lewis's "driving ambition to be the equal of Citigroup," the nation's largest financial services company. The deal would edge Bank of America closer to Citigroup in size, with $933 billion in assets compared with $1.2 trillion for Citigroup. But it does little to enhance Bank of America's presence in areas like asset management and investment banking where Citigroup is far stronger.
 Bank of America's stock fell $8.29 a share yesterday, or about 10 percent, to $73.57, while FleetBoston's share price jumped $7.40, or 23 percent to $39.20. Based on those stock prices, the value of the deal had fallen yesterday to about $43 billion.
 Stock analysts debated whether the latest combination would lead to more bank deals. Stocks of banks with leading market shares in their regions -- including SunTrust of Atlanta, PNC Financial of Pittsburgh and National City of Cleveland -- rose yesterday. For those considered possible acquirers -- including Citigroup, Wachovia and Wells Fargo -- stocks fell as investors apparently fretted that those institutions might be tempted to spend too much to compete with the new Bank of America.
 An adviser to banks urged shareholders of those big institutions not to worry. "Nobody else would pay that much money," he said of the rich premium paid for FleetBoston.

HEADLINE: BANKING GIANT: THE CHIEF; 
Salesmanship Crucial for Executive as Critics Speak Out

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, has spent most of his working life selling things. Even so, after orchestrating his company's $48 billion purchase of FleetBoston Financial, he may be looking at the biggest sales job of his career -- persuading Wall Street and investors that the deal makes economic and strategic sense. 
 As a 12-year-old in Columbus, Ga., Mr. Lewis delivered newspapers. In high school he was a star salesman at Butler's shoe store in Columbus. And he logged some time as a fire insurance underwriter and an airline reservations agent when he was in college at Georgia State University in the late 1960's. 
 But the concept Mr. Lewis, 56, is now trying to peddle could be a tough sell, in large part because a megamerger like the FleetBoston deal is something Wall Street had assumed he was unlikely to do. 
 For one thing, it had looked as if it might take the balance of Mr. Lewis's career just to successfully integrate all the banks his immediate predecessor -- the larger-than-life Hugh L. McColl Jr. -- spent the better part of two decades accumulating. And it was an impression Mr. Lewis, who succeeded Mr. McColl in April 2001, did little to dispel.
 "We've stopped talking about how big we are," he told the newspaper American Banker last year. "We don't have to do that anymore." 
 Mr. McColl's string of deals transformed what was once the NCNB Corporation, a midsized North Carolina bank, into the super-regional NationsBank and finally into Bank of America, the nation's third-largest. 
 Over the last two years, Mr. Lewis has concentrated on tidying up the place, in part by cutting the bank's holdings of corporate loans in half and withdrawing from other volatile businesses, like subprime mortgages and auto leasing. He has expanded in areas with more predictable earnings, like consumer banking. 
 All the while, he has talked about generating what he called "organic" growth, meaning growth from within, not through acquisitions.
 Investors liked what they saw. 
 From a low of $36 in 2000, Bank of America's stock slowly but steadily moved higher. By the end of last week it was trading at just over $80 a share -- an impressive comeback, although still below the $89 price that the stock of what was then NationsBank hit just before Mr. McColl engineered the $61 billion purchase of Bank of America in April 1998. 
 On word of the FleetBoston deal yesterday, the stock posted its biggest one-day drop in almost five years, falling $8.29, or just over 10 percent, to $73.57. 
 At a news conference, Mr. Lewis played down the stock market's verdict.
 "I don't think anybody could do a deal at any price that investors would like in the short term," he said. "They are going to like this deal over time." 
 But analysts were plainly skeptical. 
 "This deal is about size and scale and all those things" that used to be associated with Mr. McColl, said Nancy A. Bush, who heads her own stock research firm in Annandale, N.J. "One of the reasons the stock is down 10 percent is because the world thought the model had changed. There is shock and dismay at work, and rightly so. He is going to have some proving to do." 
 Analysts say it is unlikely that Mr. Lewis -- who joined NCNB as a credit analyst out of Georgia State University in 1969 and has been with the company ever since -- is looking at the FleetBoston deal as a way to put himself in the same league as Mr. McColl. 
 "He is a very pragmatic guy," said Denis Laplante, a banking analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. 
 As an example of that pragmatism, Mr. Laplante pointed to the way Mr. Lewis has reacted to the New York attorney general's investigation of the mutual fund industry, which could lead to the filing of criminal and civil charges against some of its executives. 
 The announcement yesterday that Richard M. DeMartini, the head of Bank of America's asset management unit, would leave after the FleetBoston merger, means that all four Bank of America executives named in the investigation will have resigned since the scandal broke.
 "I have to give Ken Lewis credit for dealing with the problems forthrightly and bringing in people to try and deal with this," Mr. Laplante said. 
 But for now the FleetBoston deal appears to have undone a lot of the good will Mr. Lewis had been building up. Whether the ill will lasts may depend on his salesmanship.
 "Wall Street feels betrayed," Ms. Bush said. "But the memory of Wall Street is notoriously short. If this deal works out, nobody will remember that everybody dumped all over it when it was announced."

HEADLINE: Acquisition Would Create Nation's Largest Health Insurer 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
In a marriage of Blue Cross giants, Anthem Inc. agreed yesterday to buy WellPoint Health Networks for $16.4 billion in stock and cash, creating a company that would be the nation's largest health insurer, with 26 million health plan members in 13 states.
 Anthem and WellPoint were pioneers in converting Blue Cross plans into for-profit companies, but lately had met with resistance from state authorities who argued that such deals led to higher costs and thinner insurance coverage. Together, the companies account for more than 30 percent of the 84 million Blue Cross and Blue Shield members nationwide. 
 The combined company, to be called WellPoint Inc. and with headquarters in Indianapolis, would overtake UnitedHealth Group in size. Yesterday UnitedHealth announced a deal of its own, agreeing to buy Mid Atlantic Medical Services for $2.95 billion, also in cash and stock. That deal will add 2 million members on the East Coast to UnitedHealth's 18.3 million total. 
 The Anthem-WellPoint combination will go head-to-head with United for the business of big national employers, analysts said. The combined company will also pursue small businesses and uninsured people by offering lower-cost policies that shift a bigger share of the growing tab for health care to patients, analysts said. 
 Anthem, WellPoint and UnitedHealth became Wall Street favorites over the last few years by raising premiums faster than the inflation rate for hospital and doctor services. A traditional turnin the cycle, to lower insurance company profits, has taken longer than usual, said Joy Grossman, an economist at Center for Studying Health System Change, a nonprofit research center in Washington. 
 In trading Monday, WellPoint gained $7.16, or 8.5 percent, to close at $91.09. Anthem shares dropped $6.21, or 8 percent, to $71.05. The transaction values WellPoint at $101.60 per share, or 20 percent above Friday's closing stock price. WellPoint holders would trade their shares for one share each of Anthem plus $23.80 in cash.
 WellPoint's chief executive, Leonard D. Schaeffer, who created the company on the foundation of a successful turnaround of Blue Cross of California, will hand the reins to Larry Glasscock, Anthem's chief executive. Mr. Glasscock, 55, will be president and chief executive of the new company, and Mr. Schaeffer, 58, a former government health care official, will be chairman. 
 Mr. Schaeffer's WellPoint holdings -- 3.3 million shares, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing last month -- jumped in value by more than $70 million yesterday, to over $300 million. He would also receive $27.5 million under a change-of-control clause in his contract and about $10 million more in executive retirement benefits, according to the WellPoint proxy and other filings.
 Mr. Glasscock is a former banker who has engineered a string of acquisitions since he joined Anthem as chief executive in 1999. He said the WellPoint deal would close in mid-2004, assuming approvals by shareholders, federal antitrust officials and state insurance departments as well as the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. The companies said they did not expect to encounter antitrust concerns, because they generally do not compete against each other.
 Dr. Donald J. Palmisano, president of the American Medical Association, said the two merger announcements raised concerns that "the country is headed toward a health care system dominated by a few publicly traded companies that operate primarily in the interest of shareholders."
 On a conference call, Mr. Glasscock noted that the new WellPoint "will have No.1 market share in 12 states." He added that Anthem and WellPoint both "have substantial experience in making acquisitions work."
 Anthem and WellPoint may have agreed to combine because efforts to convert Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans to for-profit status have stalled, analysts said. An attempt by Anthem to merge with the Blues in Kansas was blocked by state authorities, as were WellPoint deals in Maryland and Washington. "The pipeline of nonprofit conversions has dried up," Scott Fidel, a health care analyst at J.P. Morgan, said. WellChoice Inc., the parent of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York, is the only other for-profit company in the Blues system. 
 Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care analyst and managing director at the Carlyle Group, said: "WellChoice could be a merger target for the new WellPoint, but I would be very surprised if that happened soon." 
 Credit analysts expressed some concerns about the new WellPoint. "We view the ultimate company as being enhanced from an operating company perspective and being a little bit weaker from the holding company debt perspective," said Shellie Stoddard, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, the bond rating agency.
 The acquisitions of Anthem and WellPoint added $3 billion of goodwill to the books of each company, and the merger will pile another $11 billion of goodwill onto the combined company, she said. WellPoint has added plans in Georgia, Missouri and Wisconsin to its California base. Anthem, from a core in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky, expanded by acquiring plans in Connecticut, New Hampshire, Colorado, Maine, Nevada and Virginia.
 Mr. Glasscock said the deal would bring $50 million in savings next year, rising to $250 million in 2006, mainly from administrative and technology costs, and rebates through joint buying from drug makers. 
Mr. Schaeffer said WellPoint had adopted computer systems that incorporate new software for tasks like data analysis without disrupting older systems used in customer service. In the past, computer glitches have caused big problems for a number of growing insurers, notably Oxford Health Plans and the the Cigna Corporation.
 Douglas Sherlock, an independent consultant to a number of Blue Cross plans, said the main savings from the merger would come from using the new WellPoint's Blue Cross credentials to woo insurance brokers. 
 In the UnitedHealth deal, Mid Atlantic investors will receive $18 a share in cash and .82 United Health share for each Mid Atlantic share. In trading Monday, UnitedHealth shares fell $1.85, or 3.41 percent, to close at $52.40. Mid Atlantic shares rose $5.74, or 10.65 percent, to $59.62.
 Mid Atlantic's customers are in Washington, Virginia, Delaware, West Virginia, North Carolina and Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: Another Visit to China, Another Warning From a U.S. Official 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans plans to give China its toughest warning so far that the administration is growing impatient with Beijing's refusal to fully open its markets to American goods and services.
 Mr. Evans will deliver that message in a speech in Beijing on Tuesday, ratcheting up pressure that has been steadily building since September by a parade of top administration visitors, according to an advance copy of the speech. 
 In a blunt critique, Mr. Evans will accuse China of failing to keep the promises it made when it joined the World Trade Organization. They included reforming its markets, lowering its trade barriers and ridding itself of protectionism by the government and by its industries.
 "China is moving far too slowly in its transition to an open, market-based economy," Mr. Evans will say in the speech. "We have been patient, but our patience is wearing thin." 
 Frustration over the weak economy and joblessness has focused increasingly on China and has become a campaign issue for Republicans and Democrats alike. 
 The United States imports five times more than it exports to China, leading to a trade deficit that could reach $130 billion this year.
 Mr. Evans will warn of this growing tide of resentment toward China, repeatedly saying "we are already seeing signs of rising protectionist sentiments."
 American manufacturers, some of whom are large donors to President Bush's campaign, have insisted that the imbalance is because of the artificially low value of the Chinese currency. They want the Chinese to float their currency on the open market, which would weaken the dollar and lower the price of American goods abroad while making Chinese imports more expensive in the American market.
 Democratic and Republican lawmakers, responding to the closing of manufacturing plants in their districts, have introduced legislation that would impose a 27 percent tariff on Chinese exports to the United States if Beijing fails to embark on a market-based currency. 
 While saying that the administration opposes these measures, Mr. Evans plans to say that the "U.S. market will not remain open forever under unfair terms."
 These themes will sound familiar to Chinese officials who heard similar, if more diplomatic, complaints from Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, when he was in Beijing last week. Mr. Zoellick told the Chinese that the United States needed a two-way street, to try to expand U.S. exports to China.
 In September, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow had pushed China to raise the value of its currency. In response, the Chinese said they would take "interim steps" to loosen restrictions on the country's tightly controlled financial system. 
 The speech by Mr. Evans will pointedly say that is not enough.
 "Time is running out," he will say. "We need to see results. There is friction and the slow pace of reform in the Chinese market is the source of the friction."

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: OCCUPATION; 
Iraq Paradox: Cracking Down While Promoting Freedom

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
At one of the first meetings of the White House's new Iraq Stabilization Group, days before the series of attacks on Monday that left at least 34 dead, President Bush's aides debated the trade-off between locking down Baghdad and demonstrating to Iraqis that they now live in an open society, where they are free to shop, go to work or even protest the American-led occupation.
 "It wasn't much of a discussion," one of Mr. Bush's senior aides reported. "We couldn't turn the place into a police state for long, even if we wanted to. And if we did, it would be a Pyrrhic victory." 
 Now that question is more urgent than ever.
Even with the number and sophistication of the daily attacks accelerating, Mr. Bush's response to questions about how the United States should respond has become almost automatic: The United States is slowly winning hearts and minds, and making Saddam Hussein's loyalists "more desperate" each day. 
The situation will improve, he argues, as Iraqis themselves take more and more authority over the security scene.
Meanwhile, Mr. Bush's aides and Pentagon officials describe what is going on as a war of attrition, against enemies whose resources are being depleted, suggesting they will eventually run out of steam.
But when speaking on background, some senior administration officials acknowledge that some of those answers are beginning to ring hollow. Retraining the Iraqi Army, as Mr. Bush was reminded again on Monday in an Oval Office meeting with L. Paul Bremer III, the chief of the American authority in Iraq, is a slow business -- far too slow for the urgency of the problems facing the occupation forces. 
While the mixture of loyalists to Saddam Hussein, foreign infiltrators and released criminals may not be able to build momentum over the long term, they have certainly built some in the past few weeks -- as demonstrated by the attack on the Rashid Hotel on Sunday and the apparently coordinated attacks on the Red Cross and police stations on Monday. 
Targets like those could be cordoned off with new bomb barriers, new walls, new restrictions on movement.
But then, said one senior official, "you would have Beirut, without the ocean view." 
So the decision for now is to avoid a crackdown, especially one so disruptive of everyday life that Arabs could seize upon it as evidence that Iraqis have simply traded one kind of repression for another. 
The first test has already descended on the administration: Ramadan. Only a few hours after the bombing on Monday, Maj. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, the commander of the Fourth Infantry Division, was telling reporters how his troops had been told to keep their distance during the most sacred month on the Muslim calendar. He said they should "not really be patrolling or be around those areas when they are in their time of -- when they're conducting their prayers."
In other words, in the name of a light touch and religious freedom, General Odierno's troops are creating another buffer zone -- one where Iraqis can observe the holy month, and where holdovers of the old government and their foreign allies can plan and try to carry out terror attacks.
It is not clear that there are any other choices. The attack on the Rashid Hotel on Sunday, during the visit of the deputy secretary of defense, Paul D. Wolfowitz, underscores the nature of the problem. The hotel is well within a security buffer, and it is surrounded by a wall. 
Its attackers had to fire their rockets from hundreds of yards away, with a makeshift launcher hidden in a portable electric generator. A wider security perimeter would probably have halted the attack, and saved the life of the one American, an Army colonel, who was killed in his hotel room.
But it also would have required closing down an entire Baghdad neighborhood, one filled with Iraqis who, for the most part, have welcomed Mr. Hussein's ouster from power.
"Locking down Baghdad would take enormous manpower and resources, more than the administration has been willing to provide," said Michele A. Flournoy, a scholar at the Center for Strategic and International Studies here, and a former Pentagon official in the Clinton administration. 
Even were such a lockdown possible, she said, "It would be at a great cost -- perhaps at the cost of turning the Baghdad population against us, decisively."
That would be risky at any moment, she said, but particularly now, "at a tipping point where we must keep the Baghdad population with us, or at least not against us.
"If we make their life difficult," Ms. Flournoy said, "we may lose their support."
That is the kind of problem that Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser, had in mind when she created the Iraq Stabilization Group, the coordinating committee inside the White House that is supposed to hone Mr. Bush's message, keep the Iraqi economy growing, and balance good military practice and good politics.
It is a balancing act, one senior administration official said during Mr. Bush's trip to Asia, that is being made all the more difficult by the absence of vocal support from the rest of the Arab world.
There has been no outcry, he noted, from "neighboring states -- our allies -- as the attacks on Americans have mounted. No outcry at all. Which has got to embolden the terror groups."
Mr. Bush is also increasingly concerned about the infiltration of foreign fighters from the Iranian and Syrian borders. Measuring their numbers is nearly impossible, American officials say. But the concern is that they are a source of continuing funds, technology and strength for the pro-Hussein forces.
The White House strategy, one senior official noted, depends heavily on choking off those funds, guns and explosives so that the Hussein loyalists are gradually starved of resources. "To look at the plan," the senior official said, "the starvation effect should have started a few months ago. It didn't -- and that's something to worry about."

HEADLINE: BANKING GIANT: THE HOMETOWN; 
Fear of Losing Name With Roots in Colonial Boston

BYLINE:  By KATIE ZEZIMA 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 27 

 BODY:
Through mergers and acquisitions over the years, FleetBoston Financial has become the foremost banking institution in New England. But with Bank of America's announcement on Monday that it will acquire Fleet in a $48 billion deal, the Fleet name may soon disappear from the cityscape it now dominates. 
 The merger with Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., was greeted here with mixed reactions. Public officials cautioned that the deal could hurt the Boston economy. But some financial analysts said that it could lead to improved banking services in New England. 
 Fleet's roots in Boston go back to 1784, when, as Massachusetts Bank, it was the first federally chartered bank in the United States. Fleet has branches throughout the city. FleetCenter is the home of Boston's basketball and hockey teams. FleetBoston Pavilion is a popular outdoor concert center on Boston Harbor. The bank has a prominent presence in Providence, R.I., with the Fleet Skating Center, and it has large regional headquarters in Portland, Me., and Manchester, N.H. 
 "Now the control is moving out," said William F. Galvin, secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. "This is now a loss of control outside the region, and nothing can be clearer than that the offices are in North Carolina and not here. They're in the same time zone, but not the same economic zone."
 Mr. Galvin said he might conduct a regulatory review of the two companies if they decide to consolidate their mutual fund divisions. 
 While Fleet has merged before, most recently when it acquired BankBoston in 1999, Mr. Galvin said this deal was different because the institution would no longer be headquartered in Boston. Although Charles K. Gifford, chief executive of Fleet, said staffing levels at the bank would remain the same, Mr. Galvin worries that will not be true for long. 
 "History shows that these assurances are short-lived," he said.
 The Fleet deal comes after the announcement last month of the acquisition of John Hancock Financial Services, based in Boston, by Manulife Financial of Canada for $11 billion in stock. Gillette, Fidelity Investments, Liberty Mutual, Putnam Investments and the State Street Corporation are the city's remaining large companies.
 Gerard S. Cassidy, the managing director for equity research at the Portland, Me., office of RBC Capital Markets, said the Fleet deal would affect the psyche of New Englanders accustomed to having a major bank based in their region. But he said that over a 5- to 10-year period, the merger would benefit the region. 
 "Fleet Bank recognized it was becoming increasingly difficult to remain competitive in the large banking arena. In the near term, Fleet's decision was a major win for its shareholders," Mr. Cassidy said. "It means the region is now serviced by a very large bank with a significant presence in the U.S.," he noted, with significant capital "to lend into the New England market."
 Mr. Cassidy said that while the 1999 consolidation of Fleet and BankBoston caused widespread layoffs and customer complaints, that should not happen with the new deal because Fleet and Bank of America are not competitors in the local market. The Fleet acquisition will, for the first time, give Bank of America a presence in New England. As for job losses, Mr. Cassidy said he thought any layoffs at the corporate headquarters would be made up with jobs created at new branches.
 Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston said there were still "a lot of questions to be answered" about the merger, including how it would affect several thousand Fleet jobs in the state and the bank's substantial community-giving program. 
 But Mayor David N. Cicilline of Providence said he had received assurances from Mr. Gifford that the 3,900 Fleet employees in Rhode Island would keep their jobs and that more jobs might be created. Mr. Cicilline said he thought that Fleet's philanthropic activities would go on. "He reassured me of the bank's continuing contribution to Providence," Mr. Cicilline said. 
 Some Fleet customers also said they were concerned that the merger would eliminate jobs and weaken the economy. Jason Dalrymple, 27, a consultant from Quincy, Mass., has been a Fleet customer for nine years. "I'm a little skeptical and I think even though we will see some layoffs," he said, "I hope the customer service doesn't change." 
 Many Fleet employees who were questioned outside the bank's headquarters and in its branches would not discuss the merger. But one employee at a branch in downtown Boston, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not fear for his job. "I don't think it's going to change anything at all," he said. "I'm not worried because Bank of America has nothing in the Northeast." 
 As for the name of FleetCenter, an arena spokeswoman, Courtney McIlhenny, said whether that would change was "up in the air" because of a contract provision.
 But at a news conference, Kenneth D. Lewis, chief executive of Bank of America, said, "I'd love for it to be the Bank of America Center," the Associated Press reported. 
 A Fleet spokesman did not return numerous telephone calls for comment.

HEADLINE: Zillions Of Universes? Or Did Ours Get Lucky? 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS OVERBYE

DATELINE: CLEVELAND 

 BODY:
Cosmology used to be a heartless science, all about dark matter lost in mind-bending abysses and exploding stars. But whenever physicists and astronomers gather, the subject that roils lunch, coffee breaks or renegade cigarette breaks tends to be not dark matter or the fate of the universe. Rather it is about the role and meaning of life in the cosmos.
 Cosmologists held an unusual debate on the question during a recent conference, "The Future of Cosmology," at Case Western Reserve University here. 
 According to a controversial notion known as the anthropic principle, certain otherwise baffling features of the universe can only be understood by including ourselves in the equation. The universe must be suitable for life, otherwise we would not be here to wonder about it. 
The features in question are mysterious numbers in the equations of physics and cosmology, denoting, say, the amount of matter in the universe or the number of dimensions, which don't seem predictable by any known theory -- yet. They are like the knobs on God's control console, and they seem almost miraculously tuned to allow life.
A slight tweak one way or another from the present settings could cause all stars to collapse into black holes or atoms to evaporate, negating the possibility of biology.
If there were only one universe, theorists would have their hands full trying to explain why it is such a lucky one.
But supporters of the anthropic principle argue that there could be zillions of possible universes, many different possible settings ruled by chance. Their view has been bolstered in recent years by a theory of the Big Bang, known as inflation, which implies that our universe is only one bubble in an endless chain of them, and by string theory -- the so-called theory of everything -- whose equations seem to have an almost uncountable number of solutions, each representing a different possible universe.
Only a few of these will be conducive to life, the anthropic argument goes, but it is no more surprise to find ourselves in one of them than it is to find ourselves on the moist warm Earth rather than on Pluto.
In short we live where we can live, but those can be fighting words.
Scientists agree that the name "anthropic principle," is pretentious, but that's all they agree on. Some of them regard the idea as more philosophy than science. Others regard it as a betrayal of the Einsteinian dream of predicting everything about the universe.
Dr. David Gross regards it as a virus. "Once you get the bug you can't get rid of it," he complained at the conference.
Dr. Gross, director of the Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics in Santa Barbara, Calif., had agreed to lead a panel discussion on the notorious principle. Often found puffing on a cigar, he is not known to be shy about expressing his opinion.
"I was chosen because I hate the anthropic principle," he said.
But playing a central role in defending the need for what he called "anthropic reasoning" was Dr. Steven Weinberg, a Nobel laureate from the University of Texas. Like Dr. Gross, Dr. Weinberg is a particle physicist who is known for being a hard-core reductionist in his approach to science, but he evinces a gloomy streak in his writings and his talks. He is still famous for writing in his 1977 book, "The First Three Minutes," "The more the universe seems comprehensible, the more it also seems pointless."
Dr. Weinberg is among the most prominent of theorists who have reluctantly accepted, at least provisionally, the anthropic principle as a kind of tragic necessity in order to explain the gnarliest knob of all.
Called the cosmological constant, it is a number that measures the amount of cosmic repulsion caused by the energy in empty space. That empty space should be boiling with such energy is predicted by quantum theory, and astronomers in the last few years have discovered that some cosmic repulsion seems to be accelerating the expansion of the universe. But theoretical attempts to calculate this constant, also known as lambda, result in numbers 1060 times as high as those astronomers have measured. 
So despairing are physicists of understanding the cosmological constant that Dr. Weinberg joked earlier at the meeting that he would no longer read papers about it.
Back in 1989, before any cosmological constant had been discovered, Dr. Weinberg used the anthropic principle to set limits on the value of the constant. Suppose instead of being fixed by theory, it was random from universe to universe. In that case the value of the cosmological constant in our universe may just be an "environmental effect," he explained, and we shouldn't expect to be able to predict it exactly any more than you can calculate how much rain will fall in Seattle this Christmas.
In his paper, Dr. Weinberg argued that lambda in our universe could not be too big or the repulsive force would have prevented the formation of galaxies, stars and us. Since we are here, the constant should be small.
The recently discovered "dark energy" causing the cosmic acceleration fits comfortably inside Dr. Weinberg's limits, vindicating in a way the anthropic approach.
In his talk, Dr. Weinberg described the anthropic principle as "the sort of historical realization scientists have been forced to make from time to time."
"Our hope was to explain everything," he said. "Part of progress is we learn what we can explain on fundamental grounds and what we cannot."
Other panelists, including Dr. Alex Vilenkin, a physicist from Tufts University, suggested that the anthropic reasoning was a logical attempt to apply probabilities to cosmology, using all the data, including the fact of our own existence. Dr. John Peacock, a cosmologist at the University of Edinburgh, argued that the anthropic principle was not a retreat from physics, but an advance. The existence of an ensemble of universes with different properties, he explained, implies a mechanism to produce variation, a kind of cosmic genetic code, the way that evolution implies the existence of genes.
"You gain new physics," Dr. Peacock said.
But when his own turn came, Dr. Gross questioned whether the rules of the anthropic game were precise enough. What were the parameters that could vary from universe to universe? How many could vary at once? What was the probability distribution of their values, and what was necessary for "life"?
Anthropic calculations are inherently vague and imprecise, he said. As a result, the principle could not be disproved. But he was only getting warmed up. His real objection, he said, was "totally emotional." 
Ascribing the parameters of physics to mere chance or vagaries of cosmic weather is defeatist, discouraging people from undertaking the difficult calculations that would actually explain why things are they way they are. Moreover, it is also dangerous, he declared to ringing applause.
"It smells of religion and intelligent design," he said, referring to a variety of creationism that argues that the universe is too complex to have evolved by chance.
Dr. Lawrence Krauss, the astrophysicist from Case Western who had organized the conference and recruited the panel, characterized the anthropic principle as "a way of killing time" when physicists didn't have a better idea. Dr. Krauss, who has battled creationists over biology instruction in the public schools in Ohio, said he had encountered anthropic arguments as an argument for fine-tuning, the idea that God had fixed the universe just for us.
Dr. Weinberg replied that the anthropic principle was not really a part of science, but rather "a guess about the future shape of science."
"If we didn't have things in our universe that seem peculiar, like the value of the cosmological constant, we wouldn't worry about it," he said.
Dr. Weinberg compared the situation to a person who is dealt a royal flush in a poker tournament. It may be chance, he said, but there is another explanation: "Namely, is the organizer of the tournament our friend?"
"But that leads to the argument about religion," he said to much laughter.
In fact, Dr. Weinberg said, the anthropic principle was "a nice nontheistic explanation of why things are as nice as they are."
By then the audience was squirming to get in on the action. Hands were waving as Dr. Gross called the session to an end. "Clearly there is a diversity of opinion," he intoned. "Some people find the small value of cosmological constant so bizarre that only the anthropic principle will pick it out." 
Nobody who adheres to the anthropic principle, he said, would hold on if there were "an honest old-fashioned calculation," that explained the cosmological constant.
Given the floor for the last word, Dr. Weinberg agreed that it was too soon to give up hope for such a breakthrough. "I'm prepared to go on hoping that one will be found," he said. "But after the passage of time one begins to entertain other possibilities, and the anthropic explanation is another possibility."
Applying that mode of reasoning, he said, could help make the cosmological constant less peculiar, 
"But we don't know if that's the help that we really deserve to get," he concluded.
And it was time for lunch.
Dr. Gross reported later that younger physicists had thanked him for his stand.
Dr. Weinberg said the panel had generated more fuss than the subject deserved.
"Those who favor taking the anthropic principle seriously don't really like it," he said, "and those who argue against it recognize that it may be unavoidable."
